It is one of those games that you recommend to a person that has never played a video game before, wholesome, the night sky is beautiful, the animation is awesome and like many reviews say, it is refreshing to have a platformer/adventure game  with no attack button, it does take elements from other games like crystal dynamic's tomb raider climbing and jumping from cliffs part and it feels like TLOZ: Wind Waker animation wise......but still being it's own original game, it is one of those little games you want to enjoy and just look at the details and look for secrets and the way the story is told without words could mesmerize anyone new to gaming, again, I would love to see more from this studio and I know I haven't finished the game yet but it reminds me of my dog soooooooooo much that it's kinda special when I boot the game up so even if it takes me a year to finish a 10 or so hour game, I will do so at my own pace, 10/10, if you are looking for something to just enjoy and feel with a good story, this is it, give it a go and thank me later.

143415938.review:
Me: this game is perfect for modern activists.
Someone: how do you figure?
Me: because this is the only game I know where yelling at the top of their lungs gets them anywhere.

[h1] Introduction [/h1]

RiME is an puzzle/adventure game developed by Tequila Works, with heavy emphasis in visual and environmental storytelling. To be honest, I played this game before cracked, but I decided to buy it to support the developers, because I liked it... a lot. Let me explain why.

[h1] Worldbuilding [/h1]

It's difficult to talk about worldbuilding in a game like this, because the player visits several worlds, each with its own theme and aesthetics, but one thing they have in common is their rules. The way puzzles are resolved is consistent in every world, and seem to function the same, no matter where the player are in the game, which implies the existence of some sort of magic. And given the overall intentions of the writers with this game, I'd say it's pretty consistent in essence. If the rules were different for each world, taking into account the main storyline, that would be jarring, and would disconnect the player from the flow of the story. Fortunately, that doesn't happen.

[h1] The plot [/h1]

Surprinsingly, the plot of this game is very simple. It's just the story of a person going through the five states of grief. Why this person is grieving I won't mention, because it'd spoil the whole story and would robbed it from it's punch, because the story of this game packs a punch alright. I said this game relies heavily, if not completely, on visual and environmental storytelling, and it does it wonderfully. It conveys a hard-hitting messsage without any line of dialogue. Seriously. This game has no dialogue, but the story is written and designed in such a way that they didn't need to. It takes the "show, don't tell" mantra to a whole new level. And that's applicable to either the story and the gameplay (which I'll discuss in the related section). Pro-tip: getting all the white shades makes the ending way more powerful. Refer to guides if you are lost.

[h1] The characters [/h1]

This game features only two characters, a father and his son. The player controls the son. Since there is no dialogue, it's hard to evaluate goals, motivations and personalities. But his actions throughout the game speaks of someone who is kind and compassionate, because of how he interacts with different elements or sentient beings in the game, and the father obviously loves his son, because of some things that happen at the end of the game. Some beings, like the fox, the sentinels and the giant bird are allegories to things in the world the child used to belong to, and represent the five stages of grief perfectly.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

The gameplay is also pretty simple. The character the player controls can jump, roll, crouch, grab to ledges, the works. Basic platforming, in short. There are underwater zones too. He can also interact with several objects, like blocks, keys, balls of light and other elements. The puzzles in this game are basic but curiously satisfying. There are basic perspective puzzles, light and dark puzzles, activate all statues puzzles, and so on. The player can also make the playable character to use his voice to a number of purposes, like breaking jars, light up fires, even to solve most of the puzzles in the game (hence, the comment at the beginning). Because the controls are simple and intuitive, the main character is easy to control, and makes traversing the world a breeze. There are no tutorials that break the momentum of the game, only unintrusive control pop-ins when performing an action for the first time that don't stop the flow of the game whatsoever. Oh, and there is plenty of collectibles, too.

[h1] Artistic and technical elements [/h1]

The art direction of this game is lovely and somewhat cartoonish, but fits the setting and the tone of the game. Sure, this game hasn't the best of graphics, but, with a story like that, who needs ultra-realistic graphics? Plus, the art direction more than makes up for it. But one thing this game deserves praise is the music. It combines with the story to give it extra punch, and makes all the emotional highs of the game even better. Since there is no dialogue, I won't mention voice acting quality, but the sounds the boy makes fits the actions he performs and the context he is in. The performance, though, is a mixed bag. I played this game for the first time with a laptop GTX 1060, and the framerate dropped like a rock, even when the visuals doesn't look demanding at all. I had to lower the settings to get a playable framerate, so optimization was an issue then. I wouldn't know now, because my RTX 4070 runs everything just fine. The collision system needs work, though, because there were places that the character won't move, even when there wasn't any collision object, like a step or a wall.

In conclusion:

[b] Pros: [/b]

-Excellent story with a hard-hitting message.
-Superb visual and environmental storytelling.
-Simple but functional gameplay.
-The music was just awesome.

[b] Cons: [/b]

-Some performance issues (and that's tentative)
-Collision system is imperfect in some instances.

I wish more developers told stories the way this game does, because dialogue, if not done well, can do horrors to a story-driven game, Forspoken being a prime example of this. This game, on the other hand, thanks to the strength of its visual and environmental storytelling, its no-frills gameplay and tear-inducing ending, has no need for it. It's amazing how much this game achieves with so little, and that's why I recommend this game.

140873228.review:
If you want to watch the full video review on [u]the Cheapness Reviews [/u] YouTube channel:
https://youtu.be/3pXinw_cvXE
Quick Text Review:

You seemingly washed up on an island, almost no voice and guidance. Try and figure it out in this artsy game... where the protagonist has a mullet!
-Simple 3D platforming (Like a stripped down Prince of Persia)
-Inventive, if easy, puzzles to solve
-Some collectables to find (If there is a feeling of forward momentum and backtracking is discouraged)
-That may sound negative but the game is fun
-Implied/ symbolic story telling that at first felt like common indie fare (With some predictable elements) but there was a symbolic layer that only revealed itself at the end when I saw the cut scene and took a look at the level selection screen that paid off emotionally (If that screen is available before the end of the game I STRONGLY RECOMMEND YOU AVOID IT TO PREVENT A SPOILER!)
-No dialogue though
-Lovely sombre music that drives the symbolism home
-Great cell shaded visuals depicting beautiful Mediterranean environs
-Really worthwhile but ultimately an artsy game where the game play isn't the point as much 

Practical Concerns:
-Bad value for money (R13.93/ hour for me - $ and £ values in video)
-Fairly big download size (7.26 Gb on the hard drive)
-Not THAT easy to run
-I'd argue it's kid friendly in spite of the more grim elements

I really was not expecting this kind of experiencie. The music, the environments, the mechanics are very well done for a game if you just want an inmersion and explirative game.

But, to be honest, this time, in which I am writing this review is a very difficult time in my life, I am passing through several mourning in my life; and, getting to the end of this game, and acknowledging the whole narrative, the whole landscapes and things we did in all the game reflected a mourning was a huge shock for me.

Not a bad shock, I mean, it made me a little bit sad, but it also made me appreciate all the effort, and it made me reflect on the mourning stages I have been going through. Exiting to the main menu to see the names of each stage blew my mind too.

I simply recomned this game, it is beautiful, well done, and very emotional.

Thank you to the developpers for making this, it made me happier to play this game, and to know that this was done with such care and love, thinking in the emotional journey we all are in as human beings.

¡Muchas gracias!

134789964.review: It wasn't for me. Fundamentally, the problems with the game all arise from the fact that moving around is slow, not particularly enjoyable, and does not involve meaningful gameplay vis a vis challenge or interactivity. The puzzles aren't fun because they too often revolve around you painstakingly meandering around the area, moving things back and forth and forth and back. The exploration isn't fun because it's slow but also requires no mechanical effort or skill. The collecting and discovering isn't fun because the game's linearity means it feels like a chore you have to complete before you move on instead of an opportunity, exacerbated by the game's intentional vagueness (which I otherwise do not find fault with) making it unclear when you are actually pushing yourself past a point of no return. It's trying to be meditative but ends up feeling plodding.

134125248.review:
Es difícil encontrar un juego más bonito que este, en el sentido más amplio del término. Todo en él va de la mano para crear una experiencia emotiva y preciosista. 

El apartado artístico es una pasada. Cuenta con escenarios tremendamente bellos (con diferentes paletas de colores), y con unos personajes adorables. En cuanto a la banda sonora, puedo decir que es de las más bonitas que he oído nunca en un videojuego.

Por otro lado, la jugabilidad es la clásica del género. No deja de ser un walking simulator con algo de plataformas y puzles sencillos, pero funciona todo a las mil maravillas (controles muy sólidos y fiables).

Lo único malo que tiene es el rendimiento. No está todo lo bien optimizado que debería y, a veces, sufre bajadas de FPS sin sentido. Al menos, ya no tiene Denuvo (espero que hayan aprendido y no vuelvan a usarlo nunca más).

Me sorprende que este juego y su banda sonora no hayan sido más reconocidos. Desconozco los motivos, no sé si adoleció de publicidad en su momento, pero para mí, dentro del mundillo de los [i]juegos contemplativos[/i] recientes, RiME es, sin duda alguna, el mejor de todos (ligeramente por delante de GRIS, y bastante por encima de otros más conocidos como Journey o ABZÛ).

En resumen, RiME es un imprescindible si buscas algo relajado, bonito o emocional.

125376940.review:
RiME is a fun 3D adventure puzzle game.
You take on the role of a kid washed up to shore on a strange island after an apparent ship wreck, and have the piece together the mystery of what happened and solve puzzles to get through each area of this strange new world. 

This game is really fun, and has a fantastic soundtrack. It plays like a 3D Zelda game as far as the puzzle solving goes, and that's the majority of the game play along with exploration elements. There is no real combat per say in this game, as you don't really fight any enemies. Aside from running away from and avoiding a giant bird that wants to eat you, or getting around ghosts that literally suck your life energy or soul out of you. You have no conventional weapons, you have no portable tools. Have to use your head and the items around you to figure out each puzzle, how to deal with the giant bird, or how to avoid the deadly soul sucking ghosts.

There is a twist at the end of the game that can make it a  real emotional gut punch, and I think it's really well done. I just find myself wishing the game was a little longer.

Over all, I would highly recommend playing this, especially if you're a fan of the puzzle solving aspects of the more 3D Zelda games.

124889028.review:
Aunque esté mal hacerlo, voy a empezar por lo malo del juego... y lo peor que tiene el juego es su optimización.

Lo jugué en un Ryzen 3 1200 con una 1050ti y sufrí tremendas caídas de FPS en zonas con muchas partículas (como la parte final con la lluvia o las zonas con caídas de agua) hasta tal punto que se hacía injugable e incluso me daban náuseas de los movimientos de cámara tan bruscos. Sin embargo ni el uso de CPU ni el uso de GPU llegaban al 100%, pocas veces subían por encima del 90%. Era como si no hubiera ni cuello de botella de CPU ni GPU, pero el juego "no iba fino".

Pude disfrutar y completar el juego con un portátil con una 1060m de 6 GB y un i7-7700HQ.

Ahora (al escribir esta reseña) he cambiado el R3 1200 por un Ryzen 5 5600G y el juego se comporta de manera estable prácticamente como una roca a 60 fps con exactamente la misma gráfica (la 1050ti), memoria, etc. Eso significa que de alguna manera el cuello de CPU era el procesador, pero me sigue pareciendo extrañísimo que no se pusiera al 100% para indicarlo. ¿Quizá no era capaz de aprovechar el paralelismo de los cuatro núcleos y su rendimiento estaba fijado por lo que era capaz de dar un único núcleo en particular?

Bueno, ahora la reseña "buena" del juego:

El juego no tiene una elevada dificultad, ni falta que le hace para poder ser disfrutable. Los puzzles se dejan resolver con sencillez y muy pocas veces nos veremos perdidos en el mundo buscando cómo resolverlos.

Para mí eso es un punto muy positivo.

He jugado a juegos en los que me he quedado atascado en algún puzzle durante más tiempo del deseado no porque no fuera capaz de resolverlo por mí mismo, si no porque no estaba bien diseñado el juego para "mostrar" las pistas necesarias para que lo resuelvas, y en algunas ocasiones la resolución parecía que tenías que saberla de antemano sin que recibieras pistas de ninguna manera.

En ese aspecto este juego me parece fantástico. Un equilibrio muy bueno que, además, suma el hecho de que tras finalizarlo (y soltar unas lágrimas por la empatía que te genera el juego) quieras jugar un poco más para encontrar los juguetes perdidos.

Al final no he completado esa tarea, pero fue en lo primero en lo que pensé cuando lo terminé, pero sugerí a mi hija que lo jugara y eso terminó haciéndome olvidar ese impulso de buscar yo mismo los objetos coleccionables que dejé atrás.

Como mi hija solo pudo jugar en el PC con el Ryzen 3 1200, lo dejó abandonado cuando llegó a la zona de la lluvia (casi al final del juego). No me dijo directamente el motivo por el que lo abandonó, pero imagino que (al igual que yo) se debió sentir mal tras jugar un rato con tan mal rendimiento.

Ahora que he ampliado el PC doméstico espero que se anime a retomar el juego y que disfrute de esta inolvidable aventura tanto como la disfruté yo.

119119556.review:
I was always really excited for RiME, following it closely before it's release, and when it finally did come out I bought it in the first week. It is an absolutely beautiful game, the environments and visual style are charming, and it really delivers the aesthetic experience that it promised in it's marketing. 
That is, unfortunately, where the praise ends, as aesthetic alone is not enough to drive progression of this particular experience, and both the puzzle design and the story are in need of improvement. Despite owning this game since release, it has taken me 5 years to make any significant progress on it.
The story isn't bad, it's just not particularly compelling, falling prey to the phenomenon of feeling primarily driven by plot rather than by the motivations of the character.
The puzzle design was where I encountered the most frustration, often not knowing what my goal was, I spent most of the game just doing whatever was available to me at the time, hoping that it would lead to progression. A number of times I got completely stuck, not because the puzzle was difficult, but because the goal was completely unclear. 

I would love to see more from this developer in future if their puzzle design and storytelling was improved upon, but I can't recommend RiME as a worthwhile experience.

118618341.review:
This game is beautiful and emotional, and normally this is the type of game I'd love, but it has a number of issues that make me hesitant to recommend it.

First, the gameplay. Your player character moves rather slowly, and feels very stiff and heavy to move. It felt really cumbersome playing as him, especially since the game features lots of platforming and exploration. The camera is awkward as hell, and will fix angles for you whether you want it to or not.

Second, the collectables. There are so many freaking collectables in this game, and most of them feel pointless. The toy collectables contribute to the game's ending, one outfit helps with an achievement and the shells unlock a nice lullaby, but beyond that, none of the collectables unlock any special features. Combined with the awkward game mechanics above, they feel more like a chore to collect after awhile.

Third (and probably most relevant to a lot of people), the price. Forty freaking dollars??? For an indie game that you can beat in under 10 hours? This isn't something like, say, Hellblade or A Plague Tale, which weren't triple A games but still clearly had a sizeable budget and a lot of work put into the graphics, voice acting, etc. This game feels massively overpriced for what it is, especially when similar games like Journey, ABZU, or even Gris each cost $20 or less.

Honestly tho I think the MAIN reason I don't fully recommend this game is the attitude of the developers. For the last Steam Awards they tried to encourage their fans to help make it a candidate for the Labor of Love award...even tho the last update for the game was four years ago. Either the devs genuinely didn't understand what the award was for, or their sense of ego was so inflated they thought they could get away with getting an undeserved nomination. I'm hoping it's the former, but either way it leaves a bad taste in my mouth.

This is not a bad game by any means, and I did find parts of it enjoyable, but there are better games out there, including but also ESPECIALLY Journey, ABZU, and Gris mentioned above. If you are still interested wait until the game goes on sale, and be sure the play the aforementioned games to experience this type of game done right.

117652916.review: I don't often do reviews but I thought I'd give a warning if you're looking at this game and you're an achievement hunter. For the record, I enjoyed the game. But if you're interested in 100%-ing this game and want to save some time, ABSOLUTELY follow a guide on your FIRST playthrough.  Most of the guides state that there are no missable achievements because there's a chapter select at the end of the game.  But if you're like me and did a blind first playthrough to simply enjoy the game and casually found collectibles here and there, then you might as well replay the whole game a second time if you want to get the rest of them. The reason is that chapter select obviously starts you a the beginning of each chapter, so if for example the collectible you missed was the last one in that chapter, you have to play through all of it, since the last collectible is usually right before the end.

116726782.review: This is an impressive puzzle-platforming adventure game. Rime plays similarly to games like ICO and Journey wherein the player must explore environments and solve mostly intuitive puzzles. The game largely succeeds with its' aims to tell a story that is conveyed visually, but it is also supported by a moving score. Some of the set pieces may feel a little drawn out, but none of them truly take away from the altogether immersive experience. What does hitch the experience up on occasion are frame drops and performance issues. The game is beautiful and has a strong artistic style but performance issues seem unjustified. And though they are rare, they do mar slightly the otherwise smooth and mostly unbroken gameplay. It is a simple game that does not overbear the player or overstay its' course. There are also numerous optional items and secrets to collect and so, depending on player investment, it could provide a bit of replay value.

Would recommend this game despite the relatively short play-time based on the absolutely gorgeous presentation. Wait for a sale as the running-time is a detractor.
The presentation of the experience is beautiful and near flawless, from visual to sound design everything lines up to completely engage you into the flow of the action. This brings me to the crux of the "game", while the opening (the parts you mostly see in the screenshots) is breezy and light the actual theme of the game is emotional and themed with sadness. There's much in RiME to discover and collect but due to the nature of the story I don't think we will be replaying it.

110650265.review:
RiME is a puzzle platformer that focuses more on the experience than the difficulty (of both the puzzles and the platforming). If you are reading this review because you saw the screenshots and it looks like the kind of game that you would like then I would definitely recommend it: It's extremely well done for what it is, looks even better in motion, and also has really good sound and music design.

Based purely on game mechanics I would rate it as good but not great (although there are a handful of stand out puzzles). If you aren't interested in the more emotional/artistic aspects of games then there are probably other games that you would enjoy more. Even with that caveat, however, RiME has the feeling of being a labor of love, and it feels like the result of not only a strong initial design vision but also the result of iteration and polish so that everything works together well and the whole feels greater than the sum of its individual parts. I think it is a good example of a game that does exactly what it sets out to do.
(I think it's worth giving a special mention to the use of dynamic music in the game. I was constantly impressed with how the music seamlessly reacted to what I was doing, and not just by cross fading to a music cue but instead by actually having the music cue emerge from the music that was already playing.)

107771559.review:
Rime is like a miniature golf course. Every piece of it has been set up as a challenge for you to overcome. You're not exploring a world, you're going through a sequence of goals; and if you see a bunch of touch obstacles coming up ahead, you know you're going to have to get through it somehow.

In that, Rime isn't exactly my favorite kind of game. I like solving puzzles, sure, but I like the feeling that I happen to be finding a way through a strange land - not that I am finding THE only way through the strange land, the specific path that's been laid out for me. Every ledge in Rime is one you'll have to climb up onto, every item is one you'll have to use somehow, every side path leads either forward or to one of the bonus collectibles you'll find which fill in some of the story. (I'd have preferred this game if I only needed to complete *some* of the goals to proceed, whereas *all* goals completed would unlock an achievement or a bonus item, perhaps.)

And the story's not much to begin with. Kid washes up on an island and immediately starts figuring out how to get past the obstacles that have been set in his way. There's a fox companion, but unlike other games with fox companions (The First Tree, Lost Ember [actually a wolf], Never Alone, Spirit of the North), this one barks like a dog and appears to only have the purpose of showing you which way to go next, as the lavish environments sometimes make that difficult to figure out. Finding the collectibles helps explain what's going on, but I got tired of exploring every nook and cranny, so I was left in the dark. The endgame really brings the story to life and throws in some beautiful music, but I wish that had been part of the game all along.

103919269.review: Fantastic emotional exploration-adventure with a few puzzle elements. Don’t expect too much original gameplay from this, it’s again mostly about the journey. Second chapter needs some thinking to evade a threat, third chapter features some really majestic encounters, the fourth with the sapping black all around (need to see this on an OLED screen) just visually tears you down. But especially in the end chapter this game actually really managed to connect to my feelings and get me emotionally, can’t really explain why, but it truly did. Can’t really criticize much, visuals in their minimalism are superb, music is enchanting, lots to collect and explore. Only two downsides I have to mention. For one, the price tag might be a little steep in my opinion, but the game has been on sale and bundles many times at the usual places like Fanatical & Co, so it’s you’re decision what it’s worth to you. 103300008.review:
This game has a beautiful story full of symbolism, a top-tier soundtrack, and gorgeous visuals. I highly recommend it. 

That said, it does have some performance issues: at max settings, with AA and VSYNC on, I was hitting 30-60 fps on my 1440p 144 Hz monitor with a AMD 5800x + 6800xt build on a fast SSD. I found out that turning AA all the way off, and turning VSYNC off, and just sticking to freesync via AMD software, brought me up to 100-110 fps. 

Btw the game limits you to 60 fps max, but you can get higher fps by following these instructions: 
- Locate Engine.ini under C:\Users\*YourUser*\AppData\Local\SirenGame\Saved\Config\WindowsNoEditor
- Open engine.ini
- add the following 2 lines to the bottom:

[/script/engine.engine]
bSmoothFrameRate=false

-Lastly, right click on engine.ini > properties > check "set as read only"
-Enjoy 60+ fps!

102680083.review: Wow. I just finished this up and in my humble opinion it was a masterpiece of a puzzle game. For a long while I sat on the fence with this game, coming across it in various searches and reading through some of the reviews. It was something I'd wish-listed for several months. Then about a week or so ago I saw a recent review saying it could be argued the game had subtle elements of the game Inside scattered throughout it. This immediately piqued my interest as I personally view Inside as the greatest game ever made. At any rate, I Rime on sale and decided to pick it up. It's just as all the positive reviews have said: excellent puzzles, nothing too incredibly hard, absolutely gorgeous soundtrack, awesome animation and so on. Also thematically brilliant in that it borrows the concept of Elisabeth Kubler Ross's "five stages of grief" to great effect. But the part I perhaps liked the best was the world building throughout and that the developers managed to bring an element of exploration into the game. The world is, at times, very surreal and dark. It's true that there's a bit of an Inside-like vibe, and it also echoes the strangeness of games like "Vane," for instance, although Vane was quite flawed, overall, compared to this. Rime's game mechanics are pretty tight, loading times are good, and the glitches are essentially nonexistent. As I played through this I found myself thinking at various times of so many great games: The Talos Principle, Portal, Inside, Hob, Vane and even Ori in a few spots. I didn't cry at the end but I must confess there was a bit of a lump in my throat. But...when it comes to things like death and the loss of loved ones, we have no choice but to face up to our common fate. Rime handles all of this in a very beautiful, heartfelt and inspiring way. This definitely rates a solid 9 out of 10 in my book. Well done indeed, Tequila Works!!

100969619.review:
A masterpiece that deserved/deserves more polish.

RiME has some performance issues for many. I dunno if it's a bad port (or if it is even a port?) or if it is just a matter of finding what works on your components.. But it can be off putting and make this worthwhile game easy to turn away from far too early on. Most of the suggested fixes in the forums are a matter of switching away from default settings (windowed full to full, triple buffering to double, SSAO to another choice, etc etc). Perhaps they shouldn't have been the default? This game is a visual masterpiece in storytelling but by all means should "just work". Especially on powerful systems. I mean, the frame drops I had at first couldn't even be smoothed with G-Sync on. So it's a crying(pun intended) shame it isn't optimized for a wider breadth of builds. 

Beyond performance there are some gameplay hiccups as well. For a game so wonderfully animated and with a player character full of life(pun not intended); The controls can feel lackluster. Especially jumping. You just don't get a smooth feeling while making your character move. Then like many games before it, the movement on ledges is mind numbing at times. Shimmying along a ledge and leaping to the next is an exercise in patience of trying to figure out which way the game wants you to point your thumbstick versus the camera. Also of note, there is an odd design choice with the ledge stuff where there's a needless requirement to be hanging or standing on particular ledges. Seemingly identical gaps in different parts of the game require you to transition to one or the other before you can jump. And well, jumping and ledge work are the bulk of the platforming. Some more polish for a smoother wield of the controls would've led to me being completely lost in the amazing experience that is RiME. I have no doubt I would've played it through in one sitting if the controls were smoother.

I only point out these complaints for one reason though; To say they're well worth getting over. Figure out how to make the game run smooth enough on your machine. Take a break if you're annoyed by controls. But play RiME. The visual storytelling is spectacular. To think of how I felt exploring in the beginning and discovering this new world to the way I was rocked and along for the ride by the end is wild. I love narrative experiences like this in games. I'd definitely hesitate to say that the story isn't predictable as you go along, but I still felt more than I expected to when I got there. It really is a masterpiece that I'm glad I played. And the game is indeed fun to play most of the time as well. Sure there's jumps and ledges but there is also really decent puzzles and tons of exploring on foot. Plenty of hidden collectibles of various types as well. You can get lost in the experience at times and it is amazing. 

I really enjoyed the storytelling experience that was RiME and the unique world it presented. I highly recommend it. It is worth the effort to hurdle any issues you may run into.

98862040.review:
TLDR, highly recommend this game, make sure to explore as much as you can because it actually pays off in the long run and is relevant to the story!

Now for the longer review:
Overall i want to give this game an 8/10
Visuals/music these 2 i would say carry the game for me solid 10/10
Story, i wont go into detail but it does definitely get a bit confusing as you play, but that did add to the enjoyment of it because i had freedom to make assumptions and guesses as to what was happening, and once i got the answers at the end i was very satisfied!
Puzzle wise its a bit lacking, so  6/10 the puzzles themselves are nice, and the concept is very fun BUT there were almost no moments of excitement when a puzzle would get solved, usually when i got stuck on a puzzle and finally would figure it out i would be annoyed not proud/happy.
Final thought, the thing that i loved a lot about the game, is the small detail of character animation. the fact that depending on where you are walking would change the walk cycle animation of the character was pure genius, down hill, in shallow water, in deeper water, up hill, all had unique animations and it was just a joy to watch! 11/10

98433706.review:
Absolutely stunning art style and presentation. Audio and music are similarly top notch. Will be listening to this OST for years to come and i often just stopped to enjoy the view.

The game itself is a fairly standard platformer/puzzler that wont blow anyone away in terms of mechanics, but the passable gameplay pairs well with its fairly short length and additional mechanics are added often enough to keep boredom at bay. Combined with the previously mentioned top tier sound/visual work make this a memorable and standout experience. Journey is not a masterpiece of gameplay design, but has become a significant influence in the industry through it's presentation and story telling methods. The same can be said here, though to a lesser extent perhaps. 

Performance was rocky. Played at 4K on a 3070 and had many sections exhibiting stuttering. Shame because a game this old with an assumedly light graphics implementation should not stress a modern system this much.  That said, It was so beautiful at 4K i decided to just grin and bear through the stutters, that's how hard this game leans into its presentation and how well it pays off. 

OH, and if you get it, get the soundtrack bundle, a dollar or two is a steal for this OST. 

"If games are art, I want this on my wall."

I just completed the game moments ago, so these are my fresh thoughts. 

This is a very beautiful, thoughtful, meaningful game. It's also extremely derivative of games you know and love. There is nothing special about this game mechanically, and sometimes it's trying too hard to be "cinematic" and it actually negatively impacts the way the game feels to play. That being said, you get the sense that this game is very important to the people who made it, and if you like games like Journey, Shadow of the Colossus, and the Zelda franchise, you will probably find something to enjoy in this game. I give it a strong recommendation, with maybe a caveat that you might want to get it on sale. My initial playthru took less than 4 hours total, and that was with a little optional collectible gathering and a healthy number of fail states. 95386945.review:
I loved this game!!
RiME is set in a beautiful island landscape with crumbling ruins and tall towers and unfolds an emotional and bittersweet tale about a young boy's journey of discovery. The game has limited open world environments to explore by walking, running and using some elements of a 3D platformer. RiME's game play involves moving through different locations, by walking, running and often traversing sheer cliffs or walls using movements reminiscent of early Tomb Raider games such as shimmying, vaulting, pushing blocks and jumping- I usually find these actions frustrating, but they were quite easy to perform and the controls are very forgiving. The puzzles were not overly difficult and the solutions were always logical, making for a nice fluid progression through the story. The story is told through music( a very beautiful soundtrack btw), cut-scenes and drawings that are found as you move through the games locations. I needed a second play-through to get all the achievements as some are a bit obscure and can be missed as there are points of no return in some areas, that said I really did enjoy going back to search for missed items and this was simplified by the option to replay chapters once you have finished the game.

This game is really great. The graphics are perfect to my tastes, it was a whimsical atmosphere, and fantastic music. However, the end of the story, for me, ruined the entire game in an important way, recontextualising the entire game entirely in the span of about 5 minutes. I would recommend playing this game, but on a discount so you are not disappointed by the end. STOP READING NOW IF YOU DO NOT WANT SPOILERS

***SPOILERS***
The end contextualises the whole game as an illusion representing the 5 stages of grief. Not only is the connection extremely vague, but there are a number of whimsical elements - the fox, the man in the red cloak, the lights and fires responding to the voice, the magical robots - and it's not clear what in the world any of it even means given it was all some arbitrary dream about grief. I can see next to zero connection between the majority of the otherwise wonderful, magical parts of the gameworld to the overall theme, and so it really does make them feel meaningless, when they used to be interesting and mysterious. It is also a remarkably shallow meaning to put behind the story, as it is.

92887054.review:
After a terrible storm on sea a boy is washed up on the shore of an idyllic looking island. In the background you can see a ruined tower at a cliff. After climbing up a cliff the boy notices in the far distance another tower. One that is gigantic, intact and having a keyhole like shape on the upper floor. The scenery is gorgeous. Everything looks like it is hand painted. It is a pleasant art style, not trying to be photo realistic but rather to convey being in a very artistic hand painted world. Furthermore there is a day and night cycle which nicely wraps the landscape in different tones, where the night is as atmospheric as the day.
Melodic compositions accompany the boy on his journey through this island and the tower. 

Not a single word is said to convey any goals or the story (besides some shouts of the boy). Therefor one could wonder how the game can tell its story and guide the player throughout the journey. Bits of the story are mostly told by mural paintings, secret keyholes (which show a picture regarding the boys past) and a few cutscenes between the chapters. You are never clueless about what it is you have to do next, even though the game is not stringently holding the players hand. The puzzles are not that challenging but more than often you are surprised by how interesting the mechanics are. In general I would say that the gameplay itself is very chill. The boy has the power to interact with certain objects with is voice. He can reignite torches, break specific vases and activate certain statues, all with a shout of his. Besides chapter 2, which brings an element of danger until right before the end of the chapter, you can almost always take your time exploring (chapter 3 had some areas you could not access after leaving them, so there is that as well). And even the element of danger in chapter 2 is rather there to be kind of a puzzle to be solved.
In some instances exploring was very rewarding, for example when you see a place in a distance not being accessible at first but when you examine the surrounding area you could find a way to get there and eventually find more collectables or achievements. I like that design philosophy.

What I really liked about the end is that the developers made it to tell a story and not have a love, peace and harmony ending (so be warned, if that’s what you always have to want!).
It was very touching and after having unlocked the chapter selection, the meaning of the chapters became more apparent in regards to the actual story. I love it.

For those achievement hunters: There is a chapter select after finishing the game, so there is nothing you can really miss. I was peeking in an achievement guide from time to time after the first chapter to make sure I did not miss anything though. Some achievements are indeed hidden, but if you get them on your own, just by exploring the world, you’ll feel awesome. I’d say play the game mostly without a guide (or like me peeking there from time to time) and enjoy the game. Afterwards you can always replay chapters.

To wrap it all up: 
Rime is not on the lengthy side. It took me around 8 and a half hour, with getting almost all achievements and looking in an achievement guide in between. Even though a bit short, I would definitely say Rime is worth its money delivering a unique adventure with a hand painted look, a great musical score and in general a chill game.

92068295.review:
Rime an adventure puzzle game. It focuses a lot more in art than anything else, so expect simple game mechanics.

Summary:
+ Good Disney like art style.
+ Easy to control.
+ Very calm game. Good to kill time.
- Too slow, should be faster.
- Puzzle are too easy.
- Short game, with big levels, instead of big game with short levels.
- No real replayability. It sums up to getting all items. It's pointless.

You control a kid that looks like a Mexican ancient roman that solves most of his problems with impressive physical ability and by screaming at objects. You can pretty much climb anything, push big stone statues, grab heavy metal spheres and swim for many seconds underwater. Very impressive but he is a kid so he can't jump very high. For some reason screaming at monkey statues, vases, torches, and so on, activates them. Makes no sense, and all that screaming can get annoying, but you just have to do it.

The main selling point is the art style. It's kind of like a classic Disney style and works well, though it could have more shading. There are different themes in each stage, so there is art variety (e.g., water stage, ruins stage). This does make the game a lot more interesting and essential for these kinds of games. The story was designed to fit the art style, meaning the kid is always happy, smiling and tagging along with friends he finds along the way. Kind of nauseating, but as you'll eventually find out, not all is what it seems. The music is nothing to brag about. It's not bad, not good, sometimes annoying and not memorable at all. This is one area the developer could have invested more.

In my opinion there are some obvious issues with the game. It's a very slow game were you spend most of your time running instead of solving puzzles. It's not as bad as it should be because at least you can enjoy the art style, but it could be a faster game. The puzzles are too basic and sometimes it's hard to understand what you're supposed to do. It should be the opposite, easy to understand, but hard to solve. You do have hints if you're lost, in particular a fox helps. By the way, someone should tell the developers that red foxes don't bark like dogs. Either way these two flaws can be off putting to a lot of people. The game does start boring, but gets better over time. It's also a short game, with big levels. Instead it should be a big game with shorter levels. But I guess the main focus was always art.

So it's a slow game with pretty graphics and basic puzzles. It's good to help sleep for sure, not that that's bad. It's a calm game and doesn't really require much skill. It's a good game if you like art and have patience.

89009857.review:
Rime is a console ported 3D puzzle platformer where you control some kid in ancient Greek/Roman type clothes and explore an island with ruins and stuff on it. 

This might work but of course it was developed for consoles, and as we know, consoles make gaming worse for everyone, and Rime is no exception.  The console port is pretty bad here, you can tell the game was designed for console peasant childrens toy gamepads, and KB+M was an afterthought.  For example, "Shift" makes you roll, not run.  Presumably the guys at Tequila Works got their name for a reason, and also, they never saw a PC with a keyboard before.  The sure as hell never played a PC game before, or they wouldn't bind "Shift" to "roll". 

The same console peasant centric design is followed along with completely gamer-hostile camera controls.  The camera is wonky as all hell, and the developers break one of the core rules of game development... [b]NEVER[/b] seize control of the camera from the player.  Except of course, the guys at Tequila Works drunkenly decided players love having the camera yanked off the player.   Well, we don't.  Maybe console peasants like that kind of thing. 

On a technical basis, 4K works, but only in Fullscreen mode.  You can't go that high if you like borderless window, because they either didn't bother testing on PC (a plausible scenario given how bad the controls are), or they just didn't see the sense in making it work properly in 4K because console peasant appliances usually don't go that high.  Also, the graphics are really low poly, again this is because consoles can't render PC tier graphics properly so compromises get made to make the best out of a bad platform.   Told you consoles make gaming worse for everyone.

Anyway, this is basically what might have been an okay game, but it's console ported trash with PC as an afterthought.  Also, it's stupidly overpriced for such a poorly done port.  $40 would get you a game developed for PC, with KB+M working smoothly, proper UHD support, and proper graphics.   This second rate "What's a PeeCee???" console port is not worth a 10th of their greedy asking price.

85358480.review:
Rime is a very stylish exploration game with some puzzles along the way. 

Rime has a cartoon-like art style and I think it looks very nice. The art style gives it a nice relaxing feel, yet the game
can still give off a multitude of feelings and emotions. In my opinion the art style also works because the main character
you play as is a child

Rimes soundtrack is nothing really to speak of. The soundtrack does fit well with the game but it does not stand out on it's own.

Since there is no dialogue the only interesting characters to me were the fox (because the fox was super cute) and the sentinels
because they had a cool design. however the game doesnt dive too far into either.

There are two main gameplay elements; puzzles and platforming. The puzzles aren't to difficult, you might get stuck for a minute
or so but then it's easy to figure out. Thats not a ding against a game unless it tries to be difficult. This game isn't trying to
stump you. I feel like the puzzles here are just to add variety of gameplay and it works fine. Thecontrol for the platofmrer could 
be better, sometimes i feel like I am not jumping where i thought I'd be. Thankfully the game isn't a percision platformer so some loose
controls doesn't harm the gameplay.

I liked the overall feels of the game and I really enjoyed the ending scene. 

I didn't like that the game doesn't change over the 10ish hours it took me to beat. The puzzles don't get harder nor does the platforming become harder or different.
As a result the gameplay can get boring as you get closer to the end of the game. 

Overall the game is a fine game. It doesn't push the envelope or attempt to do something new. It does what it tries to do and I can't blame it for that.

85233231.review:
Such powerful interactive storytelling. Reminiscent of Ico, Journey and Spirited Away amongst others, RiME's puzzles take second place to the story embedded into the gameplay and little details placed here and there for the player to get invested in. 

It invites you to take a moment and ask yourself: What am I doing right now? Why am I doing it? What does it mean? And these simple questions make you draw a picture that little by little one unveils with a twist (for some) at the very end. If you have been paying attention, you will feel the warm feeling of melancholic resolution. If you have just been focusing on the puzzles and a bit of foreshadowing here and there, you will be flooded with emotions as a wave of cold salty water runs down your spine. Regardless of the way you play it, the ending does not disappoint. What's more, I believe it may make you want to go through it all one more time.

If you can, avoid all spoilers and just buy the game. Enjoy.

85083301.review:
"I need a bigger key..." - the boy, probably.

Rime is an action puzzle game without the action element.
So just a puzzle game?
No, I know what i said, your character moves as if part of an action game but has to solve puzzles in order to process.
A great cell shaded look and good shot-composition foward the story of this boy that stranded on this strange and whimsical island must uncover what happend to him in a narrative that comunicates theese feelings to you without using a single word.

Una obra de arte repleta de sensaciones, todo está cuidado al mínimo detalle... todo encaja a la perfección... Si, es un juego de exploración y puzzles, pero es mucho más que eso! es una historia que te tocará el alma!

Empezamos en una playa, donde parece ser que hemos naufragado y nos tocará explorar y ver qué ha pasado. Al poco tiempo encontraremos un pequeño y precioso zorro que nos guiará toda la partida y lo dicho, a explorar y resolver puzzles.

El juego es precioso, toda la partida he estado parando a contemplar los paisajes, el cielo, las puestas de sol, la noche estrellada... es una preciosidad. La música a su vez acompaña de manera magistral y te llena de emociones, que al final es de lo que va este juego, te hará sentir desde el principio en un cúmulo de sensaciones que será como un torbellino que removerá todo tu ser por dentro.

Como punto negativo, el control es un poco tosco con los cambios de cámara que se marca pero nada que empañe el resultado final.

En resumen, un juego que te va a llegar al corazón.

84272258.review:
6.5/10

RiMe is a par game that makes a lot more sense after you reach the ending. If you haven't already played Ico, Journey, or The Last Guardian, prioritize those over this one.

This game feels very much like a mash up of Fumito Ueda playstation games (mostly Ico 2001), and Journey 2012. It has the speechless protagonist of Ico, the green glowing objects of The Last Guardian, and a musical score reminiscent of Journey.

Unfortunately the only new ground RiMe strikes is at the very end in how it explains (loosely) the world of the game. It feels very much like a fan made Ico, and while that is not a problem if it had been of equal quality, it largely felt derivative and less polished mechanically. The soundtrack for RiMe is incessantly performing the background in a way that felt like the game feared allowing the player to soak in the atmosphere without constant musical mood setting. Introspection is firmly replaced by an unrelenting (albeit nice) string orchestra. The sound that defines Fumito Ueda games is silence, and this game has none of that to offer.

This is not a bad game, but unfortunately it falls just below interesting for me.

79726345.review:
Description: RiME is an exploration puzzle game developed by Tequilla Works and published by Grey Box Six Foot in 2017. Play as a young boy who finds himself washed up on shore of a mysterious island. With the help of a mysterious fox he must explore the island and learn the mysteries of where he is and why he is there.

Graphics/Art Style: I really like the art style in RiME. It really holds up well considering the game is over 3 years old. Characters have a somewhat unique look to them, and the environment is absolutely gorgeous. From the starting beach all the way to the end of the game, every environment you encounter is breathtakingly beautiful. Detailed landscapes inspire a sense of wonder and awe, dark ominous areas instill a sense of dread, and ancient abandoned buildings make you wonder where you are and what happened in the ancient civilization that existed long ago.

Audio/Music: The music in RiME is exceptional. It is a great mix of insightful, somber and tranquil. I added the soundtrack it to my spotify playlist immediately after finishing the game.

Controls: RiME controls fairly well. My only complaint is that the character seems to lock on to some ledges very strongly, which can lead to you falling to your death when trying to jump somewhere else. I only had one or two deaths that I attributed to the controls, which is acceptable.

Gameplay/Difficulty: The puzzles of RiME are fairly simplistic. I like this, as overly complex puzzles could easily detract from the story, which is the main highlight of this game. Although they are simplistic, there is a lot of variety, and none of the various mechanics are overused at any point of the game.

Replayability: Sadly there is little replayability in RiME. Unless you missed some collectables and want to go back and find them later, once you beat the game you will be more or less done.

Writing/Story: The story of RiME is where this game truly shines. Unfortunately, due to spoilers I can’t say much about it, but what I will say is that I haven’t been this emotionally invested in a puzzle game for a long time.

Length/Price/Value: I was able to beat RiME in 5.3 hours, and I collected roughly half of the collectable items in the game. Purchased for $10.59, totaling roughly $2 an hour. While this a little spendy, I still enjoyed the game quite a bit.

Recommendation: RiME is a great game for those who like a good story quality mixed into their puzzle game. I enjoyed it a lot, although some may want to wait for it to go on sale before buying.

79534885.review:
Rime is one of those beautiful games that you don't understand anything at the beginning, and learn everything on the fly.  Similar to INSIDE in that regard, but that's where the similarities end.

You play (mostly) as a young "boy" (in quotes because i found it ambiguous) and get to follow a fox around that shows you where you need to go for most of the game.  Simple concept, and its shown in beautiful cell shaded style.

But it gets much deeper than that.  Who is this mysterious cloaked individual?  What are these creatures?  What is this world?  Many questions will arise in the course of playing the game, and most will be answered, but, like all good games,. some is left to interpretation.

Much like To The Moon, If I explained what makes this game so good and wonderful to play, I would have to give away what makes it so good in the first place.  Go in blind, and understand that things are not always as they seem.

Pros:
-Absolutely amazing and brilliantly crafted visuals from start to finish
-Great soundtrack, definitely worth a listen to
-a good story with a twist, open to interpretation
-You can play with the fox!
-You can light things with your voice!
-Experimentation is encouraged, as you can't truly "die"
-Exploration is heavily encouraged, especially if you want to find and collect everything
-its very hard to get truly lost, as every time you do or can, the fox comes along to save the day and show you where to go to proceed

Cons:
-Ultra settings will require something akin to a gamer PC or laptop
-Controls can be a bit finniky at times, sometimes they can mess up and require a restart of the game to fix
-Forced camera parts while you're running on thin pathways can be very annoying

I highly recommend this game if you want a fun little adventure with as touching story and absolutely amazing visuals.  I cannot stress that enough, this game is gorgeous from start to finish, and only gets better.

If you're looking for a mindless game where all you do is kill people and get points for it, this isn't for you.

This is a prime example of a game being art with a deeper message that can and does take everything you know and shine a new perspective on it.  Much like Superliminal does.

If the trailer interests you, i guarantee you will enjoy thew game.  it deserves to be played.

79396877.review:
This game is a masterpiece. It is beautiful. It is an incredible story of innocence and loss told without a single word.

I cannot recommend enough that you play it.

79394795.review:
Achievements: Not unreasonable to 100%.  Most achievements are easily missed, but a chapter select option is unlocked after beating the game.  

RiME is a gorgeous game with compelling music and visuals.  Each environment, each creature, each towering structure is so beautifully crafted.  The areas feel unique, the scenery is stunning.  Unfortunately, this is all that RiME really brings to the table.  Personally, I could not find the fun in this game.  The puzzles were dull (but pretty!), the platforming was stiff, the walk speed was much too slow, and the story felt disappointingly ordinary.  

Looking at the screenshots on the store page gives the feeling of such grand, expansive environments.  "Adventure" and "Exploration" are two of the top tags describing RiME.  One could certainly be led to believe this game is full of sprawling stories, diverse places, and lots of content.  This is not the case.  RiME is a linear game.  The environments are giant, but they're also empty.  The only thing earned by exploring them is the occasional collectible.  Some of the areas are designed in ways that are confusing, forcing the player to backtrack large distances or redo long climbs.  I feel there was more of a focus on aesthetics than good level design.  This, plus the lack of any maps, means there's a huge potential to get lost while looking for the one place the game wants you to go.  

Navigating the vastness of RiME is not fun.  The run speed is slow while the climbing is clunky and stiff.  I don't feel compelled to search the lands for secrets when it takes so long to get around.  There's no sprint button.  There's a roll, but it's slow and seems useless.  Jumping while running removes your momentum.  For me, a game with long walks needs something to keep my attention along the way-- whether that's combat or environmental hazards or just a button I can press to make me feel like I'm going faster.  

RiME could be called relaxing, but it could just as easily be called boring.  The puzzles are bland.  Don't get me wrong, they feature very strong and creative imagery that feels satisfying to watch unfold.  They are still very bland, though.  The solutions are simple, the same mechanics are repeated throughout the game with little variation or complications.  There's no challenge to them whatsoever.  

In terms of value, I think RiME is overpriced.  One playthrough-- wherein which I got lost several times-- took only 5 hours.  The rest of my playtime was spent getting the achievements I had missed.  Five hours of content-- regardless of how scenic it was-- should be cheaper than $30.  

Overall, I am disappointed by RiME.  I enjoyed the visuals, the symbolism, the breathtaking music, but I did not enjoy the game.  For me, it just wasn't very fun.  If there was more to the puzzles, more to the lore, more fluidity towards the platforming elements, then I would be more inclined to recommend it.  Otherwise, if you're still interested, I'd recommend you only consider buying it on sale.

79344226.review:
RIME is an adventure puzzle game about a boy moving about an island yelling at flames, statues, and pots and finding keys in the process.  Beat it in 6.5ish hours taking my time, using a game controller.  Difficulty is easy to moderate.

- This is one of those wordless 'surreal story' art games.  That said the story is... There?  It's there.  Expect to have your heart stabbed if you're the sensitive type.  If you're not the sensitive type...  Um...  Yeah, surreal story art game right here!  Enjoy the lush game play experience!!

- Speaking of, the game play involves jumping from ledge to ledge and climbing stuff or grabbing items in order to open doors to get to the next area.  It's pretty loose in terms of direction and you can tell your helper to sod off and explore all you want per area, jumping recklessly into pits or throwing yourself at rocks to find hidden paths.

- Each chapter is unique and provides different challenges and enemies, however most of the puzzles revolve around the 'push box, get key for door, jump and cling to ledges' formula.  Once you beat the game, you can access each chapter individually.

- The graphics are pretty and the camera is very well balanced.  I normally die of motion sickness in games, and fully expected to here, but the worst I had it was in the underwater levels, and it wasn't that bad at all.  Took a ginger pill and I was fine for hours.  Turn up brightness for the darker levels if needed.

- Music?  Music's pretty and atmospheric.  

- There's a fox!  Fraka-kaka-kaka-kaka-kow!

- You pet the fox!  AND hug it!  (Once, anyway)

- There are many inventive achievements to get and trinkets to collect that unlock all sorts of fun stuff like outfits.

- On the very last scene the camera was a bit laggy, like my processor could barely withstand the experience.  And this is a beefy comp.  If you experience this issue, try turning VSync off.  I also fabulously went out of my way to glitch the fox so he's invisible for cut scenes and the pigs so they were stuck in walls.  Tried really hard to get the boy stuck on multiple occasions, almost succeeded once, but he's good at getting free (better than his animal friends).  So the game isn't glitch proof.  Not that any of those glitched killed the adventure for me.



If you're into games like the ICO trilogy or Uncharted series, Rime is a very nice, entertaining adventure puzzle game with very loose story elements, an atmospheric soundtrack, and replayability.   I beat it, the ending didn't do much for me, but I'll play it again and very likely 100% the lot for fun.

79225124.review:
Aesthetically, I adored this game. The cute, colourful and bright art style is right up my alley. It's so pleasant to look at, I sometimes stood on a cliff just to see how the landscape changed as the day became night.

I didn't like the music, as I found it too same-y, but I didn't hate it either.

The gameplay is decent enough. The puzzles are very easy, but that's okay because the game is pretty clearly meant to be relaxing and sentimental. Wish the kid were a little faster, but again, adequate.

Now. The story.

I'm sorry to say the story is where it lost me.

First of all, we don't spend enough time with the characters to develop a strong emotional attachment to them. Like, at some point a "character" we have sort of been solving puzzles with for less than a hour disappears, and the kid throws himself to the ground wailing in despair. And I'm kinda feeling, well, that was unfortunate, but I'm not exactly feeling like crying here. Sir, I hardly know you.

The goals are also too vague and unclear. You move forward because it's a game and you are supposed to move forward, but there is no real sense of *why*. It's a desert island, it's not like you are going to get back to civilization by diving into underground caves. In fact, given that the first stages are like a beautiful paradise with plenty of food and the chance to be spotted by passing ships, while the later stages are creepy and dangerous and hidden away, story-wise it would make more sense for the kid to remain where he is and build a shelter.

Of course, in the end this logic is meaningless, because...

[SPOILERS]

...the story turns out to be a metaphor/dream.

Unfortunately, that still fails to move me. Partly because by the time of the Reveal I've already been moving forward for no given reason for 4 stages, so it feels a little too late. Partly because, well...

I didn't know why so many indie developers are obsessed with loss. If you are playing an artistic indie game, it's a pretty safe bet that the story is about death, either your own or a loved one's. It's so widespread that it turned what is supposed to be an emotional journey into *routine*. I'm sorry, but at this point I consider it an unexpected plot-twist if they don't die/aren't Dead all Along.

Given how predictable that theme is, a game that follows it has to do something really special to shine. For example, LIMBO has very creative puzzles and a 100% unique presentation.

Nothing RiME does feels special enough. It's an above average game, but not a great one, so it can't overcome the burden of "I've already seen this trope many, many times".

78153426.review:
RiME speaks a language that's familiar to gamers; there's a castaway boy on an island with magical ancient ruins. The graphics, and the non-verbal protagonist, bear a strong similarity to [i]Wind Waker[/i].  Here, there's a simple puzzle that teaches you the concept needed to solve a harder problem.  Over there, a secret area and a collectable. Further on, some portentous hieroglyphs and a forced-perspective puzzle. Elsewhere, climbing segments and sliding blocks.  A mysterious watcher and an enigmatic animal guide fill out the familiar, comfortable tropes.

And yet...

Even early on, RiME begins hinting to the experienced gamer that not everything here is the well-trod ground it appears to be.  Something deeper and more consequential is being built up. RiME is good at keeping its cards close to its chest, however.   Recognition that there is some kind of metaphor in play comes early, but full realisation is held off at length.  The result is a powerful and compelling tale, told in the language of games, that should not be spoiled.  Avoid spoilers for this one.

To me, this was a beautiful, perfect gaming experience.

I went into this expecting a two hours beautiful game, I did get the beautiful part but for even longer! 

Positives: 
+ Deep story that connects together at the end 
+ Beautiful world (that got me excited to take screenshots)

+ You get connected to the characters, and the emotions behind the story really gets to you. From the beautiful and light to the dark and depressing. 
+ a fox that barks 
+ It stays with you once you finished it. 

(possible) Negatives: 
+ The performance! It was a nightmare. I have a good PC that runs every game that came out this far but it's just horrible with this game. It keeps dropping frames, sometimes between 5-12! 
+ The puzzles. Although they're often fun, they can also get boring. It really depends if you're the type to enjoy repetitive tasks or not. 
+ You can feel at loss at first without knowing what to do. But once you get the pattern it gets easy. 

The story is bittersweet about love, loss and learning to live with the present. It's truly beautiful, and I definitely recommend it.

A gorgeous game all around - gorgeous visuals, gorgeous music, gorgeous story. I really enjoyed playing this! I thought the story was great. I'm always impressed when a game can be moving and evoke emotions without any dialogue. I found the gameplay enjoyable as well.

That being said, I can see how this game isn't for everyone. It's not fast-paced, and there's no combat or anything like that - you're just exploring the world while trying to solve puzzles (a big plus for me, but could be a minus for others). Playing this game was a serene experience for me, and I would often find myself taking moments to stop and soak in the environment around me. So if you're not into playing a game that has a more relaxed pace/feel, you might not enjoy this as much as others. It's also on the shorter side (I beat it in about 8 1/2 hours, and I played it at a relaxed pace), so you might wanna wait for a sale.

Otherwise, I would absolutely recommend that you play RiME. It's beautiful all around. It's been a loooong time since a game has affected me like this one. I adore RiME, and it's one of my favorite experiences that I've had with a game in the past few years.

RiME is an incredibly beautiful and heartfelt Adventure, Puzzle game. All right the story.

A young boy wakes up on a Mysterious Island, how did he get on the island, who built all these structures and more importantly where are the people? That is what he wants to know as he explores the land and tries to discover the truth.

So the likes, Well to start the game is incredibly beautiful starting with the levels from the warm grassy Hills and ocean to the ruins and desert valley to the rain-soaked land of chapter 4, there is just so much to see and explore. 

The game's atmosphere was very good and can be it can be beautiful or haunting or depressing and sometimes all at once.

The story is really, really good with all its themes and playing it a second time makes the story even better. Plus it's one of those games where there's no dialogue, it tells its story through actions and cutscenes which this game pulled off very well and this game is one of the few games to make me tear up.

The music in the game was incredibly beautiful to listen to especially the ending theme. The puzzles in the game were good and fairly difficult but not impossible to figure out. All those Collectibles you can get throughout the game was very cool like the keyhole collectibles.

Now the dislikes, the game is a bit short you can beat it in four hours, it only gets longer if you're going after the achievements. The price for the game is seriously too high for such a short game, I mean I could understand if the game was like 10 or $15 at most but 29,99 that is way too high. 

And lastly would I liked away to skip cutscenes I mean when I was going after the achievements I wish there was an option where I could just again skip the cutscenes.

Now with that said RiME is an incredibly beautiful and heartfelt Adventure, Puzzle game. With so much to love from the really, really good story, to the incredibly beautiful levels and the incredibly beautiful music.

Now if you’re looking for a Adventure, Puzzle game this is so for you, I highly recommended it but I say wait till it's on sale before you get it.

Absolutely beautiful from start to finish. Feels like a gentle version of Shadows of the Colossus, though without any Colossi. Make of that what you will.  It's the setting, the atmosphere, and the feeling that you're playing with ancient machinations you maybe shouldn't be.

This is one of those rare adventures that just is. You're told nothing, you just dive into the world you find yourself in and learn as you go, the scenery is gorgeous, vast and actively fascinating.  The story is silent, not a coherent word is ever said or written, and yet it really knows how to tug on a few chords in your heart before you know it.

There are some stunning set pieces and some superb animations that really carry a message stronger than words could.

There're no punishing elements to this game, any deaths I experienced (and a single glitch that stuck me in a wall and I had to restart), put me right back where I left off. There can feel like pressure and weight to your actions but failure is gently corrected.

73580192.review:
Visuals - For the most part, this game does a great job of setting these grand backdrops without melting your GPU. I feel like the developer hit the perfect balance of keeping things visually appealing without compromising on performance. You're not going to be wowed by super complex textures or water physics, but game stays beautiful from beginning to end and runs great. What really stood out was how the gameplay elements (climable ledges, interactive objects, etc) fit in seamlessly with the surrounds; enough to make it seem like everything was supposed to be there but not so much that you weren't sitting around scratching your head wondering what to do or where to go

Story (NO SPOILERS) - I've seen a lot of developers try and capture the emotional tones of games like Journey and Abzu and completely wiff. Thankfully, TW knocked this one out of the park. Telling a story without dialogue or written words isn't new, but it's tricky. The overall theme only becomes apparent to the AFTER you beat the game but what blew me away was how well each section of the game complemented each other. There's optional collectibles that flesh out the narrative a bit as well. I missed most of them on my first playthrough but the game's length (~7 hours) and post-completion chapter select mean I'll probably try once or twice to find more.

Gameplay - The puzzles in RiME aren't difficult, but I don't think they're meant to be. The puzzles are there to give context to the narrative, and while they're not challenging they are pretty clever and satisfying to solve. There's some mild platforming in the form of some Nathan Drake esque ledge climbing but again, it's there to enhance the feeling of exploration. Overall movement and climbing was satisfying and it reminded me somewhat of a more responsive version of a Team Ico game (Shadow of the Colossus). I did appreciate how nice the camera movement felt. I can't count how many times I've played a game that tried to be "cinematic" and just resulted in me wrestling for control of the camera 90% of the time.

Overall 8.5/10 would recommend

73488558.review:
I really enjoyed this game! I see some reviews online where people are judging the game against what they want it to be and it leaves them disappointed. The real question is, what is RiME TRYING to be, and does it accomplish what it sets out to do? To me, the answer is a resounding "yes" to that final question.

Graphically it is gorgeous. I have a mid-range PC and it ran silky smooth on high settings. I believe the performance issues they were having earlier on have been ironed out. I really love the art style in this game. The music/score is also top notch... really beautiful stuff that fits the game nicely. I also really liked the story. I've seen some complaints about the story not being explained or complex... but that's the point. The game is a journey of discovery where you have to piece it together. And when you finally do figure out what is going on, yes, it is a "simple" story, but it is powerful. A game doesn't need a dozen characters or voice acting to tell an effective story.

As for the puzzles, yes, they are not especially challenging, but they aren't trying to be. I enjoyed working my way through them and exploring the beautiful environments. I recently finished The Witness and it was one of my favorites, so I am not opposed to some good puzzling, but RiME is not trying to be a hard puzzle game. I did find some of the platforming a bit repetitive and the controls were not perfect, but they were more than sufficient.

So take RiME for what it is, a beautiful journey of discovery with some fun but not overly difficult challenges along the way. For an indy game, I think it is a triumph.

This game is a gem.  It's perfect for both experienced and novice gamers alike.  For the experienced, it is a beautiful and relatively stress free action-platformer with plenty of environmental puzzles in the vein of Zelda and Assassin's Creed.  For the novices, it is a great way to understand modern game mechanics in an environment that doesn't punish failure.  

I played this game with my fiancee who up until a year ago had never really played a video game.  With a bit of ongoing assistance she was able to truly begin to feel comfortable with a controller in her hand.  The ability to manipulate a character and camera in 3D space with an unfamiliar control scheme is a lot for newbies.  This game does an excellent job of holding their hand, while also still making the gamer feel smart.

I fully recommend this game for couples looking for a game they can play together.  I also recommend it to anybody that wants to enjoy a laid back 8 hour experience that will leave them feeling positive.

The best part about RiME is about how you put together a story easily if you can perceive what's happening to the character and the world that you traverse. 

I think that the fun at least for me was trying to understand the big picture and if you are not in it for that it might leave you disappointed. The quality of the game is overall good I didn't get stuck and finding out where to go next was easy. It's not a game that is so abstract that it basically feels like there isn't a story but more about giving you signs and leaving the interpretation up to you. Rime is a great adventure game with platforming and puzzles.  You're  a boy who finds himself washed up on the shore of a beach. You make your way inland and find a fox along the way. The fox guides you where to go as you work your way throughout the game. The game is around six hours long if you don't search every nook and cranny for collectibles. The platforming and puzzles are pretty easy so just about anybody can complete the game, but they're still challenging enough to keep you engaged throughout the game. 

The art, the music, and atmosphere that they create goes perfectly with the story the developers are trying to tell. The way this game is presented made it easy to be immersed in it. Some people may not be impressed with the art style of this game but I think it will age well as time goes on. The game is quite cinematic and every scene is directed well.Rime is about dealing with loss in life and the music is used to highlight that. 

I would recommend this game to anybody looking for a game that doesn't require a lot of time or effort to get through. Gameplay is simple enough to keep you from getting stuck and engaging enough to keep you interested.  I found it a bit relaxing and a very enjoyable experience. 

Overall:9/10

Visuals: 8/10
Music: 10/10
Gameplay:8/10

72846156.review:
I have mixed feelings about this game.

The first two of four (the fifth level is a glorified cutscene) levels are amazing.  Beautiful, platforming, puzzles, lots of secrecy and mystery through exploration.  The third level is the "Water Temple" x 3.  It's confusing, and it doesn't know what it wants to be throughout the entire level.  Is it a maze?  Oh, the maze part is done.  Is it an avoid the evil creatures?  Oh, the evil creatures part is done.  Is it lead the drone through the ancient puzzle areas?  Yes.

The final level lacks any of the beauty of the other levels.  it rains the entire time and the level is all stone black.

The game also has a story.  It's not necessary at all, and for me it's what makes the game mixed for me.  If they threw the story out the window and gave me the same first two levels but five different times, then the story just wouldn't matter.  But they have a story and thus fit mechanics into said story:

[spoiler] You play a son who died during a storm at sea who is searching for his father.  Each of the five levels emulate the five stages of grief.  So while the first two levels emulate denial and aggression, which fit really well into the game, the third and fourth levels emulate bargaining and depression.  I guess I felt those during the levels?  But it was so poorly done at the third and fourth levels that the end did not pay off.  The fifth level is "Acceptance", which means you simply press W a few times to walk through a hall and let a scarf go.[/spoiler]

Overall, I spent about 5 hours in the first two levels, having fun.  The third level I spent 3 hours in, confused out of my damn mind, and the fourth and fifth level speeding through clocking a whole 1 hour about.

No payoff and I steel fill a bit empty.

Still, I'd recommend buying it.  It was fun while it lasted and makes me long for games like the Legend of Zelda and such.
