72444812.review:
RiME es una obra bellísima, muy bien orquestada y original, a pesar de que hay otros juegos en los que se inspira. El punto fuerte de RiME es su sentimentalismo (envuelto en el misterio de su historia), sin olvidar sus gráficos preciosistas y su tremenda banda sonora.

Los puzles no son complicados, pues el juego no pretende ser un gran desafío ni atascar a los jugadores demasiado tiempo, sino que está pensado para que el que lo juegue vaya disfrutando sin frustraciones, con un ritmo dinámico y enlazando poco a poco pedacitos de la historia en los elementos que va encontrando en el mapa o las secuencias de vídeo (los extras no son imprescindibles para pasar el juego, sin embargo aportan información importante para entender la historia). En resumen se trata de un juego corto (unas 10 horas si no nos detenemos mucho a explorar todo o hasta 30 o mas si queremos completar todo). La Historia es el gran misterio que hay que desvelar. El único "pero" es el de sus problemas de rendimiento (FPS o caída de frames/cuadros), solucionado ya casi por completo con parches. Sin embargo, si has jugado juegos antiguos con muchos elementos en pantalla, las ralentizaciones entonces (Nes 8 bits, etc) eran mucho peores y no nos privaban de jugar magníficos juegos. En mi experiencia personal no me afectaba ya que ocurría de vez en cuando, y con menos frecuencia a partir del segundo capitulo (lo he jugado completo en Nintendo Switch antes del parche que lo mejora muchísimo). Es un diminuto gran juego, que pasará a ser una obra maestra con el paso del tiempo, aunque para mí ya lo es. INOLVIDABLE. Lo estoy jugando de nuevo en PC ahora que lo acabo de comprar en edición física (DvD). Editado: "Hace bien poco que lo volvi a terminar en su version de Xbox One, la mejor de todas, graficos al maximo y suavidad en fps, inolvidable, jugado en una Series S".

71784038.review:
It pains me to give this game a negative review.  It is, after all, a gorgeous game, and I must admit, I was captivated by it almost the entire way through.  But there are two things I really didn't like about this game.

The first was that most of the puzzles weren't interesting, once you are introduced to their mechanics.  Basically, the game will introduce a puzzle mechanic, and the first puzzle might be somewhat confusing, but after that, almost all puzzles are straightforward variations of it.  Some aren't even puzzles so much as busy work, especially climbing sequences.

I could excuse this defect because the game has really gorgeous aesthetics to it, and the protagonists, despite the lack of words, have endearing qualities to them.

The thing that really annoyed me about this game is the following.  About 3/4ths of the way through the game, I mentioned to my wife, "I really hope that [hackneyed plot twist] isn't true."

And waddya know?  It turned out to be true!

And that was so disappointing, not just because it has been done to death, but because it does not serve to tie any of the other game's elements together.  Frankly, the game would have done better to leave you in the dark to form your own hypotheses.  Instead, it clumsily attempts to hit you over the head with its "big reveal," but misses by a mile.

What follows is my opinion, which slightly gives this away, and so I will shroud most of it in a spoiler:

I think this game suffers from what a lot of media suffers from these days: the need to be deep by over-explaining things.  Professor X can't just have gone bald, because Male-Pattern Baldness is a thing.  He has to have lost his boyish mop of hair after being strapped into a machine of death.  Han Solo can't just be named Han Solo, because it's just a name.  No, he has to acquire it, because he "goes it, alone." (and, for some reason, people in a galaxy far, far, away are aware of Spanish).  In this case, [spoiler]you can't just have a child truly journey through a mysterious island with ancient technology, and unconventional topology.  No, it has to turn out to be "like a deep metaphor for loss, and grief, man."  Give me a break.  If you're going to do that, at least do it well.  Have the Fox, the scary bird thing, and the ancient walking robots be symbolic of this.[/spoiler]  Instead, we get what amounts to a hairy dog story in video game form, and that really does the rest of the  game a disservice.

71693887.review:
Okay... let's go easy now. "Rime" is not the game you may think it is at first. If you're expecting a casual, relaxing walking simulator, "Rime" is not quite that. Because in order for a game to be that, it wouldn't ask so much from its players as "Rime" does. Most of its puzzles are fair enough, but some others can be really brain-wrecking and time consuming. So this is the first thing to learn about this game: it's not so casual as it looks. It will take you some time; my first run in it took me close to six hours.

The game is very much a semi-open world, with these large areas. There's very little to indicate you where to go, since the game goes for minimalism, but it surely could use a way to at least point players where to go next, like in "BioShock: Infinite", "Alien: Isolation" and even "Mirror's Edge". For "Rime", there's this fox that barks at you, pointing you where to go in bigger areas. And sometimes, there'll be lights coming from the ground into the sky like beacons. Those are helpful, but a bit cumbersome; a mini-map could have aided much.

As a puzzle game, it has its fair share of classic key fetching, and sometimes you'll need to carry small objects to complete your goals. You'll also be dragging larger blocks around like in a "Tomb Raider" game. One little problem with the game is that it can have some annoying backtracking, as once you activate something, you're required to walk your way back into where you've been before. It's not something that happens often, but it's a noticeable issue nonetheless.

The game is heavy on puzzles, but one big thing about "Rime" is the platforming. There's a lot of jumping and climbing to do in this game, and controls are fluid and reliable - except however when you need to drop down from some higher ground, as landing from certain altitudes will stun your character for a bit. There's also a lot of swimming in this game, but underwater environments can get very big and very disorienting, while you can only hold your breath for so long.

This brings me to something important: you can actually die in this game. Falling from large heights and drowning are the ways the environment can kill you. As for enemies, you'll come across the "shades": sinister creatures in dark hoods who are harmless at first, but become dangerous later on. In a level, you'll also see this giant bird that can poach you if you stay in the open for too long. The good news however is that once you die, you immediately pick up from close nearby, meaning that you don't lose anything at all. The deaths in this game will be more of a nuisance than a heavy frustration.

The visuals are splendid, and many compared them to "Breath of the Wild": it doesn't go for ultra-realism, but instead for painting-like graphics that are exuberant and evocative. It even feels like those short animated films you see in YouTube. The thing however - and I don't think this is something all players experienced or will experience - is that my PC would get really hot while playing this game, to the point I could personally feel it. And this scared the hell out of me, more than any of the enemies or visuals in this game. I toned the graphics down, but even then my PC would still heat up like a fireplace. It's weird that happens for a game in which the visuals don't even look that demanding.

There are plenty of collectables in this game - so much in fact that to call this game a collectaton wouldn't be so far off. Some of these collectables are easy to find, but others are very well hidden, representing massive detours from the main path. After you beat the game, you can access the levels individually at the main menu to pick up what you missed. There's also a lot of achievements, so this game will keep completionists busy for a time. You can even unlock new clothes for your character, but they're just cosmetic; it would have been nice if different clothes would bring certain benefits.

Speaking of your character, this is when I address the story, and I left it for last for a reason. I won't spoil anything, but I'll just say that the main idea of this game was treated clumsily. It tries to tell a story in a symbolic fashion, but at some flashbacks, the game kind of lies to us in order not to reveal itself so soon. And the game is so minimalist with its storytelling (not a word is uttered throughout the whole game) that some players might not even get it after concluding it. The story itself is quite noble and surprisingly profound, but I wish its themes were treated better.

"Rime" is a flawed gem of a game. It is much more than its visuals alone, and you should definitely buy it if you're a fan of puzzles, platformers and collectatons. It assimilates all that is familiar to us in its own unique way.

71192508.review:
[h1]So only after upgrading from my previous RX 580 (8GB) GPU to my current RTX 3060 (12GB) GPU was I able to play this game...[/h1]

And as interesting as the game was, needing a "battlestation" to run it is [b]COMPLETELY[/b] unacceptable.

[b]7/10[/b] - A rather compelling take centered on the five stages of grief. But again, the requirements/optimization are unsatisfactory to say the least.



[h1]ORIGINAL 2020 REVIEW:[/h1]

[b]The "System Requirements" section is a joke, as is the optimization...[/b]

I own a machine consisting of a Ryzen 5 3600X processor paired with an RX 580 (8GB) GPU, 16GB of DDR4-3000 RAM and an SSD on which I installed it [i](tried it on an HDD as well)[/i], so not only does my rig meet the "Recommended Requirements", but it has also surpassed them, only to get 50 choppy frames in 1080p with every graphical setting turned off.

Now the game itself looks really fun, nice, relaxing and whatnot, but I cannot recommend it because 3 years later, my experience with it [i](before I finally gave up and uninstalled it)[/i] consisted of benchmarking, mixing settings, switching screen mode and VSync, googling the issue and trying other potential fixes, to no positive end result though...

"Resolution Scale" is the only setting that gave me [i](along with everything else turned off and set to "Low")[/i] 60 frames without the game being choppy and stuttering constantly, but I was not about to play it downscaled from a simple 1080p resolution considering the machine I own...

So yeah...since I could not enjoy it until the end [i]([b]or at all for that matter.[/b]..spending almost 4 out of 5 hours benchmarking, mixing settings, googling fixes and whatnot)[/i], this is my verdict:

[h1]While it looks like an at least [b]7/10[/b] game, it plays and is optimized for a [b]3/10[/b] score at best...

You have been warned.[/h1]

71017190.review:
A charming platformer game with treasures to collect, story to experience and beautiful environments to explore. If that sounds like your cup of tea, give this game a try.
Personal experience:
I think the idea for the game’s twist was born before a single asset was made. The game knows it is telling a dramatic story, but for new players it comes off as just weird or pretentious. In the first hour when the music swells with emotion, I have no idea why. It’s pretty, sure. But so what? Why should I care? This is what has been going through my mind as I played the game.
It borrows heavily from Journey, Ico, Shadow of the Colossus, Tomb Raider. It desperately wants to be just as deep, but comes off as juvenile. I don’t regret playing this game. It’s beautiful, it’s well done. I wish it was just a bit more well executed as a whole.

70846097.review:
Wasn't sure about this game at first. But it was enjoyable. Games I've previously played that were said to be similar are Abzu and The Witness. For the most part, the game is really enjoyable, even relaxing at times, to play through. Would recommend.

Except the first level - I hated the first level. It's long, it's tedious, it has the hardest puzzles (in my opinion), and it that point in the game you really have no reason to care about anything going on. Exploration felt limited (e.g. you can only climb up the rocks in a very specific way, when it feels as though none of them should be off limits), yet at the same time I was often confused where I had to go next. It honestly left me not feeling like I wanted to play anymore after the first chapter. Only reason I did was to get this game out of my backlog completely.

I'm glad I kept playing. The remaining levels were *significantly* more interesting and there was a much better sense of progression within them. The story actually (sorta) amounted to something, and I found the remaining levels more visually pleasing too. Besides the first level, I really enjoyed this game.

70015305.review:
The art direction is stunning.
As is the music.
And even the very last scene suddenly touched me pretty profoundly.

Yet the game as a whole is lacking in two very important aspects:

The story is - besides the aforementioned last scene - non-existent.
I didn't know anything about the character, the world or the motivations - anything at all.
That's why, throughout the whole experience, I couldn't get myself to CARE about anything
in the game world. Nothing had any meaning to me.

The gameplay drives this point home even more, because it's soooooo slow and unfocused.
HOW MUCH I wished for a key to get the character to really RUN for once, as well as a MAP FEATURE
to finally get hold of where in the game world I was, where I already had been, and where I would have to go.
This goes down to some - really unexpected - details that frustrated the hell out of me:
Every miniscule edge you stumble upon your character has to climb. And he does so. VERY. SLOWLY.
Yes, I'm not even kidding - it drove me mad, that CLIMBING, one of the major movement mechanics of
the game, wasn't even fun - it was repetitive, sluggish and therefore overall frustratingly boring to watch.

So if you like colorful, artsy games, and walking simulations in particular, for all means - give this
game a go, one can tell it's a passion project.
But I really can't recommend this game to a broader audience for full price.

Well crafted game. Music, level design, art style, everything clicks well. Presentation is excellent and the puzzles are not too difficult, with some situations where it's easy to get stuck.

Negatives are not many. Camera can get wonky in few tight spaces. The game feels more demanding on the hardware than it should be based on its visuals. And the story, although solid, is a cliche by now, a kid alone in a strange world, death, loss, grief, yadda yadda... It gets the job of playing with your emotions done adequately, but I wish the developer had the guts to try a different approach. Still, well worth playing.

67826100.review:
Having recently bought a controller, I wanted to try a game which I could sit back, relax and enjoy and boy did Rime deliver that. I bought this game very cheap and a while ago. Having played AER, I liked the similarity of the graphics and gameplay of the two. 
Rime portrays you as a young boy who has been washed ashore a scenic island with main feature being a lighthouse like building. The game has a few puzzles (nothing too hard) but its mainly a walking simulator with very scenic visuals and an amazing soundtrack. There were a few frustrations when trying to jump on ledges but overall I thoroughly enjoyed the game. The ending was a bit sad but it doesn't change my view of this game. I thoroughly enjoyed the short game journey of the boy.

On price factor alone at the current listed price of 30 quid, I would not necessarily recommend it as the game is fairly short between 5-8 hours of gameplay but if you can get it cheap then its definitely worth time and effort.

67825004.review:
Rime is a decent enough puzzle game. Great graphics, puzzles are not too hard or too easy. 
The music is probably the best part of it. However, it does have some really annoying flaws. It has no "Collectible" mode. Even though you can select stages when you finish it once, you still have to redo the level from scratch to access the collectibles. And there are a lot of them, and they're usually out of the way, so it's unlikely you'll get a lot of them just playing through the game. 
You can't skip cinematics (and some of them are just irritating). 
The controls can be a bit finicky (for example, if you are moving along a ledge, sometimes instead of left you need to press up, even though a second ago you were pressing left - because the camera changed a little).
In the end I replayed it for the collectibles not because I wanted to, but because I'm a bit OCD. I could just as well not replayed it again - it doesn't have high replay value.
If you pick it up on sale, that would be ideal.

67328300.review:
I decided to play this because it had a fox in it, and while the fox is a very minor part I am very glad I had the experience. To me this is very much like Ico, but with environments similar to The Witness. The platforming is not very difficult, but allows you to explore the cool environments in interesting ways. There are also a ton of hidden collectibles, most of which I don't know how you'd find without a guide, but provide more ways to interact with the cool environments. The soundtrack is also very good, going from subtle ambient to swelling orchestral. The credits song is particularly good.

It took me about 10 hours to complete, but that would be shorter if you did not try to get all the extras like I did.  I recommend you give it a try if you have the time.

66365660.review:
Maybe there aren't more games like this because nobody knows what to call them. 

They're not really platformers, even though you spend a lot of time climbing and jumping.  There are environmental puzzles to an extent, but they don't feel like full-on puzzle games either.  And you're actually doing something, so they're definitely not walking simulators.  

We like to put names on things, and these games kind of defy categorization.  Each one is its own unique self-contained experience.  For that reason they might just be tough to make, too.  

Is this true?  Explain yourselves, developers!

This particular one lands somewhere between NaissanceE and Ico, which is a pretty good place to be.  It's not as pure and abstract as NaissanceE, nor as grounded in narrative structure as Ico.  

Like Ico, you play as a little kid who's not the slightest bit afraid of heights; but for all of the acrobatics, what they're really focused on here is creating a certain mood.  To do this they rely heavily on one of the most difficult and underappreciated skills in storytelling: knowing when to shut up. 

You wake up on a beach, alone.  A less confident game would immediately start dumping text onto you--maybe a flowery poem or a cryptic quote or something--to tell you how to act and feel; or even worse, they'd give you a chattering companion to follow you around like a nervous salesman trying to close the deal.
  
Not here, mercifully.  Just you, the wind, the waves, the rustling grass, the seagulls, some low-key music and the sun rising and setting as you head out to explore this strange new island on your own.  It's a totally different sort of immersion.  The game simply creates a space and invites the player to reach out and fill it.  Without saying a word they make you want to investigate every last corner; but not in a hurry.  This style slows you down to a point where you feel really present in this place.

They do speak to you along the way, but it's a visual sort of language, subtle little signposts of meaning that offer both guidance and new questions.  The little "i" up there in the title, for instance, is like that because it's supposed to look like a keyhole, a theme that shows up throughout the white tower that serves as the game's physical and figurative axis.  Other elements like the fox and the red cape appear to draw your eye and pull you gently down the game's path; and the road changes a lot as you go. 

At the beginning things seem perfectly tranquil.  Time and time again I found myself stopping just to listen and watch, looking out over some magnificent ocean vista.  Seriously, this first part is just absolutely gorgeous. At one point you interact with a puzzle that causes the whole sky to wheel around you, and I actually said out loud, "wow!" 
 
Arrive at the next section, though, and and the tranquility gives way to a frenetic, hunted tension.  Each new level brings with it a similar shift in tone.  By the time you get to the rain section, the atmosphere of crushing sorrow is so thick you practically choke on it. 
 
If you're more perceptive than I am, it might dawn on you at some point that there's a coherent purpose to what they're doing here; but rest assured they explain everything in the end and it makes perfect sense.

So while you might be thinking that this whole thing sounds awfully "artsy," they're not being pretentious about it at all.  It comes across as very sincere and heartfelt, like the authors had a genuine vision they wanted to convey.  They really are trying to show you something, not obscure it behind a cloud of oh-so-cleverness like some games do.

Of course, it'll surprise no one that the story is ultimately geared to make you feel bad.  That's pretty much par for the course with these things, huh? 
 
I wonder if that lingering bittersweet aftertaste is part of why this game doesn't seem to get talked about as much as, say, Ico.  Although Ico also had a more overtly personal story, too, with the girl and all that, whereas this one is more allegorical; so maybe Ico is a little easier to connect with in that sense.  Plus, nothing here quite matches that drawbridge scene, which was one of the most brilliant examples of visual storytelling you'll ever see in a game. 
 
Still, it's a worthy addition to the whatever-you-call-it genre.

And hey, developers take note: they managed to build this entire game of mystery and wonder without including a single sewer level.  Was that so hard?



You can find more indie game reviews at [url=https://oddlittlegames.com] oddlittlegames.com [/url] or visit my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34514756/] curator page. [/url]  Thanks, and enjoy!

¿Merece la pena?

Respuesta corta: Sí, pero rebajado. 

Respuesta larga:

Compré el juego sin conocer el estudio y sin haber escuchado de él en ningún sitio. Me llamó la atención estéticamente y como estaba rebajado y tenía unos euros en la cartera lo pillé por probarlo. 

El juego no supone ningún reto, es muy sencillito, pero la verdad es que la ambientación y la música es espectacular. A pesar de ser muy fácil, es muy divertido de jugar, ya que lo que pretende no es darte un reto sino mostrarte cosas y eso lo hace genial. Bebe mucho del team ICO este juego y se nota, pero en plan bien. 

El juego es muy cortito, 4 horas y pico me ha durado a mi, pero han sido unas 4 horas en las que no me he podido despegar del mando, cosa que no me ocurría desde hacía mucho tiempo. Son 4 horas que valen oro, pero aun así me parece un precio excesivo 35 euros por 4 horas de juego. Pilladlo de oferta. 

Me sorprendió mucho el final cuando vi los créditos y vi que estaba hecho por españoles, me alegra mucho que un equipo español demuestre que puede hacer cosas a la altura del panorama. Eso sí, la próxima vez por favor, curraos más la publicidad porque algo así no puede pasar tan inadvertido. Un saludo.

64014946.review:
This is probably the most visually and aurally beautiful game I've played. If you want to spend 5 hours or so hitting the screenshot key and saying "wow" audibly, then at least consider this. 

It's also an amazingly intuitive game. I an only assume that the designers did a ridiculous amount of playtesting to make every element of the game immediately clear. There was literally only one time in the entire game when I spent any time wandering around with no clear goal. This is despite it being a game with no tutorial, no dialogue, and with puzzles that feature teleportation and other elements that make that even more difficult.

That out of the way, this is a puzzle game. The puzzles are a mix of figuring how to get from one place to another by climbing and jumping, or making use of devices and objects in the world to do something. The best comparison I can think of is something like Tomb Raider or Enslaved: Odyssey to the West without the combat.

The plot is great, if you don't mind allusive mythopoetic nonsense. If you demand a plot be a group of opposed people trying to accomplish divergent goals or some such thing, then you'll be disappointed. There is no dialogue in the game, and, while it does come together at the end, it mostly consists of people doing allusive and enigmatic stuff in a world with its own logic. 

Overall, I think it was a fantastic experience.

63519177.review:
Perfect.. I'm really impressed with how this game managed to convey such a clear story without words..

My thoughts on this game (SPOILERS)
-
-
-
I think the "boy" was the father all along, and the entire journey symbolized his journey through the stages of grief. The reason he started out as the boy was because in his mind, he'd rather he had been the one to die in the accident instead of his son, which is why we see the seemingly misdirecting scene at the beginning: it was his denial that started this whole journey. The world is seemingly beautiful and perfect, but there is always that nagging feeling of wrongness, symbolized by the red hooded figure he is always chasing, but can never quite reach. Gradually, anger sets in and the world is a desolate, scorched land plagued by monsters. We also begin to see the dark creatures that symbolize depression and grief. The giant bird represents our psyche that actively tries to fight back and continue our state of denial but as we pull out the stops and let the grief run free (the smoke), this opposing force weakens until we are able to face the fact that something  bad has happened. In the bargaining stage, the dark creatures become hostile but the boy can seemingly fight back against them using the light orbs and the robots, and for a while it seems that the boy could win. That he could change the world back into the sunny place it used to be. But then we see the last of the robots sacrifice itself to open a door into more gloom and darkness, and you see the boy finally break down. The last stage is pretty obviously grief and depression. Instead of lighting torches, you proceed by extinguishing them. There is no light, and the dark creatures leave you be because you are clearly not a threat anymore. As the last of your hope dies (the fox), you stop feeling and become numb (stone). Life feels pointless, you've screamed so much you've lost your voice and you literally become a shadow of yourself. In the last stage, the boy fights to open up the flood gates and let the light back into the world, and finally the truth is revealed and relived. The "boy" walks towards the corridor and confronts himself (as the father). He chooses to accept his fate and leaps into the void. The father then gets up and goes to his son's room for the first time in a long time. All the locks the boy opened through out the game culminates in the final, physical act of unlocking the door into the room. Finally, he lets go.

63501123.review:
Wow.

For a person that doesn't play single player games at all, that's all I can say about this game, really. You have to play it to get the full experience. For a normal person playing it, it should take around 6 hours. The soundtrack and story are so amazing. There are a few puzzles that may [b] seem [/b] difficult, and if that happens, just step back and take a look around. Nothing is impossible.

One other review said that bugs don't exist in this game. I actually managed to softlock myself twice when I played it: once, I got stuck between a pillar and moving box, and was basically floating and couldn't move my character. 62951498.review:
I don't think this is a bad game, it's just I am [i]so not[/i] the intended audience for it, it's hard for me to tell. 

This game is for people with a strong affinity for visual art and story telling. Are you the kind of person who can decode the ending of The Sopranos, either by yourself or with a couple of hints? Do you love "Ways of Seeing" by John Berger? Then this game is probably for you. 

If, like me, you would never, ever in a million years have figured out what happened to Tony Soprano without that Master of Sopranos guy explaining it, or you tried to read "Ways of Seeing" and didn't understand WTF Berger was trying to explain and didn't particularly care; then this will probably just be another blah 3rd person platform puzzler. If you like that gaming genre, you might like it, but the controls feel sluggish and unresponsive. I get a strong "poorly optimised console port" vibe from it.  

Every 3D puzzle game I play now gets compared to [i]The Talos Principle, Portal[/i] and [i]Portal 2[/i]. Those games had a narrative, atmosphere, and/or carefully crafted mystery that inspired me to persevere with the tougher puzzles. The plot in [i]RiME[/i]... exists[1] as far as I can tell and that's about it. Again, this is probably because it is told purely visually, so I'm no doubt missing a lot.

The difficulty of the puzzles (at least as far as I got with it) lies exclusively in decoding the visual cues that explain the mechanics. Once you understand the mechanics that the visuals are trying to communicate, they are utterly trivial. Compare with [i]Talos[/i] or [i]Portal[/i], where the mechanics are explicit, but the logic is challenging. 

[i]The Talos Principle[/i] evoked an incredible, simultaneous combination of joy and melancholy. My emotional response to this game can be summed up as either "that's pretty" or "that's annoying." YMMV.

I did not enjoy this game.

[1] [b]SPOILERS[/b] [spoiler]My best guess at the plot is: you are a prince. You have been shipwrecked/orphaned/killed (not sure which). You must navigate the ruins of what may or may not have been your kingdom. You are not given much of a reason to do this beyond figuring out what happened to you. You have a pet fox. It is not much help. I got to the windmills level with the big bird. It is pretty obvious you have to activate the windmills to drive off the bird so you can use the golden ball to set the time of day, then stand on the pedestal so yours and the statue's shadows open the portal.[/spoiler] I didn't care enough to bother.

EDIT: Just read the plot summary in Wikipedia. Unless there is a step-by-step "this symbolises X", "that symbolises Y" reveal at the end, there is no way I would ever have guessed what this was about.

62295434.review:
I played RiME just recently, a couple years after its release, and I wish that I had picked it up much sooner. RiME is a beautiful game. The landscapes and stunning visuals just ooze a one of a kind atmosphere, developing tonalities that play a part in the larger narrative. It has the capacity to be meditative and small, in moments just a wonder-filled story about a boy encountering a magical island steeped in myth, but also larger than life and compelling if you'll listen.

I've played exploration puzzler games for years, starting with the Myst games when I was a kid, and I have to say that if you're looking for a game to wow you with complexity and crushingly difficult puzzles, that isn't what RiME is about. The puzzles in RiME are a mechanism of the story-telling and while they are often surprising and always fun to interact with, they just don't have that kind of difficulty as an object. That said, if you're looking for a story told in long dialogues and filled with characters verbally developed, this is also not what RiME is about. Instead, RiME is an exercise in the kinds of stories that can be told beyond words, and it tricks you into loving every part of the world that they made along the way.

So please as you play this fantastic game (and you really should!) take it slowly. Explore. Be playful. Take time to experience the world and feel your way through this masterful piece of story-telling. Too many games today tell the same stories, packaged in the same way, or have nothing to say at all. RiME is a breath of fresh air, from a team of developers who took the time to craft something poignant and meaningful. 

Hope you enjoy it as much as I have!

I signed up for the Ghibli-esque art style, music, and adorable fox; and I got onions. Thanks.

The only major complaint I have is that the story feels incredibly disjointed, for reasons I can't exactly get far into without possibly saying too much. But basically it's like it set itself up as one thing and then all of the sudden decides it wants to be something else entirely. Which tbf it does kind of makes sense why, but it's more like 2 stories (or 3-ish depending on interpretation) awkwardly stitched together than at least one cohesive one. Or at the very least when I finally found the solution I just felt embarrassingly dumb rather than having a "hell yeah" moment.

It's another I would probably wait for a sale. Though it is pretty to look at and the music is amazing, it's one of those games that's less a game and more of an experience, even if it is an experience that might stick to some people for awhile. There's not a lot of replayability unless you just want to collect everything (Which you definitely should, to get the best ending. It's been a long time since I played this game, but I enjoyed it.  On top of that, I found the mood and theme of the story very touching.  It's seldom that I recall a game with an emotional sense as with this one.

There are possible spoilers beyond this.

I actually thought I'd given a brief review before, but since I did not one reason for writing it now is because a few days ago I witnessed the funeral of a 13 year old boy (young man).  He developed an infection that rather quickly put him in the hospital.  Within a couple of days more he was comatose and died within a day after that, leaving his family and two sisters just before Christmas.

At some point during all of this maybe I noticed a trading card in my inventory, but for whatever reason I felt a strong connection between the "kid with fox" card and the loss of the local boy.  I think that some players perhaps were not satisfied by the amount of action in this game, and if so they may not have appreciated the weight of the last scenes.

Maybe I shouldn't make this game seem epic, but for me it certainly was far above average, and it can be purchased very cheaply at times.

61104260.review:
Paid: ~$10 (USD)

I beat it but didn't feel good about it.  8.25 HEY!/AAH!'s out of 10.

There are many (44) collectibles in this game: toys, emblem fragments, outfits, keyholes, strange statues, white shades, and lullaby shells.

I progressively got worse at finding the collectibles as my patience dwindled and as the game became scarier.

As a result, I beat the game in under 6 hours (went AFK with the game open) with a lousy 11/31 achievements unlocked.

Pros
- Great performance (on an i7-9700K & RTX 2070 SUPER at least)
- Great soundtrack (just listen for the subtle changes as you progress)
- Great controls (used both mouse & keyboard and Xbox One controller)
- Visually appealing (solid use of the Unreal Engine)
- The journey, not the destination
- Ability to review all obtained collectibles and additional artwork from the Extras menu

Cons
- Learning the hard way that there were hostiles
- Being gated from the collectibles (accidentally progressing via critical cut scenes and adventuring beyond points of no return)
- Feeling like I did something wrong upon beating the game (probably because I didn't pick up on the story)

I think it would have helped to have known that this game - in general - is about [spoiler]the five stages of grief[/spoiler].

61016961.review:
After washing up on an island that contains ancient, beautiful ruins a young boy sets out on a journey to find out what happened to him. After a bit of exploring he comes upon a meadow where there are statues. In order to activate them he must follow the lights that shoot into the sky. To reach them he has must climb, jump and swim to their locations then activate them with his voice.  Once he returns to the meadow a fox is waiting to guide him further on his journey of discovery!
As the boy leaves the meadow he can find hidden paths and places that reveal objects that are part of his story.  He will find some of these are easy to get to while others require much more to reach. He will learn as he climbs, jumps  and swims his way through locations and puzzles the story unfolds revealing who he is and what happened to him. Though the boy may not find all the hidden items the first time through....he will find it's worth playing again to find them.

I highly recommend this game.  It is one that requires patience because it's not just a walk in the park type of game. It requires lots of exploring and figuring out how to reach areas and solve puzzles along the way. I have just completed my first play through and found I did not locate all the extra items that can be collected. I know it may take several play throughs to find them all but it will be worth it. The only thing I wish is that the game was broken down better in to chapters or episodes to make game exploring for the extras after completing the game the first time through.

I really wanted to enjoy Rime... It's a beautiful surreal world to be dropped into and at the beginning I wanted to explore every corner of it, especially when I discovered there are collectibles to find! But they gave the boy an ungainly movement style that made exploring feel sluggish and annoying to me. Every time you run and stop the boy wobbles and almost falls over, as though he is an uncoordinated toddler rather than... maybe eight, ten years old? When you jump down off anything he takes his time picking himself up. It's just too slow and constantly interrupts your gameplay. I didn't find most of the collectibles because it was too annoying to go looking for them. 

The puzzles were not very hard or very varied. I got 'stumped' for a few minutes at two or three of them. I'm not a hardcore puzzle gamer. 

I had to look up what the story was about after I finished the game, though I got an inkling of it in the last chapter. It still doesn't quite make sense to me. 60111832.review:
RiME (pronounced like rhyme) is a game that was created because some dude decided he would try to impress his date and swam out into the sea with her towards a buoy off the coast of Spain.

True story.

He realized he had went past his limits but kept on going since he thought he could just rest while hanging onto the buoy. But this turned out to be wrong as the buoy was really slippery and it was a struggle to hang onto. He told the girl he was too tired to get back to land safely and she basically just said 'ciao' and ditched him. He struggled back to shore only to fail and he began to drown. As his life flashed before his eyes, he came up with the idea for RiME.

Fortunately, someone saw him, and saved him at the last moment. Then he married the girl who ditched him, and turned RiME into reality. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

59732086.review:
This game is visually beautiful, and has a very good soundtrack, and for those reasons alone I'd recommend you get it when it goes on sale. 

However, the gameplay and story fall flat for me. The puzzles are shallow and reminiscent of every other puzzle game in existence (moving boxes, basic platforming, borrowing Journey's voice mechanic, etc.). Because of the lack of dialogue, the story is entirely told through occasional cinematics and environmental storytelling. Unfortunately, these things aren't executed as well as in many other games that use them, and for the majority of the game you're left guessing at what's really going on. I came up with my own interpretation of the story based off of the scraps of information the game provided, and was unsatisfied when the full story was essentially packed into the last 5 minutes and clashed with what I thought was going on. Even after the game was finished, I had to look up the synopsis of the game to answer the question: "What happened?" Even understanding now what the game is about, there are certain elements that are still confusing. 

[spoiler] This game is meant to represent the 5 stages of a father's grief over his son. Okay, cool concept. But there's just not enough concrete storytelling to have everything in the game make sense with this. What do the robots in the green temple area represent? What do they have to do with grief? Are the shadow people just grief personified, or are they something else? Sure, the monster bird thing probably represents anger, so what do the windmills represent? What does the storm in the windmill area represent? Why is the kid's voice his source of magic, besides to copy Journey? This game feels like it was supposed to be something besides an allegory for grief, but maybe that's just me. [/spoiler]

On the whole, this game was beautiful, but disappointing. I just wish this game was something slightly different.

57748609.review:
Throughout their continuing history, video games have defined and redefined what it is to be a video game: confounding puzzles, horrific experiences, cinematic journeys, thoughtful meditations, everything in-between, and every combination of the aforementioned. There is one quality that all video games endeavor to share, though: that they are entertaining, that they are fun. Lamentably, and as much as this reviewer wishes it were not the case, [i]RiME[/i] just does not deliver on that front, despite being created with so much apparent care.

[i]RiME[/i] sees you filling the sandals of a young boy shipwrecked on a mysterious island populated by ancient ruins, curious statuettes, a delightful red fox, and plenty of mysteries. Throughout your time on the island, you'll look to discover who you are and how you managed to end up here in the first place. Your journey will take you through a variety of beautiful locales, dizzying heights, and treacherous lows, all of which have been beautifully (and stylishly) realized with Unreal Engine 4. All the while you're accompanied by a haunting and lovely soundtrack. It's these qualities that make it so unfortunate that [i]RiME's[/i] gameplay is such a woeful slog.

Rest assured, it's not the lack of combat or the heavy focus on exploration that make the gameplay drag so. In truth, at the outset of the game there was hardly any notice of a drag at all. As [i]RiME[/i] proceeds, though, the block-pushing, climbing, and even the decidedly clever puzzle elements that are introduced early-on begin to wear thin. Bear in mind, this is not something that would make or break a game. It's the fact that on top of this, the simple act of movement in [i]RiME[/i] starts to become an irritation. It began to feel like every action made by our curious hero was mired in some way: his running [i]just[/i] too slow, his climbing [i]just[/i] too sluggish, the cooldown on his interactions [i]just[/i] too long. This even lead to a moment of shouting, "Move faster!" at our hero. At this time, the very game itself had become a draining experience and it was the curiosity about its story alone that kept me pushing onward to the end.

That being said, [i]RiME's[/i] ending is touching and heartfelt in a way that was unexpected...but getting there had felt like such a chore that the impact was lessened. I was shocked to find it had only taken around 4 hours to complete when it legitimately felt like it had taken five times longer. This is all written with a pang of regret: [i]RiME[/i] has so much good about it but moving around its world is simply not fun and the player spends most of the game doing it. I feel that the best way to express this is to point to Giant Squid's [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/384190/ABZU/]ABZU[/url], which has no combat, is only about exploration, but is an absolute joy to move around in.

There are so many things to appreciate about [i]RiME[/i] but it just was not enjoyable to [i]play[/i]. On top of this, the price of entry (at time of writing: $29.99) is far too steep a price for what [i]RiME[/i] brings to the table. All of this being said, I simply cannot recommend [i]RiME[/i]. As beautiful as it may be, as lovely as its soundtrack, its fatal flaw prevents it from being something that all games should aspire to be: fun.

55888903.review:
The problem with RiME is that it feels more like a tech demo for Unreal Engine 4 rather than anything substantive. It's certainly not a bad game; a positive of being so simplistic, but visually competent, is that there is nothing fundamentally flawed in the underlying structure. But it's not a game I can say I will remember or recommend people spend the time playing if they can play anything else.

Technically RiME looks fantastic, and will really work your PC if it doesn't have the most recent of cards. Your graphical options are fairly minimal, and even on max settings you aren't missing out on a lot from there to low settings and SSAO aliasing off. Regardless you get the visual equivalent of a water-painting, and even if you didn't have any choices with graphical fidelity the game would still stand on its own due to the good work underneath it. Ironically I can't say that this game blasts, say, Windwaker out of the water, but that's more a testament to how cel-shading endures the passage of time.

Typically I don't talk about 'graphics' in my reviews, and this next section should explain why.

RiME is a competent, albeit shallow experience. The game is a puzzle platformer, with you travelling 5 somewhat open but fairly linear areas. I'll give the developers a pat on the back for making this feel like an open-world game whilst not being one-that takes a bit of map design skill. The game mechanics focus on either pulling on objects, grabbing ledges, activating mechanisms, or rolling spheres to change shadow trajectories. There is no additional equipment to collect, which means that you never feel like you shouldn't be in an area, as every puzzle can be solved upon encounter.

With minimal narrative tools, the game really should be applauded over its ability to give no information whilst not leaving the player in the dark. Part of the fun is figuring out just what is expected of you, and perhaps as an outgrowth of its simplicity it's never too complex.

There is a story here, and a lack of narrative doesn't necessarily [i]hurt[/i] the game...but it also doesn't [i]aid[/i] it either. See, there's a twist at the end of sorts, but it's less impactful when its the only piece of information that makes any sense. In the end there wasn't much of a story to begin with. I can explain it in a sentence but it would spoil the whole thing. Just as shallow as everything else, the story is a lot of fluff until the reveal.

RiME's development history was tumultuous, and in the transition from an open-world tower defense/survival game the developers likely stripped everything to basics to get a finished product. It's a fine product, but a thoroughly unforgettable one that was perhaps too stripped down to amount to anything memorable. It will get praise by the "artistic" gamers in the crowd, but I can't find any solid merit to recommend this over anything else on the market. 

4/10: Below Average

I recommend this to everyone. Absolutely everyone.
A 10/10 game, no glitches, beautiful story, challenging and inventive puzzles and nice collectibles. Solving the puzzles gives constant rewarding feels, and the game looks absolutely breathtaking (even with a stylized look!).

As for my recommendations:
- Take the time to play this. Make sure you have a few days close to each other, because you want to keep this story fresh in your mind. 
- DO NOT look anything up about the game. Seriously, I mean it. Just press play and do not look at anything else besides the settings. This will allow you to self-discover the story, and I promise you, you do not want to know beforehand.
- Explore. Explore everything and everywhere and you will be rewarded with background story and just general feels.
- "yell" at everything.

Cons: 
One of the chapters (bird) has a large, open map that is very easy to get lost in. Otherwise, the game leads you on very well, but this chapter is simply not linear and got me frustrated. I spent a long time running back and forth trying to find the next place to go. Ugh. I have seen many a streamer struggle with the same issue.

55606275.review:
[h1]Overall[/h1]
If I could give "RiME" a so-so rating, I'd do it.  Since I'm not all that enamored of it, I really don't think it's worthy of a Thumbs Up and I feel bad about giving it a Thumbs Down.  But, since there are plenty of positive reviews here, I guess I'll go the negative route and Not Recommend it.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
Aesthetically, "RiME" is a beautiful game both visually and aurally.  It's got a good, solid theme.  And, mechanistically, my only gripe is that the game tends to grab and reorient the camera for its own purposes instead of leaving it where it belongs for mine.  

[h1]Negatives[/h1]
Unfortunately, there are several big faults with it:
[list]
[*]The story is very weak, and, when you get down to it, what the story has you doing really has no logical connection to the end result.
[*]You don't even get an inkling of the story until you've completed the vast majority of the game.  Coupled with that, or perhaps because of that, you play the game without having any idea of what you're supposed to be doing or accomplishing (or even why you should be doing it).  I spent much of the game wondering if I was letting some vast, old evil loose into the world.  After all, someone locked all this stuff up for some reason, didn't they?
[*]Outside of aesthetics, the game doesn't know what it wants to be.  Is it a platformer, puzzle, adventure, or exploration game?  Well, yes and no to each of them.  There's platforming, but it's fairly pointless and easy (it works out to a search for guano since that marks places where you can climb).  There are puzzles, but they're all trivial.  The adventure aspect is marred by your having no idea what your goal is or why you're doing the things the game wants you to do.  And, exploration is scarred by the game locking paths behind you for no reason and having no way to go back since it's a checkpoint game.
[*]The game introduces some kind of "shadow people," gives no explanation for them or what you're supposed to do with them.  Heck, in most places they're entirely passive (basically, landscape).  But, in one area, they attack you for no reason.
[*]At the same point where the game introduces those shadow people, it starts putting sand statues of people in.  Again, with no explanation or apparent use.
[*]And, finally (and I have to be vague here because of spoilers), in one stage of the game, it uses a very silly thing as a key to a lock.
[/list]
[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
It took me 8.6 hours to "finish" the game with only 13 out of 31 Achievements (41%) complete.  Aesthetically, I'm pleased with the game.  But, gameplay-wise, I'm not happy with it.  Also, at its current list price of almost $30, it's certainly not worth it.  Normally, I 100% all Achievements.  But, since I'm not all that happy with the game, I'm not sure if I'll be going back to complete them.  But, even if I do, I highly doubt they would add enough to the game to make it worth that price.  So, even though I'm mostly on the edge with the game, I'm Not Recommending it.

EDIT:  I went back through the entire game with an Achievement walkthrough just to get those Achievements I'd missed.  It took me another 6.9 hours to do so (totaling 15.5 hours for 100% Achievements).

55183317.review:
RiME is a Puzzle/Plattformer game and an adventure in a beautiful world. The game is kind of open world and mostly relaxing. It has a line path to the story but you can explore any areas around. 
This game is more about story than gameplay, players who want complex and challenging puzzle games will probably not be satisfied here. 

[u] Story [/u]

Rime starts with a little boy being washed ashore on a mysterious island. There are many ruins and a huge tower in its center. When the boy, with a spiritual guide, a fox, explores the island, he encounters several times a mysterious man in a red cloak, whom he can never reach. 
[spoiler]As the boy climbs the big tower, the first level ends and he comes to the four other levels of play. It becomes clear, that the individual game levels represents each of the five stages of mourning and dying after Elisabeth Kübler-Ross:

Deny
Fury
Negotiate
Depression
Acceptance [/spoiler]
One wonders what we are doing here, why we are here and what our goal is. Gradually, we get to know the "before",  but at the end, there is a (surprising) disclosure, that reveals a much bigger picture of the storyline.
[spoiler] The feels man...[/spoiler]

[u]Graphics [/u]

I really really really enjoyed the grafics (took screenshots every 5 mins lol).
They create a magical world that changes more and more as the game progresses. Each section has its own well-rounded atmosphere.

[u] Music [/u]

The music is beautiful and creates the atmosphere of the game sections combined with the visual aspect.

[u] Overall / Achievements [/u]

If you only focus on the Storyline, you will probably get through the game in 6-7 hours. But you will miss a big part of the RiME-world. Most of the Achievements are collectibles, for which you have to explore and experiment a lot. Some of them are easy(er) to find, for others I needed a guide, because they were really hidden or you had to do some extra rounds. With that part of exploring, it doubles or triples the play time. Overall ,it is really fun to do them, mostly because there is so much so see and do, but some Achievements are a pain in the Ass [spoiler] "Hold your breath" had cost me all my nerves lol [/spoiler] 

I really liked it and enjoyed it very much. It was just the right mix between relaxation and excitement (even if the story at the beginning is confusing. Keyholes may help a little -. IF you can find them)

If you don't want to lay back and relax with your videogames this isn't for you. If you still want to experience the story then watch a silent playthrough of the game or something.

RiME is a story told through the medium of a video-game and it's absolutely stunningly beautiful. It's "a book come to life" sort of "game". There are little secrets you can go out of your way to grab but they don't mean all that much in the end, it just meant you explored more of the world that was built. I personally don't recommend it cause it will take away from the experience of the game. What you're really here for is the meat/story of the game which is throughout the entire way through, incredibly vague and puzzling but intriguing which keeps you hooked constantly. The payoff of this game comes in the final parts where it all finally snaps together because the story is told without words. The game is adorable, the colors are vibrant, and the sound design is stunning. I could go into more depth but it would take ages. If you want to play this game I would suggest playing with a controller so you can lay back and relax from your bed or couch when playing this game. Being hunched up in a chair while trying to play the game will really take away from the experience. Comfort is key. Enjoy!

55081446.review:
to be completely honest I went into this game without high expectations and thinking it would be just a fun/entertaining adventure game but I sure was wrong:


the Rime sets itself as an adventure for you and me to play through and the Rime sets the world and its characters to tell us a story about the rise of fall of you and me, and the Rime sets its lights, water and dust, drawings and artifacts as a way and a mean to gaze into ancient cultures and civilizations that tells so much without words, that tells so much without trying to and that tells so much without changing the reality of that a child who wakes up to find himself lying on a sunny beach somewhere in the world

the Rime excels at telling an adventure, a history and most importantly, a tragedy

You wake up on an island which seems overused but soon enough you start to realize that your voice is a way to control a certain...things lets call them for now, certain things in the island as if you were destined to wash up on that island's beach and if things were built for you and you only, you and me


but where are you and where did you come from and who are you and why are you doing what you are doing?
I had the same experience in many other games, as where some of them failed to explain the situation or give a simple explanation the Rime not only succeeded but it excelled at not only explaining itself, the world and its characters, you and your past and your future but it dug up ancient tribes and realms all through drawings on walls and on pieces of wood and cloth just as in real life because the Rime is nothing but an attempt to imitate real life... or perhaps an attempt to refuse the reality of real life and replace it?

Acceptance, Depression, Bargaining, Anger, Denial is what the Rime is and what it is here to tell and it does it so well that it makes it not only a puzzle adventure game but a puzzle within a puzzle which can only let the player think about the possibilities and options and perhaps... 
the realities 
it will leave the player wondering about life's worth and everything's price, freedom price and what's the captivity price too

from denial to acceptance, the eternal light controls all,  it guides us and it enables us to keep going, to never stop no matter what the price is, sacrifices are to be made and tears to shed because the price of freedom and the price of us and them raising from the ashes is never too much.

the Rime allows us to experience all that while us being nothing, a soul looking for guidance and the eternal light provides but will we make it? where to though? we don't know, we only know that we are just a soul, a lost one that is trying to reach its final destination to reach its ''acceptance''

the ending of the Rime re-frames the whole game, it re-frames everything, and allow us finally to be something and to finally let go, let the pain and let the past go and accept reality, that is most definitely not a denial that is indeed acceptance.

recommended.

55081274.review:
I thoroughly enjoyed this game, and found it contained a surprising amount of story considering it lacks text or speech. Anyone who enjoyed AER: Memories of old will likely enjoy it. I highly recommend it to people who enjoy puzzle games and being able to explore.

Pros:
- Beautiful, colourful art style similar to AER: Memories of Old
- Puzzles were not too complex for the most part
- Tells a story via cutscenes at the end of each chapter
- Collectibles expand on the story, but are not necessary to understand it
- Plenty of nooks and crannies (many containing collectibles) to explore

Cons:
- Some of the collectibles are *very* well hidden - I can't imaging many people would find them without a guide
- THAT EFFING BIRD IN CHAPTER 2. I was so happy with the finale. I found it discouraged exploration and made some areas frustrating as it gave me mere seconds to try and figure out the puzzle before dying
- Some areas, especially chapter 3 and later, are too dark. I understand the desire to make it atmospheric and realistic, but I found myself getting of the couch and up close to the TV to try and make out what was going on. I could have increased the brightness, but then non-dark areas look washed out. 

Verdict: 8/10

A beautiful puzzle/platformer with a seriously bitter-sweet theme (that ending.....damn, that ending.....was someone chopping onions nearby?!?).  The graphics are good, the music is phenomenal, and the puzzles are easy enough that you don't feel like beating your head against a wall and/or consulting a walkthrough, but challenging enough that you feel like a smart person when you solve them (well......some of them......most are truthfully on the "push a button to win" side of things, but that's okay once in awhile), and the signposting is largely good (there's a few points where I wandered around a bit before I figured out where to go next).

There are a few minor issues with the camera which can prove troublesome when trying to perform a jump of some sort from place to place, but they don't appear often (I only noticed it four or five times, so roughly once an hour....not bad at all!).

All in all, I quite soundly recommend Rime.

54631542.review: Un juego bellísimo en todos los aspectos. El diseño artístico es bastante único, con unos escenarios repletos de arquitecturas y paisajes que evocan a Italia, España o Egipto, sin dejar de ser un mundo fantástico y onírico. Si a ese imaginario propio le añades una pizca de Ghibli y otra de Ico, te puedes hacer una idea de lo que verás en Rime. La música raya a un nivel pocas veces visto en un videojuego, y menos en uno independiente como éste y será la que irá conformando la parte emotiva y emocional de lo que vamos a ir experimentando durante el viaje. El juego nos irá presentando distintos escenarios que deberemos recorrer de una forma más o menos lineal (dichos escenarios están llenos de coleccionables que podremos encontrar siempre que nos alejemos del camino marcado), resolviendo puzzles lo suficientemente retantes como para distanciar al juego del walking simulator, pero que en ningún momento suponen un reto que frene el fluir de la aventura. Estos puzzles son bastante entretenidos en términos generales. La historia es metafórica y se irá desentrañando con imágenes y simbolismo, pero sólo al final comprenderemos en toda su magnitud lo que hemos visto y vivido. Y esa comprensión te va a romper algo por dentro. En fin, un juego muy recomendable, un viaje único y una experiencia de las que dejan huella.

54592093.review: Pretty nice adventure puzzle game. Very peaceful and zen with nature. The artwork is gorgeous, the world complex, soundtrack superb and it changes subtly with the progression of the levels. The puzzles and the gameplay make me think of this as a more kid friendly Tomb Raider. The puzzles feel like they are the right amount of hard for me, with some decent queues on how to progress without much back-tracking or head scratching, younger players not used to the genre might get stuck on some of the sections of the game though. Overall, it feels good to explore the different locations of the world as the game progresses and that's it's main selling point. The feeling of wonder didn't seem to vanish. You do need to be in the right mindset to enjoy your sessions without the progression feeling like work (i had to keep them short and occasional) but the whole cinematic ambience is very quick to make you feel at home at once when you come back to it. It feels a bit pricey, i got it on a sale/bundle, otherwise i probably wouldn't have purchased full price, but you can see where all the development money went into as you progress through the game. I agree with some negative points mentioned by other reviewers that the camera movements sometimes feel a bit counter-intuitive and the character moving too slow to really make you want to explore every nook and cranny. The ending is pretty memorable and well worth the full play through.

54588741.review: I didn't expect it to hurt...

54574676.review:
Rime es un juego de exploración y plataformas en 3ª persona ambientado en un mundo imaginario basado en el paisaje de las costas mediterráneas. Durante unas 7 horas manejaremos a un niño por espacios abiertos mientras recorremos acantilados, cuevas, bosques y templos resolviendo pequeños acertijos y descubriendo sus misterios. Nos cuenta una historia más sencilla de lo que creemos en un principio, siempre utilizando la metáfora como recurso. Un juego que comienza muy fuerte con unos escenarios abiertos y jugosos y que, con el paso de las horas, va ofreciendo unos mapas más sosos y se olvida completamente de introducir nuevas mecánicas jugables o hacer más complejas las que ya existían. En general los retos más interesantes y los mejores escenarios los encontraremos en la primera mitad de la aventura, resultando la segunda mitad mucho menos inspirada, lo que puede provocar cierta decepción tras el inicio tan bello del juego.
En cualquier caso es un hermoso juego, que transmite múltiples sensaciones, con un gameplay básico de plataformeo y exploración, pero con un potente diseño artístico. Una aventura original, sencilla y muy personal que disfrutarán los jugadores más calmados que no necesitan de grandes dosis de acción para divertirse con los videojuegos.

8'2

Más: https://yexreviews.wordpress.com/2019/08/11/rime-2017/

I like platformers. I like puzzle games. I like exploratory "emo" games. But for whatever reason, Rime was just supremely boring. I managed to plod through the whole game and the overall story is... sad, I guess? I don't know. It just felt like it was a lot of random imagery trying to convey "something," but I never really got exactly what that something was.

Visually, it's beautiful (although taxing even on my 2080). But the gameplay is just... so... boring. It's like it couldn't decide if it wanted to be an exploration or a platformer or a puzzler, so it just half-heartedly tried to be all of them, and none of it is even remotely challenging and, for me, none of it was engaging. Actually, it felt a *whole lot* like Abzu, just with a sadder story. If you really loved that game then you'll probably like this. I greatly prefer Limbo/Inside, which this game also seemed to rip off (or "pay homage to") near the end.

54168119.review:
I'm giving this a thumbs up because overall it was a pleasant experience and I'm sure it will be amazing for a large group of people.  I want to start with what I don't like about this game first before I get to the good.  Beware of exactly what type of game this is.  Steam recommended it to me because I play a ton of puzzle games, and the trailer made it seem like it was going to be very puzzle intensive.  Well if you're a hard core puzzler, DO NOT expect to be challenged whatsoever by this game.  The puzzles were extremely easy.  There were less than a handful of times I was stuck very briefly, and that was always because I literally couldn't find an object I needed or a ledge I was able to jump to.  It was "pixel hunting" stuck, not mentally stuck.  I feel like this game had much bigger potential to take advantage of the types of puzzles it used.  Some of them were heading in the cleaver direction but the moment there would be the slightest hint of a challenge, that was the end of the puzzle.

This game also had huge potential to be challenging in a different way but again was made far too easy.  The platforming aspects.  It is heavily influenced by the original Tomb Raider games.  Often times that type of platforming can be puzzles in and of themselves.  Once again, this game touched to surface of that aspect but never presented an actual challenge.  It left it very ambiguous as to whether I was playing an atmospheric walking sim, or if I was playing a puzzle platformer.  

The game seems like an open world exploration game at first but it's actually straight up on rails.  Which I have no issue with.  That part is done very well because you feel like you're in a large world but you're always subtly steered in the correct direction without it being overtly obvious.  That's not an easy feat and they executed that well.  There are hidden bonus items scattered variously off the path, however I stopped purposefully looking for them early on.  I don't feel like this game rewards exploration because there is no way to make your character go any faster, and these areas can be quite large.  So if you go all the way to a far corner of an area just to find nothing, you have to trek all the way back to the main path every single time.  It really gets old after a while.  There needs to be a sprint key.

Onto the good.  The game is downright beautiful and the music compliments it perfectly.  I was very absorbed into the atmosphere of the game and I kept playing it just to see new areas.  Your character is very entertaining with all of his little quirks that you can trigger with the "shout" button.  He sings when he's in a good mood, pouts when he's frustrated and in a difficult area, shivers when he's scared, says hello to strange creatures.  The art is simply incredible and sound design is also outstanding.  There is no dialog at all but there is most certainly a story with an emotional twist.  I kind of predicted the ending but it was still very powerful.

If you are on board for a feel good experience with only slight challenges then this game is a 10/10.  If you love games like The Witness, Portal, Stephens Sausage Roll, etc., and are looking for something along those lines, then this game is a 2/10.  So choose based on you.

54073650.review:
I don't like this game. It looks pretty and the music is quite good, but it feels like Rime wanted to be a painting, not a game. There is practically no story, beside the atmosphere that is, there are no character to speak of, and the puzzles feel arbitrary and shoved in as required to make it a game, rather than because the puzzles are inherently interesting themselves, which they’re not. 
      While I tend to enjoy some games like these, the visual and sound design should exists to support either gameplay or some kind of story, which it doesn’t, which is a shame. The Witness visual design supports the core gameplay of puzzles, which are challenging and interesting. Wandersong uses it’s visual and sound design to support its story, characters, and themes. Anti Chamber uses its minimalist design to draw attention to its space bending puzzles. Rime uses it’s nice and stylizes art direction and music to walk you through a pretty picture, but with little substance behind it.
      If you want something pretty, then go ahead, but don’t expect anything else other than “pretty”

54004058.review: A surprisingly good game.  Metacritic ranks this at 78 - I'd rank it more in the low 90's.  Definitely one of the best games made in the last decade (uh...I play LOTS of games) and is also ESRB rated E10+.  Other than the second level, I enjoyed it very much.  The first level was an absolute treat - very relaxing, discovering what to do, easy game mechanics, beautiful visuals, long view distance, no enemies, etc.  The second level brought in the game's only real enemy that was very annoying and left me no time to freely view the landscapes.  Part of the second level and a good chunk of the third level missed a huge opportunity to have relaxing underwater puzzles.  Instead, the underwater bits involve frequent racing through the water just to get to the next section before the character would die.  Plus the underwater bits are quite beautiful but there's just no time available to simply stop and look around.  There's some replay value in the game to go back and find all of the missed secrets and to get the achievements.  Revisiting/playing the first level again is totally worth it but you'll have to decide for yourself if the other levels are worth revisiting.  The game can be beaten very casually in about 6.5 hours and the story is solid even though none of the characters really say anything.  The music and audio are fantastic and timed to the actions of the character.  Definitely recommend.  RiME is a game that gamers of all ages will enjoy.

They've even tried to keep the open world illusion by putting jellyfish in the water outside the bounds of the map to stop you, instead of having you just hit a transparent barrier like in some games. Took me a little bit to work out that the trackpad is your camera angle though which you really need to know. None of the puzzles I've come across so far have been particularly hard, but young kids might need some help. This game actually got to me in a way very few games do. So, you're a lad who washes up on the shore of this island with a big tower off in the distance and you're led along by an adorable little fox spirit. The character's primary mode of interaction is simply shouting, which distinctly reminded me of a few similar style games such as The Last Guardian. But what really drove me were the underlying mysteries I'd start asking myself in this imagery driven game, such as "What's with the tower? Why is it important? And just what is the deal with the mysterious figure that always seems to be just out of reach?" The game is stuffed full of little collectibles that encourage exploring this beautiful world.
In my opinion, a beautiful game I absolutely recommend giving a shot.

RiME is a puzzle platformer, it isn't just decent but also cute.

The puzzles are challenging sometimes but not too hard, the platforming scenes ok, not too hard. Doable for anyone who not really good or like platformer games (like me).

The story is interesting, touching. No narration, no voice acting but you not going to miss any of those.

The graphic is decent, looks awesome, the game is colorful and beautiful.

RiME is kid friendly, you can purchase to your kid or nonadult relative.

Only thing I not liked in RiME is the camera movement/rotation, most of the time you can move it freely, then suddenly at most of the platforming scenes it moves to a fixed position and sometimes I had issue to realize which button to push for moving forward as sometimes it was A or S or D and not W.

I would recommend this game, it is very enjoyable and cute. I personally find the base price very expensive, but as an East-Middle European who cursed with West European prices, I find the full prices of all games overpriced with a few exceptions. RiME is a must to play once owned or very recommended to purchase during the sale.

[b]Hey, I am an achievement hunter! [/b]

Many collectibles are very easy to miss. The good part is, that you can replay chapters once completed the game so easier to return to missed items and achievements.

Great game with great atmosphere and a moving story. It has good, intuitive puzzles that I found compelling and fun, though they might be a bit easy for some. Good platforming and environment variety kept it from being just another Journey-clone. 

I completed it in 4 hours, which might seem short, but was just right for what the game was going for.

I noticed some visual glitches, with the geometry disappearing when the camera collides with the terrain. This only happened within caves and tight spaces, and was most noticeable in the first area of the game. 

Apart from that, RiME is a very good platforming adventure, that i would recommend to any fan of games like Ico and Journey.

53289504.review:
Empecemos por las cosas buenas: es un juego precioso con un arte que quita el hipo, tanto que he perdido la cuenta de las screenshots que he hecho, la música también es increíble.
Realmente el juego no tiene nada malo, simplemente cosas regulares como los puzzles, que son demasiado fáciles, quizás, para mi gusto. The game is not perfect:
[list]
    [*]I found many instances where controls were not in sync with the required action
    [*]There were far too many cases where the camera just goes wonky (usually at very inconvenient times)
    [*]The puzzles were decent, but as I only got stuck once, I'd say they could have been a bit more challenging
    [*]The length of the game is too short (like Portal 2, too little of a good thing).
[/list]
But, those issues were minor issues to me. I've read that some have had performance issues with this game. I experienced no such issues (i5-6600, GeForce 1070, 3440x1440 monitor with default game settings). I got the game on sale, and got more than my money's worth. I would definitely recommend it to anyone who likes this style of game.

[b]Difficulty: 2/10.

Tequila Works define su propia filosofía de trabajo como «crear cosas pequeñas, con buen gusto», ¡y vaya si lo cumplen!

Este juego es como un chupito (de tequila, no podía ser menos); es corto, deja buen sabor de boca y calidez en el corazón. Y, sobre todo, su esencia radica en el acompañamiento, en este caso el limón y la sal serían la melodía y el arte visual. Me atrevería a decir que es para paladares habituados, pues como en el caso de los licores, cada cual tiene sus gustos y, en este caso, han de gustarte los puzles.

No hay historia previa, no hay mapa, no hay diálogos. ¿Qué tenemos? Una inmersión difícil de mejorar. A pesar de estar frente a un juego en tercera persona, la forma en que está planteado hará que seamos ese personaje desde el primer instante. ¿Por qué? Debido precisamente a lo que no sabemos.

52043047.review:
RiME is a stylish and at times beautiful puzzle and collection game that has quite the sad yet fulfilling message.  Each area has a different motif or a hidden meaning and I would say try not to spoil yourself on the ending or major levels before you buy it as it kind of ruins the experience.  You will go through a nice grassy starting island to a desert cliff side to an area that is always pouring rain with water drenched rocks reflecting what little light there is.  Visually and artistically speaking RiME is a very pleasant game to look at and experience.

You control a boy as he wakes up after being thrown out of a boat, the area is friendly in how it is presented to you and really fits the whole “starting zone” type of thing that games like Mario 64 accomplished decades back.  You progress through levels by hunting through slight mazes, hitting switches and opening doors in order to progress to the next area.  The areas are somewhat open world, some zones you can run around everything that you see, back tracking all the way to the place that you started, others you are very clearly locked out of going backwards.  

I just wish that it was better optimized, from what I’ve read the game running smoothly is a serious issue even on console platforms.  You will have a major machine but you may not even be able to break 40-50 FPS maybe see 60 every so often but it is very inconsistent.  I mean inconsistent as in you’ll be seeing 50-60 then suddenly go through a tunnel and come out of the other end and suddenly you’re seeing 30 FPS!  That’s honestly one of my biggest problems with the game is that as much as I want to enjoy the story and the emotional ride it gets jarred constantly but the poor optimization.

I would say for the visuals and story alone to pick up RiME, as I’ve gotten older I’ve started to appreciate these “walking simulators” more and more (so long as they are good) but this one is far more of a 3rd person puzzle game than just a walking sim.  I ended up playing this a few times just to grab every secret, items and story fragments that the game has and each time I noticed something new (as you tend to when you revisit games that you’ve already beaten).  Just a shame about the poor optimization.
