51747755.review:
[h1]7/10[/h1]
RiME is an artistic game, made for the story and music.
- The graphics are cartoonish but very polished, they remind The Legend of Zelda: BotW.
- There's no HUD, just music, ambient sounds and nice visuals.
- The gameplay is a platform based mostly on puzzles, and they vary a little bit from start to finish but the controls sometimes are bad and not very responsive. Sometimes even if you do the puzzles right the game still doesn't count them right so you have to redo them, but it's not a big problem.
- The music is amazing, it's the most important part of this game, it helps you feel like you are truly into this game's world.
- The story's very nice, since there are no talking scenes or written collectibles, you have to understand the story by yourself (some collectibles help you understand more though).
- Even though the game is created using Unreal Engine and the graphics are very simple, this game still manages to lag even on good hardware and I saw on some forums that it's not the only game Tequila Works made that was very poorly optimised not only on PC but on consoles aswell.
- The game's not very long, 4-6 hours for the story and around 8 hours to get 100% completion, the only achievements you have to pay attention for are the collectible ones and some hidden ones which with the help of a guide are very easy. So I think the full price is not justifiable, I recommend you buy this on sale.

Now, even though the game is very beautiful, I didn't find it very captivating, actually boring at times. I would still recommend you buy this game and try it for yourself to see if you like it.
If I would have to rate the game, without any decimals, I would rate it 7/10.

51525494.review:
Quick note: Don't watch the trailer. Don't watch a review. This game must be experienced firsthand; anything else would be a disservice to yourself and to RiME. Spoil as little as possible for yourself.


Original review: Unplayable. I'd really like to play this game, it looks beautiful. But I've got slightly above the recommended specs, and turning down the graphics gets me... 24 fps. That would be okay, but there's something about the extremely unstable fps and the fov that just give me a massive headache, which means I can't enjoy what seems to be an absolutely amazing game. 

This is the first time since seven years ago when I built this PC that I've needed to overclock my GPU to play a game.

Update Mar 2020: Even with a 1080ti, the game still stutters and crashes. Also, the gameplay is really, really slow. It might be beautiful, but I'm not sure it's worth my time.

Update April 2020: Welp, this game has THOROUGHLY redeemed itself. Seems like the one crash was a fluke, because the rest of the game has been relatively smooth, although still with some occasional frame drops. But now that I've played through the whole thing, I can easily forgive everything except the fact that those on less-capable hardware (The recommended specs listed, an R9 280x, are not enough to play this game at all). It's a shame, because everyone *should* have the chance to play this game, regardless of the hardware they run. It's truly a beautiful experience. Even the backtracking that I was annoyed with earlier was mostly a fluke as well. The devs really put some thought into what the player experiences. 

I would be doing a total disservice to this game if I tried to actually explain it, but typically a review is meant to tell you whether you should buy the game or not. The answer is not unequivocally "yes." But this game is not for everybody in the same way that any other game is not for everybody. It's just that "Zelda/Tomb Raider Reboot but prettier and with a more touching and more personal story" just isn't doing this game justice.

Let me put it this way:

The Witcher makes you fight.

Nier Automata makes you think.

This game makes you feel.

(The Witness makes you bored). 

...

Well, let's say you already knew that. You know you're getting an emotional story mixed in with some puzzles and some absolutely beautiful scenery. I'm sorry that I don't have much to compare this game to. Every other game that I can think of just hits different. This game is meditative. There's no fighting. There's next to no action. Its pacing is most similar to the Tomb Raider reboots, but TR_r feels absolutely empty by comparison. I can't remember the last time I played a game where the story felt this fulfulling, but I can't actually explain why without totally ruining the game for you.

51501228.review:
[h1]ICO 1.5[/h1]

Nota: [b]8/10[/b]

51453247.review:
Está muy bien este "RiME", un juego de exploración, plataformas y puzles, todo envuelto en ese mundo mágico y lleno de color.

La historia está bien, jugando con el misterio hasta el final, quizás sea algo ambigua si no te paras mucho a explorar o dar significado a la narrativa visual, aun así el juego quiere dar un mensaje y logra su cometido.

En cuanto a gráficos pues ya veis, no es un portento pero si que logra crear un mundo muy vistoso y llamativo, al que dan ganas de explorar y que se siente un personaje más de la historia, las animaciones y las físicas están bien logradas así como el juego de luces y sombras, visualmente es una delicia.

La banda sonora también está muy bien cuando la tenemos y acompaña sobretodo en los puntos importantes de la historia, en otros momentos solo escucharemos sonido ambiental que también ayuda a reflejar y potenciar la soledad del mundo que nos rodea.

En cuanto a los puzles y el plataformeo pues cumplen, los obstáculos que nos iremos encontrando suelen ser sencillos de superar, dejando claro el camino a seguir o el objetivo del puzle que estemos haciendo, esto sumado a una recogida de ciertos objetos de forma fastfood, y algunas zonas de ensayo y error suman las mecánicas principales del juego.

El contenido del juego es enorme, la historia principal sin pararte mucho ya son unas 8 horas, pero es que el juego esta plagado de coleccionables y de caminos ocultos, la isla se vuelve un laberinto y por cada zona bien explorada se recompensa con algún objeto opcional o pequeñas dosis de lore, se nota que el juego pese a tener una historia muy decente se ha centrado mucho en la exploración y en dar vida al mundo que nos presenta.

En conclusión RiME es un buen juego, largo, interesante, bonito, con contenido, pero... no es perfecto, ya que quizás su ultimo tramo se puede hacer algo pesado, los puzles aunque están bien son algo repetitivos y nada que no hayamos visto en otros títulos similares, la historia aunque interesante es tan ambigua en ciertos puntos que no logras conectar todas las pistas, el contenido opcional es tan gigantesco que te da miedo dar dos pasos por si te dejas cualquier rincón sin explorar, algunos saltos, plataformas y animaciones podrían estar mas pulidas...  Pero en conjunto es un juego muy recomendable y todo un orgullo que sea producto nacional, si te llama mínimamente la atención,hazte con el. Vale la pena.

51138562.review: The last decade has seen a wealth of stylistic games able to pull at the emotional sensitivities of their players, with the likes of Journey,Abzu, Firewatch, Edith, Aer and Brothers to name but a few. And Rime is a similar, if not slightly inferior, experience. Fortified by the gorgeous stylized partially toon-shaded visuals and beautiful musical accompaniment,  Rime is able to tap into some real emotion as the game progresses and the brief snippets, glimpses and allusions begin to piece themselves together to give the full gravity of the adventure. It left me feeling something... although I'm not quite sure what that something is. I do know it was a worthwhile six hours of my life. If it comes up on a steam sale, I recommend giving it a go.

51123487.review:
This game is stunning. That is the first impression I got. And by that, I don't mean that the graphics are great - they aren't - but that the game is aesthetically beautiful. And not just the graphics, but the subject matter, the approach, the way the story is told, everything has a deeper layer of beauty to it that makes it all the more poignant and hard to ignore.

The game walks in the footsteps of ICO, there is no denying that. But instead of looming castles, solemn keeps and forlorn crags, you find yourself on a sunlit island with a Mediterranean climate. It might not come as a surprise that the studio is from Spain. White temple-like structures, green grass, blue sky along with a flora and fauna make the game a pleasure to play, the color palette is one of the cleanest and most pleasing out of any game I can think of. How the time of day is shown is better than any other game I've ever played; at first I thought I was imagining it, that the light had changed, but then it really did go from dusk into night, and then into a new morning, all with their own distinct light and colors. Truly amazing.

The story is for the greater part of the game a mystery, told in glimpses and fragmentary flashbacks. There is no dialogue (like ICO) and no combat, only exploration and puzzle solving, yet the game manages to continue to grip your attention without becoming boring or repetitive. The game does get darker, and the environments change, yet the clean, beautiful, crisp colors don't go away even when you descend into gloomier parts.

It is without a doubt a game that will bore some, but going into it not knowing anything about it (which is always the best way) will provide you with an amazing experience if you go all the way to the end - and I cannot stress this enough, you HAVE to go all the way to the end. The conclusion makes RiME what it is.

All in all, it's a visually and emotionally amazing game in a genre that is very sparse.
90/100

51002560.review: I'm marking this as a negative review while in fact it is more of a neutral review. It has positives as well as negatives that drag it down from being a game up there with Journey and Abzu. Upon experiencing the first hour or so the game's world which is a fantasy island filled with magical ruins and mystical spirits and it lures you into this false sense of what the story is about. It's not an enclosed fantasy like Journey with a simplified 3 act story. The final act of the story pulled a unexpected and rather rushed subversion of the narrative that had been going thus far and ultimately left a very sour taste in my mouth afterword. It is not a fantasy, but rather a metaphorical story pertaining to the 5 stages of grief, something I wish I had known going in. And I'm fine with sad/melancholy stories, I've played What Remains of Edith Finch and SOMA. But don't give me a plate of ham and later tell me it was someone's pet pot-bellied pig. Other than that, the mechanics are a bit too simple, leading to bland platforming. The level design and art is fantastic. The music, beautiful. The story, disappointing, which, sadly is the core of the game.

50949923.review:
You already see my opinion from the red thumbs down, and on a page of nearly universal acclaim, you might be willing to just assume I'm some disgruntled gamer and sweep on past.

Don't do that. This game is not for everyone, and it certainly isn't for me. Let's pick it apart by each of the features it touts as its selling points. At each moment, I'll compare it to The Witness, which is also a puzzle game featuring exploration of a mysterious island and secrets galore.

Exploration: The main point to exploring this game is to find secrets, which I'll talk about later, so I'll use this space to talk about the game's movement. First off, this game is linear. There's 'exploration' in the sense that you can step off of the obvious main path to find some secrets, but aside from that the game railroads you in a straight line forwards. Worse still is that your character moves so abysmally slow that I felt punished for exploring, in that it took so long to reach the end of a branch to see if there was a secret there. This game is desperately in need of a sprint key, and exploration feels more like a chore due to how the slow movement grinds away at you. Compare it to The Witness, which has a sprint key that moves you inhumanly fast across the landscape. A good speed in my opinion.

Puzzles: They were easy. Not just 'yeah i get this' easy, but 'why are they wasting my time with this' easy. In the first 100 minutes, I didn't find a single puzzle that I had to think for. Most were simple enough that I understood the solution from the first moment I saw them, and the few that weren't only took a few seconds thought to figure out what a new piece did. You can carry a game on the strength of good puzzles. The Witness, as a game, is exclusively about puzzles, but that ties into the game's deeper philosophy. In Rime, the puzzles were not only simple, they felt disconnected from the game itself. They were barriers barring progress and nothing else.

Find Secrets: This is where the game really fell flat for me. I'm a sucker for good secrets, and the ones I found in Rime just... aren't. There are 4 different kinds of secrets (that I found. there's 6 sections on the extras screen.) You can find new outfits, little wooden dolls, fragments of coins/seals, and conch shells that play a lullaby. The seals and dolls are, at first blush, literally useless, The outfits are... neat? But not a satisfying reward given the time it takes to find them. And the lullaby was... eh. It's a thing that exists. Maybe it has some deeper meaning once you put the entire song together. Again, let's compare to The Witness. Secrets take two forms; usb sticks that hold philosophical quotes and excerpts- usually about knowledge, learning, and the pursuit of both- and optional perspective puzzles, where the secret is an additional puzzle about finding the right place to stand, the right perspective to look from. Each USB, each philosophical quote, again, ties into the game's theme, while the bonus puzzles are exactly that; bonus puzzles. They have literally no purpose, except that they exist to be solved, and The Witness, as a game, is about taking enjoyment in that intellectual pursuit of knowledge and conquering obstacles. 

Be Enchanted: I'll give the game credit here, it is beautiful and atmospheric. The soundtrack is pleasant, the graphics are stunning, and the environments you explore are rich and colorful. This game has the visual design down scratch, but at the end of the day, it's still a video game, and IMO if your main selling point for a game is visual appeal, why not just make it a movie?

TL:DR Painfully slow movement makes exploration a chore, and the secrets you find while exploring didn't seem to have a payoff that was worth exploring for. The puzzles were simple and lackluster, and while the game's beautiful, there's not enough -game- in it to justify a 30$ price tag.

If you want a pleasant stroll around the island with some light puzzling, maybe grab this on sale, but I wouldn't pay more than 10$ for it, and even that's a stretch.

P.s. People say the ending is fantastic and the game makes way more sense in retrospect, but I don't feel like trudging for 8 hours. Did I mention the game's that long? Some people call that short, but it's longer than I wanted to spend trudging on a linear path.

50834888.review:
Bonito y emotivo, pero nada original juego de puzzles y aventuras

- Historia: el juego trata claramente las fases del duelo de forma correcta. Sin embargo, el final es bastante predecible y le quita gracia a prácticamente toda la campaña, ya que si eres avispado desde el primer nivel sabrás, como digo, el final. 
- Gráficos y sonido: bonitos gráficos y banda sonora emotiva, sin grandes alardes. La optimización del título es pésima, con una RX 580 de 8gb he tenido que poner varios ajustes en medio para que el juego tirara a 60fps, simplemente ridículo.
- Jugabilidad: el título es bastante lineal y los puzzles son sencillísimos. No hay ninguno realmente inspirado y que te sorprenda por su originalidad. No son muy variados.
- Originalidad: aquí encuentro uno de los principales puntos negativos, y es que si habéis jugado a cualquier obra de Fumito Ueda veréis que la inspiración raya en el plagio, sobre todo con "The Last Guardian". Todo el rato tenía la sensación de que ya había jugado a lo mismo, pero más grande y mejor. 
- Duración: entre seis y ocho horas la campaña. Puede llegar a doce si quieres conseguir los coleccionables, pero no hay ninguna razón para ello ya que no aportan absolutamente nada a la historia, están muy desaprovechados.

En resumen, un título sencillo, bonito y emotivo que no ha venido a aportar nada al mundo del videojuego. Sus puzzles son muy fáciles, los coleccionables no te inspiran lo más mínimo a conseguirlos y si has jugado a otros títulos como el mencionado The Last Guardian vas a tener una molesta sensación de deja vu constante. No puedo recomendarlo. 

Nota: 5/10

50679234.review:
Although I eventually decided to "recommend" this game, I would only purchase it if it's on sale or if you're a diehard puzzle-game fan who doesn't mind some unfortunate technical problems. 

First, if you like atmospheric puzzle games like ICO, the Talos Principle, or The Last Guardian, then you will find a lot to like in Rime. Although it doesn't approach the greatness of the aforementioned, it does hold its own pretty well.  The developers nailed the atmosphere in this game with amazing music, vibrant visuals, great sound effects, and a touching story that will have you interested in playing until the end (I finished the game in 4 hours, although I did not worry about the collectibles and other extras). 

That said, the game suffers from poor optimization, creating a laggy experience with large frame drops in many areas.  Despite running a fast rig that can max out most AAA titles, I had to suffer through dips down into the 20fps range in many parts of the game.  This ruined much of the immersion that a game like this requires to succeed.  There are also some frustrating control issues, specifically when scaling walls and having to leap between ledges.  These might seem like small flaws, but when the entire game is based around atmosphere and platform-intensive puzzle solving, these flaws add up to a frustrating experience pretty quick.

All in all, Rime is a decent puzzle game that is worth playing through once if you have any interest at all in emotional puzzle games like these. If not, then the juice probably isn't worth the squeeze, and your time and money are better spent elsewhere.

50609345.review:
No spoilers ahead.

TL;DR: The game's proficient and quite pretty, but feels a bit generic and is too pricey and long for its purposes. Gameplay by itself is ok at best. Buy at a discount.

The visual presentation is, unsurprisingly, one of the better parts of RiMe. It doesn't, however, really stand out from the genre it populates - visually pleasing adventure games with gameplay mechanics that feel a bit like formalities. Some of the "woah, that looks cool" moments feel a bit too scripted and the overall aesthetic isn't particularly distinctive, but it's all quite serviceable. Maybe open exploration would give more weight, catharsis and variability to the visual experience of the game.

The music is decent, but not especially memorable or interesting. The puzzles are pretty generic.

The game (and what it wants to communicate) would've been better served by being pricing it at around 20 € and cutting some of the content. Games like this - pretty adventures with some form of a meta-narrative - shouldn't, in my estimation, cost 40 € and/or last as long as RiME does. The gameplay just isn't engaging or distinctive enough to not overstay its welcome, especially since the game is a linear adventure without that much significant exploration. The underlying narrative is a decent one, but also isn't served that well by the length of the game. 

The game is still an enjoyable one for the most part and I do recommend picking it up if you're into the genre, but you should definitely wait for it to go on sale instead of dishing out the listed price.

50499020.review:
Imagine a banquet laid out in front of you. Roast meats, steamed veggies, various bottles of  sparkling drinks and your favourite desserts. It a looks wonderful and smells delicious so you start to dig in. As you're almost half-way through the meal you start to notice that the meats are fully cooked, the veggies are soggy from being left steaming for too long, the bottles of drinks are flat rather than bubbly and the desserts are starting to go sour or stale. This meal is just like RIME.

As first, you look at the game and it looks really well polished. The music and ambience is stirring and initially the world seems vibrant and interesting. The animations on the character is top-notch and this is something that the game maintains throughout as each character is packed with personality and emotion. Early puzzles are varied and clearly give some nods to Legend of Zelda in that they are strictly logic based and visual clues prevent the need for referring to online guides or having written instructions. With occasional exceptions each puzzle can be solved by exploring the nearby area and you can often see the objective but need to figure out how to achieve it. However.. all of this begins to fall apart after the 2nd level. The game starts to degenerate into tedious platforming sections, lots of running between areas just to trigger buttons or events and becomes progressively more linear as you feel funnelled through one area to another when earlier in the game you had some freedom to explore.

RiME is a prime example of developers running out of ideas and not having a good quality assurance process. You can see that they started off strong and then let the remaining 2/3 of the game become extremely mundane and tedious. The musical scores are amazing in once instance and utterly forgettable the next. Some parts of the game have background music that is extremely quiet and is drowned out by the ambience and sound effects leading to parts of the game feeling very empty and unfinished. This mixture of great gameplay and music alongside utterly tedious gameplay and mundane music just makes the latter seem so much worse as RiME's quality becomes like a patchwork quilt

There was an attempt at a storyline here, quite clearly the devs started to lean into the 'this is art' angle to the point that they forgot it was supposed to be a game. I have played other games which dealt with abstract concepts portrayed via gameplay but RiME fell short by not leaning into the symbolism that is supposed to be telling the story and instead depending upon hidden collectables to actually tell the story.  If you don't find any of these you'll get to the end and suddenly be faced with a 'twist' which makes no sense. Again this patchwork quilt effect whereby the gameplay is detached from the story the developers wanted to tell.

As much as the 1st third of the game is worth seeing, I simply cannot make that the justification for recommending the game. RiME needed to go back to the drawing board, cook for a little longer with the QA teams and then finally be released but as it stands it simply isn't a worthwhile experience and with a playtime of only 7hrs it isn't even good value for money.

50429333.review:
I'm not sure what I was expecting from RIME, I was drawn in by its aesthetics and the vague knowledge that it had a focus on exploration, I guess I was expecting a fairly basic platformer with pretty visuals and not a lot else. I'm pleased to say it turned out to be more.

You play a young boy who wakes up on a mysterious isle after a terrible storm, Its a beautiful environment to explore and straight off the bat you have some freedom to explore, theres no real tutorial to be seen but the overall controls of the game a simple and easy to get to grips with as you explore. The world isn't vast and open so theres no chance of wandering off and getting lost but the island is large enough to have multiple side areas with various collectables hidden about the place rewarding the player who looks around and maybe notices a climbable wall or cliff or small opening, theres more to the collectables than just achievements too unlockable art hints at lore, and there are music and costumes to find and unlock as well encouraging you to explore and rewarding you for taking your time to take in this world.

Now as to the gameplay its fairly basic you roam about the world heading for landmarks (towers or light pillars) scattered about the map, its actually a good way to give direction to players as rather than railroad them you guide them more naturally toward points of interest. Within each landmark will be some sort of platforming challenge or puzzle, personally I found none of these difficult and was about to make swift progress (your mileage may vary) between stops to explore and find hidden loot. In addition to these minor puzzles there is generally an overarching theme to each area/world you visit, one might add in a flying monster that will attack you if stay out in the open too long, another will have non-logical layouts (corridors fold back on each other or connect in impossible ways making navigation a challenge), combine all this with beautiful art and sold visual themes for each area and its a joy to travel through this world.

But the last part of the game is of course the story, its told entirely without words, through the world and brief flashbacks between worlds, each world has a theme, something that the title of chapter gives away, in fact the chapter titles give away abit too much so I would say avoid any guides on your first playthrough its easy enough and you unlock a chapter select if you want to go back and do achievements later. The story is bittersweet and best just experienced so I'll leave it at that.

Overall RIME is a great time, a little on the short side but still worth the price especially on sale, give it try.

50415761.review:

50400518.review:
RiME is a little adventure game that really surpassed my expectations. Beautiful and inspiring sound track, interesting puzzles, stunning graphics and a thought provoking story.

Before I begin, I will stress that this game takes TIME. The story has a very slow pace and there is no real context given to the player at the beginning of the game. Therefore, the puzzles you complete and the setting can seem a bit .. strange. But all will be explained and believe me, it is worth the wait! Only until about halfway through the game did I gain any sort of inclination as to what I was actually doing and what it had to do with anything, but nevertheless, the quest to find answers is the purpose of the game and it definitely kept me wanting to discover more.

RiME encompasses many different settings and does so beautifully, from bright and sunny to dark and melancholy. Each scene is well crafted and perfectly utilises light to encapsulate the emotion it intended (especially the last few scenes). It also includes many underwater locations which were one of my favourite environments due to the gorgeous graphics. The majority of the playtime for this game is spent like a platformer, jumping from ledge to ledge and completing a task or puzzle.

As the game is tagged, it is a puzzle game, and although there is nothing too difficult, there are many aspects to the puzzles which keep things interesting. Despite this, the focus and I believe, strong point of the game is definitely its adventure filled world and subsequent story behind it all. Possibly due to this focus, the developers have been quite forgiving and in the rare chance that you actually do die from the handful of baddies who have the capacity to kill you; you will re-spawn very close to where you died and simply just pick up where you left off. 

 As a bit of an extra, you can stray away from main objectives which are conveyed to the player by following a helpful fox and find tonnes of collectables. This also ticks the box for collectors, or those looking for a second play-through. 

Unfortunately, RiME is a victim of very noticeable frame drops. In a select few scenes it is extremely laggy for no apparent reason and it can only be overcome by simply moving to the next scene. This isn't a deal breaker for me but it certainly wasn't fun and did take away from my experience, considering the heavy immersive focus that the game intended.

Lastly, the price tag. Yes the $AU40 price tag seems substantially high for a short (4-7 hour game, depending on collectables). But before I become too pedantic, RiME is a game that is repeatedly bundled together with other games and also heavily discounted on many popular sites for as little as $4. With that in mind, it is hard to fault RiME as it incorporates everything an adventure lover looks for. Although it is difficult to truly describe what this game is about without unveiling any spoilers, I can definitely recommend this to fellow adventure lovers. Don't overlook this little hidden gem like I did, its absolutely worth your time.

If you liked this review, please follow my curator page for more: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34936724/

50224232.review:
"I wish they'd add a neutral review option... like a sideways hand." - my friend on discord.

I had a decently positive experience with this, but I still can't really recommend it. It kinda peaks in the first hour and a half and maybe again in the last 30 minutes. The game is slow, the puzzles are stupid simple, and the platforming is imprecise to a huge fault. That last part is pretty important, because nothing ruins the mood quicker than reaching the end of a platforming section and instead of jumping up, the character jumps 4 stories to his death. Shame, since the mood and visuals are easily the best thing this game has going for it.

The first couple of chapters are really great. You get to run around these beautiful, open locations. It feels like everywhere you go there's something cool to see (architecture, animals, collectibles). But starting in the second chapter, the game begins to feel more linear, mostly due to the addition of a mechanic that actively prevents you from anything other than making a beeline from enclosed location to enclosed location. The rest of the game progresses in the same kind of way, creating this upside down pyramid of limitation on how far you can explore. By the end of the game, you'll literally be running a circular maze to do puzzles. Understand that there is a thematic reason for this progression, but it kind of drags a lot of the fundamental problems with this game into the spotlight.

Outside of visiting a bunch of cool locations, there really isn't that much to do. The puzzles are easy and the platforming is restrictive. Huge missed opportunity with the vocalize command, since its really only used to initiate cutscenes and solve puzzles (read: open doors). Oh yeah, sometimes you can sing along with the soundtrack. No where in the game is it more than just 'something you can do.'

All in all, I found the first couple of chapters delivered an amazing sense of exploration and wonder, but the game lost a lot of its luster once every location became a bunch of hallways. Recommended only if you have the patience to sit through the slow sections to get to some great visuals.

This review isn't finished lol. I'll update this review later with what I thought about the story once something has coagulated into coherency (I didn't love it).

50222447.review:
[b]TL;DR[/b]
After a painful beginning to what I thought would be an underwhelming experience, RiME really shocked me with how deep its story was willing to go. The problems I had with the game were replaced with a wonderfully gentle ride through heaven, and I can't express enough how shocking it was how much I ended up loving this game. The puzzles, the graphics, the story all made for an experience so incredible it was worth the confusing introduction.

[table]
   [tr]
      [th]Area of Game[/th]
      [th]Score[/th]
   [/tr]

   [tr]
      [td]Gameplay[/td]
      [td]22/25[/td]
   [/tr]

   [tr]
      [td]Visuals[/td]
      [td]24/25[/td]
   [/tr]

   [tr]
      [td]Music/Sound[/td]
      [td]24/25[/td]
   [/tr]

   [tr]
      [td]Story/Characters[/td]
      [td]25/25[/td]
   [/tr]

   [tr]
      [td]Verdict[/td]
      [td]95/100[/td]
   [/tr]
[/table]

If you told me 30 minutes into this game that I would fall in love with RiME and it would end up being one of my favorite games of all time, I probably would have laughed. I could have given an infinite amount of reasons why I wouldn't recommend this: it was glitchy, boring, a walking simulator, and the puzzles had no challenge to them. Let me be clear about this: I HATED playing this game for the first hour of it, but a lot of my complaints slowly... disappeared as I progressed through the game.

Before buying this game, I didn't know much about it. All I knew was the graphics reminded me of Breath of the Wild, and it was a puzzle game with very bright colors. I didn't bother to look further into it before buying because it was on sale for $5 and just thought of it as a quick buy. I had very low expectations before going in, and they were pretty much met with the beginning. I had trouble with the controls, the story seemed slow and stereotypical with the [spoiler]amnesia[/spoiler] and such. The music and visuals were good from the start, though.

As I got further and further in, my opinion slowly changed. I started to enjoy the puzzles more after getting the hang of the controls, and the story took turns I really didn't expect. [spoiler]The ending was absolutely heartbreaking, and wrapped up the story in a perfect way.[/spoiler]

Don't ignore this game. It will impact you in a way no other game will.

Rime is a lovely fist person exploration game with some puzzle solving.  The story is good, but not great.  What I enjoyed most was having the ability to explore chapter by chapter, without having to worry about a huge open world.  Some people don't like collectibles, but I do and I enjoyed that part of it as well.  I also liked that once you completed the game, you could go back into each chapter and pick up anything you missed.   Best of all, it has achievements that are not ridiculously hard to get, but do require a bit of work.  Just the right balance, I think.

Issues:
 I had trouble using my 360 controller with the game -- some days it would work, the next day no.  

When I had to use keyboard/mouse the view would go out of bounds of the area you were in, especially when you were near a wall or cliff face, making it impossible to see.

The perspective was kind of wonky at times, but not enough to make it unplayable.

Overall a great game, that I would play again.

Having just finished this game, I almost feel like I am letting go of a good friend. Which I suppose the game devs kinda did lead me through just that sort of process. After all, this is a game about the grief associated with loss.
This was a wonderful puzzle game, but it lacks much replay value. Despite that though, I am really glad I got it. I may never play it again, but I believe I will always remember the emotional and mysterious story that they unfolded for me. I was fully absorbed throughout the process. I especially appreciated all of the thoughtful hidden extras I could go look for, or I could ignore if I wanted to stick to the story of the game without distraction. 
Overarching the rest is the wonderful artistry and vista views made the game a complete winner for me.

50164602.review:
I was pleasantly surprised by this game.

I tend to avoid games that are too open ended/minimalist as I don't really like to walk around trying to find what to do next. But this game does a good job funneling you towards your next puzzle/objective without putting a huge arrow on the screen. I always found what I should be doing next within a minute or two.

The puzzles are mildly challenging but not frustrating. There were maybe 3-4 of points where I was stuck for 10 minutes, but the solutions were always obvious in retrospect. I only truly got stuck at one point and it turned out that it was just an issue of screen brightness (I couldn't see a ledge that was supposed to be obvious). I never needed to stop and look up a guide to proceed.

The world & story are abstract but it avoids feeling too pretentious. It's a sad tale that resonates strongly with me due to very recent events in my personal life.

I picked this up on sale and it was well worth the money.

50142548.review:
Similar to the game [i]AER[/i] which I just gave a little review to, this game, [i]RiME[/i], is also an exploration-based platformer with puzzles, all wrapped up with artistic design. However, [i]RiME[/i] is a much longer game, with more variety in its areas and types of puzzles. Both games have some fantasy land you are in, along with some mystic themes, where you are left to figure out what is happening. The difference there is that [i]AER[/i] had lore via text and a few NPCs, whereas [i]RiME[/i] has no text or dialogue at all, to my recollection. Nevertheless, I would say that [i]RiME[/i]'s story is much quicker to realize by the time you see the ending moments, and it had a much heavier impact on me.

Anyway, I am not quite good at reviewing artistic games like these, because there is usually minimalism in the plot design (or at least for most of the game), thus I can't really discuss that. And they tend to be games where you simply navigate and progress, solving puzzles. [i]RiME[/i] is broken up into 5 sections, each with a different environment that adds onto the puzzles you have been doing, and at some points, even adds enemies for you to avoid or "defeat" in a particular way.

In the end, these types of games are mainly focused on the journey that is going on and what everything means. If you are looking for something like that, then give this one a try.

50116768.review:
7.5/10 . Relatively simple "adventure" gameplay bolsters a story that manages to be vague without being esoteric, and which becomes increasingly understandable as the ending approaches.

Presentation: The game looks good. The art design isn't technically impressive, but it's stylistically good. The music is really, really good. The game seems a little poorly optimized, in that my Vega 56 was humming rather loudly the entire time on Ultra at 1440p (with TSAA), but it was 60 FPS throughout the game as I could tell.

Mechanics: The gameplay of Rime is fairly basic. You can run around, jump, roll, interact with things, or yell. I never encountered a use for rolling, but the others get plenty of use. You primarily solve environmental puzzles and do light platforming. Neither is difficult, but that's not really the focus of this game. There are collectibles scattered throughout the world that you can find; most are meaningless, but at least one is related to the game's story.

Story: You play as a little boy in a world with no other people, there're no voiced lines, you have an animal friend. I didn't really have any clue what was going on until maybe an hour before the end, and even now there are elements I'm unsure of. As I mentioned when talking about the mechanics, there's one set of collectibles which seems to describe the game's story, and after the game's finished there's a pretty big hint in the Main Menu, but I wasn't able to find all of the former, and even with the latter as mentioned there are still things I'm curious about. Overall I think it broaches a meaningful subject in an interesting way.

Worth pointing out: I finished this in 5 hours. Is this worth $30? H*ll no. $15? Heck no. $10? If you're desperate for a game to play. $5? Yes.

50016727.review:
A compelling game straight off the mark that I managed to complete in 10 hours.  There were a ton of collectibles I didn’t collect and a ton of cheevos I didn’t cheev, so maybe you can get more out of this game.  At my playtime I would consider Rime a tad on the expensive side but it has been bundled and rebundled and goes on sale often.  It is an adventure platformer game featuring a great story.  Wait for a sale if your wallet can’t handle the price tag.  If you can't handle the price tag then pick up AER Memories of Old for the time being as it shares a lot of qualities with this game.
_______________________

PROS  
+ Beautiful art style.  Everything is richly coloured and detailed but at the same time a bit blocky.    
+ The soundtrack is amazing.  There are very emotional swelling pieces of music throughout the game that add a whole new level of detail to the experience.
+ Story.  Without ever saying a word Rime gives us an amazing story in great detail.  It uses powerful visuals, music and level design to push forward its narrative.
+ Excellent level design on the whole.  It is a very corridor exploration game when it is ushering you into the next area or trying to get on with the story but there are also some tougher puzzles that will have you needing some time to think how to progress.
+The sounds.  All the sounds in the game feel very real and match the environment. Everything from the waves crashing onto the beach, the thunder, the slap of your bare feet on sand or stone to the seagulls screetching are organic and sound amazing.
________________________

CONS
- Some parts of the game drag out a bit too long for me.  
- Controls can be a bit frustrating, especially in some of the platforming parts.
________________________

I’m not going to spoil Rime in any way.  It is a game with a really strong story where you are firmly in the shoes of the protagonist and are discovering this strange world exactly as he is.  It reminds me a lot of the old school Tomb Raider games where we find ourselves in self-contained areas that we have to traverse and pull levers in order to advance.  Rime has a ton of places to explore and a tons of screenshots waiting to be taken.  If you want to delve into a world that is (mostly) non-threatening and live out a story then you need Rime in your library.

49999883.review:
I was initially referred to this game by people on the Quern and The Witness game forums who were comparing it to those games and putting all three into the 'Mystlike' category; now that I've played the thing I can say that's an inaccurate comparison as while the game has puzzles in it and is set on an island there isn't much else about it that is particularly Myst-like. Nonetheless, I wanted to give the game the chance to stand on its own merits irrespective of what other people are advertising it as... and there are still quite a few problems with it.

* The puzzles are not the Myst-type point-and-click puzzles but the sort from Portal or Talos Principle which involve picking up and moving around different objects with the 'use' key. I personally prefer the Myst style, but irrespective of that the puzzles here are simpler and not especially challenging.
* There also weren't very many of them. In fact, the world seems 'larger' than it needs to be, with a lot of time spent just getting from one place to another which is not helped by how slow your top speed is. The game is arguably more of a platformer than a puzzle game, but the platforming is also pretty straightforward and isn't very satisfying: it's always pretty clear where to go, and your movement is pretty restricted; it doesn't feel nimble and quick the way, say, the Sly Cooper games did. 
* As it progresses the game attempts to get increasingly symbolic and 'psychological', but it's not especially compelling or even really all that important. There really wasn't a lot *to* the game looking back; I was able to power through it in a little under a day.

If you came here looking for a Myst-like "Island Puzzle" game you are better off playing The Witness, Quern, or even Talos Principle; even if that's not what you were specifically expecting I can't say I'd recommend it unless the game is expanded in the future to be less full of itself and more full of actual content.

49938116.review:
[url=https://youtu.be/JqYknuRXG78][b]Video review[/b][/url]

[h1]Aaaah![/h1]

This game really surprised me. I didn’t expect much, I expected a half assed attempt at a walking simulator but I’ve a great platformer/puzzle game with amazing art, soundtrack and story.

You wake up on the beach not knowing what happened and start your journey. At first you take your time to admire the scenery because this game is really beautiful. Simplistic cell-shaded graphics was a good choice for artistic design. There’s also no hud so nothing get in a way and can fully immerse in the world.
The story is really sad in this one, it’s beautiful but when you realize what’s happening you understand how sad the story really is.

Gameplay is pretty basic. You run around in an open environment and explore every corner of it. Although it’s not necessary to explore everything, I highly suggest you do that. You progress the game by solving puzzles and collecting some items. Puzzles are not too hard so they don’t break the flow of the game. This is really more of a narrative game than puzzle, so difficult puzzles would just ruin the experience.

Every level is different and represents something else. You’ll climbing, uncovering secrets, avoid monsters, run, jump and yell. Yes there’s a lot of yelling. You interact with thing by yelling. There’s also a cute friendly fox who will guide you through the levels.
The only downsides I notices are that camera angles sometimes are annoying and climbing controls could be better.

Graphically the game looks stunning. The visual are very clean and minimalistic from the first sight, but there’s so much detail everywhere. Levels are very well crafted. Overall graphics are a work of art. Although the performance can be little disappointing. I don’t know why this runs worse than AC origins. I had to lower some settings to get 60fps and even then I experience big fps drops. Optimization is not very good.

Soundtrack just adds another layer of awesomeness to this game. It fits the aesthetics of the game very well and makes it so much better.

I recommend this game for those who enjoys good stories, well balanced gameplay and beautiful visuals. Don’t miss this game.

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Beautiful graphics
[*]Great sound design
[*]Sad story
[*]Balanced gameplay
[*]Many different locations
[/list]
[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]Performance could be better
[/list]

Since I was streaming, I skipped many of the collectibles. Luckily, the game has a great menu for selecting previous stages to acquire what I missed so if I ever go back to try to 100%, I don't have to replay it all from the beginning.

49763950.review:
Reviews for Rime seem mostly mixed. Some think it's a walking simulator. Others think it's all bling no ding.

For me personally, Rime was as captivating and enchanting as some of the more well known titles such as Abzu and Shadow of the Colossus, similarly, Journey too.  

Rim is an interesting game in that yes, most puzzles are easily solvable, the story is a bit vague, and the gameplay is limited, but behind these rather minor concerns, you have an extremely vibrant, absolutely extravagantly designed game. The visuals are utterly astounding, some of the best, most timeless art style's paired with an absolutely phenomenal soundtrack that makes you weep and soar in all the right moments. 

I had an absolute blast playing this game. I had my fair share of frustration with certain aspects, but the pro's here absolutely outweighed the cons for me. Not many games make me genuinely cry. Kudos to Tequila Works for making such a mesmerising, and truly beautiful narrative that I could lose myself in for some of the most emotional 6 hours I've had in a while. Truly, thank you.

Pro's:

Timeless, bright and diverse art style reminiscent of the Wind Waker days.
Truly captivating and wonderful soundtrack that can and does take you on an adventure of its own.
Easy control scheme with some interesting game elements.
Vague, but decipherable story with heavy themes and strong emotional appeal.
A good dose of wonder and mystery as you unravel said story to unveil the meanings and symbolism. 
Not a 'hold your hand' styled game, get yourself out there and learn for yourself!
Well balanced puzzles that promote progress and a little thought without stopping you dead in your tracks long enough to get flustered.
Diverse environments to experience and explore, never feeling dull.

Cons: 

Though I listed this as a pro, it can also be a con. Puzzles are relatively easy, some more intermediate and even hard puzzles requiring multiple aspects of gameplay, such as the use of lights and your ability to create them would have been a bonus here.
Missable collectables create the need  for a rerun which ultimately detracts from the purity of a one time run, sadly diminishing  the emotional weight.
Somewhat slow character movement may prove annoying at times.
Steep price point for a standard 4-6 hour experience, and a 6-8 hour experience if you want to 100% it. Also expensive when considering the soundtrack is not included.


Honestly can't find much to fault with this game. I had a wonderful experience, and I hope you do too.

9/10

49761107.review:
I wasn't expecting much from this game other than it looking really pretty but its more than just that. I strongly recommend this game to anyone wanting a relaxing and heartfelt story, you can tell this game was a labour of love. 

If you like relaxing puzzle adventure games then you'll most likely enjoy RiME. There is no dialogue, combat, health or even text (apart from button prompts) in this game so it ends up just being a relaxing experience which you're supposed to unwind and take at your own leisure. The only two things you can really do in this game is walk around and interact with things, which you'll be doing a lot to solve puzzles and discover collectables. If that doesn't sound appealing then it might not be for you.

The visuals of the game is absolutely stunning in my opinion as it uses shape and form to really help the environments and structures pop, add on top of that great colour and lighting and you have some amazing looking levels that you can just stare at for hours. The use of reflections in the metals and the shaders for the water look fantastic too. I honestly can't get enough of the visuals of this game!

The soundtrack is phenomenal and you owe it to yourself to listen to it. If you love the Ghibli soundtracks then this will blow you away. During gameplay it uses audio cues and blends them with the music to help make certain moments really stand out and it really adds to the feelings you'll be experiencing throughout.

Performance wise the game is mostly great, I noticed there was a huge performance hit with SSAA turned on, no matter what other settings you changed (im running a RTX 2070 and i7 7700k) it would always dip below 60fps. Turning it down to TXAA or FXAA will increase performance greatly. Other than that it ran great for me!

Oh and the game has native support for 21:9! Which is a huge plus for me.

Rime es un juego de puzzles y plataformas donde controlaremos a un niño perdido en una isla, que irá descubriendo los secretos que oculta, pasando por zonas áridas, bosques o incluso ruinas.
LO BUENO:
- El gran punto a favor y lo más destacable del juego es su calidad artística. Los escenarios son putamente preciosos, y siempre te quedarás mirándolos y apreciando el escenario.
- La banda sonora es correcta, pero logra encajar perfectamente con todos los momentos del juego.
- Las animaciones están muy trabajadas: Cómo baja una ladera, la forma de rodar, la forma de correr... Todos los movimientos están muy logrados.
- La historia no parece ser gran cosa y puede parecer apenas inexistente, pero todo cobra sentido a medida que va terminando el juego, con un gran final.
LO MALO:
- En un juego donde destacan las plataformas puede ser bastante frustrante que algunos saltos no los haga el personaje de forma correcta, o que tengas que pasar sí o sí por un saliente específico, y no medio metro mas a la derecha. Además, muchas veces el personaje se quedará trabado en esquinas o con algún objeto aunque no lo estés ni siquiera rozando, lo que supongo que será un fallo con las áreas de colisión.
- Los puzzles no son para nada complicados. Quiero entender que no buscan lastrar la aventura o atascar al jugador, pero sí que habría agradecido un par de puzzles que tuvieran algo más de complejidad.
- Aunque el juego intenta que conectes con él, yo no he logrado sentirme unido al personaje y apenas he logrado empatizar (a excepción de un par de momentos).
- Durante gran parte del juego se me ha hecho divertido el juego, pero tengo que decir una cosa: El tercer nivel es, en mi opinión, innecesariamente largo, y una zona que me terminó aburriendo a partir de la segunda mitad del mismo.
CONCLUSIÓN:
En general, Rime no es un mal juego, pero me da la sensación de que podría haber sido mucho más. Lo recomendaría en caso de haber una buena oferta. 6/10

49422059.review:
https://steamcommunity.com/groups/The_dull_games_reviewer

What can I say about RIME? I'm not sure I have the words to do it justice, so I'll just use some quotes from celebrities:

"It's all been rather lovely"
John Le Messurier, actor in the BBC comedy 'Dad's army', said those words before he died. He was ruminating on his life and not this game, but he probably would have said the same thing if he'd ever played it.

"RIME was alright to play, I guess. I prefer manlier activities like sticking my boot / shotgun / chainsaw up a demons butt. No! I'm not crying! Just got some....um... acidic demonic blood in my eye...yeah....stings like a mutha! Pass me a tissue"
The DOOM guy 

"What did I think of RIME? Emotions are for girls......now, pass me a tissue. I got some, er, acidic alien blood in my eye, and it, uh, stings like the mutha-****** of all mutha-******s. I, uh, need to dab it out before the, um, acid eats all the way through my brain. Yeah! That's it. Duke, you crafty fox! Those suckers will never know you were crying. Hey! Wait! Is that thing still recording?"
Duke Nukem

I can't really sum up the plot of RIME too much, because it kind of doesn't have one - at least, not in a conventional sense. You play a boy who wakes up shipwrecked on a mysterious island, that is gradually revealed to be far less normal than it first appears. Despite looking like an ancient place in the mediterranean it has robots, shadowy creatures, strange mechanisms seemingly powered by magic, and an evil giant bird that really doesn't seem to like you very much.

How did you get there? What is going on? What are you meant to be doing? It's one of THOSE games....where what little you get told is 80% visual storytelling, and the other 20% comes from the moody / sombre / melancholy / soaring music. No dialogue. No text. 

The ending isn't too ambiguous as to its meaning, but until then it's just a "feeling" the game gives you whilst the island gets more and more weird. Not weird in a Far Cry 3 drug trip kind of way, yet enough that you'll question how this place came to be, what it's for, and what every activity you're doing in it is all about.

It's a fairly gentle platformer with some mild puzzles, and takes a few hours to finish. I honestly can't make the game play sound anymore exciting than that, because it isn't. If you can't get swept up in the beautiful, simple, music or get hooked by the emotive narrative (such as it is) / sense of discovery, then the relatively sedate action isn't likely to satisfy.

It's not a twitch platformer, or has mind bending conundrums. It's "nice", and will maybe punch you in the feels come the conclusion. I'm not that familiar with games of this type on PC, and the only one that springs to mind would be a dead giveaway as to the ending of RIME if I named it as the two aren't all that dissimilar. It's relatively comparable to the playstation games ICO / Shadow Of The Colossus / The Last Guardian mechanically, and in it's themes of love, loss and regret.

I wouldn't have said it matched the last two for emotional oomph, but it's a moot point if you don't own a playstation, and to be fair to RIME it plays better than any of them. If a long play time is your thing then this may disappoint, as I think it took about 7 hours to finish. Though that's not so short for the type of game that it is, and what's there is really well made. 

The production values are quite high, it's glitch free, and runs fairly well, so I'd recommend it...if it sounds like your "cup of tea", of course. I just can't say what that "cup of tea" exactly is without spoiling it....

If you found this review to be helpful then why not check out my curator page here:
https://steamcommunity.com/groups/The_dull_games_reviewer

49122933.review:
[h1]Simply Beautiful[/h1]

Rime is an adventure game with puzzle elements from Tequila Softworks. I picked it up for $3 and went in with fairly low expectations due to the mix of positive and negative reviews on the store page. I actually ended up being pleasantly surprised! Rime is a beautiful game that tells a story in an interesting way, and it does it with relatively few frustrations. 

[h1]Positives:[/h1]
[list][*]Rime really is beautiful, I love the aesthetic here and it remains pretty consistent throughout the game. The first three chapters are particularly beautiful, with the fourth being quite haunting. There were a couple of textures that looked a bit rough to me, but really good overall. I also think that all of the creatures in the game are really well designed.

[*]One thing I was quite pleased with was that the puzzles were quite straightforward. There were definitely a couple of puzzles that had me stumped for a minute or two, but for the most part I found them easy to figure out. Now, not everyone will think that’s a good thing, but personally I think Rime is much more of an adventure game than it is a puzzle game. The puzzles are certainly fun, but the real meat is exploring the world Tequila created and piecing together the story. I don’t think Rime would work as well as it does if less-experienced puzzle players were constantly forced to check guides/walkthroughs to figure out how to carry on.

[*]One thing you might need a guide for though, is the collectibles. I think there are four types of collectibles in the game, but there may be others that I just never saw. Seemingly they’re tied to most of the game’s achievements, as beating the game only got me 8/31. I’m usually not interested in collectibles, but I am actually interested in going back through to try and get some/all of them, which is a rarity in games. I think it adds some good replayability, especially if you’re a die-hard achievement hunter.

[*]There are some dangers in Rime, I won’t go into detail about what the dangers are lest I spoil the game, but I was glad to see a little danger thrown in, just to add some tension to the game. Though even with the tension in some parts, Rime is still a pretty relaxing game and I really enjoyed just sitting back and playing through it, it’s a good experience.

[*]I think the story is quite good, there’s some mystery that kind of strings you along through the game, and then once you see the ending of the game the story of the whole game is revealed to you. I don’t want to say too much more than that, so I don’t spoil it, but I felt satisfied by the ending. I think a second playthrough is probably required to make sense of everything though, as there are a couple of things I’m left confused by.[/list]

[h1]Neutral:[/h1]
[list][*]One thing that I noticed other reviews picking up on is the climbing mechanics in the game, with that being mentioned in some of the negative reviews. I don’t really understand why this was an issue for some people, because while it wasn’t quite as interesting as something like Grow Home, it felt like it worked similarly to an Assassins Creed or Tomb Raider game to me (just with a little less animation). This is an adventure game rather than a climbing-focused game after all, so I think what’s there is about as good as I would expect it to be.[/list]

[h1]Negatives:[/h1]
[list][*]My biggest disappointment with Rime was that it doesn’t have a photo mode. This game is beautiful, and it’s exactly the kind of game that a photo mode would work really well for. I get that this probably isn’t a huge issue for everyone, but I was definitely disappointed by it.

[*]Performance wasn’t quite as good as I expected, I had to turn the settings down a fair bit more than I would have liked and even then, it wasn’t running great. The visuals are great, but the game is simplistic and it’s not like it’s photo-realistic, I expected it to be easier to run. Probably not an issue for people with beefy rigs, but if you’re on a mid-range gaming laptop or PC like I am, it might be worth keeping in mind.

[*]There was a little too much underwater stuff for my liking. Rime really doesn’t look anywhere near as nice or play as well during the underwater sections, and while I really enjoyed the rest of the game, I could not wait for the underwater sections to be over with.[/list]

[h1]Verdict:[/h1]

I ended up enjoying Rime a lot more than I expected. It's a relaxing journey through some beautiful places, but don't come here looking for a challenge. It's worth playing through at least once. However, I don’t think there’s anything here that makes this game worth $30, I’d wait for it to be $15 or less.

If you found this review helpful, please check out my other reviews over at [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33633486/]Kemo's Corner.[/url]

49073566.review:
[h1]RiME: más allá de las palabras[/h1]
[u]Reseña Spoiler-free[/u]

Si tuviera que describir este juego con una sola palabra sería [b]hermoso[/b]. Todos los detalles visuales están cuidadísimos, desde lo que ves hasta lo que oyes (con una maravillosa canción de Lindsey Sterling, no te digo más). El cielo, el agua de lluvia cayendo sobre la piedra, el día y la noche... No te vas a cansar de observar todo tu entorno; y es que de eso va precisamente el siguiente punto, de buscar coleccionables. Si de algo se ha preocupado Tequila Works es de que tengas que andar rebuscando en cada esquina y cada saliente en busca de un sinfín de coleccionables diferentes: conchas, cerraduras, trajes...

La historia es maravillosa y, en pos de no hacer ningún tipo de spoiler, me limitaré a decir que deberías jugarlo sin ver nada: ni gameplays, ni walktroughs, ni siquiera guías por escrito.

E hilando con el tema de las guías, he de decir que mi mayor pega para con este juego es que la dificultad es [i]nula[/i]: los "puzzles" son demasiado fáciles, el plataformeo es para niños pequeños (con los bordes CONVENIENTEMENTE cagados por palomas) y el mapa es muy lineal. La única dificultad real del juego son, como ya he mencionado antes, los coleccionables y los [b]logros[/b]. Cazadores de logros: estáis jodidos sin una guía.

[h1]En resúmen[/h1]
[list]
    [*]El juego es, visualmente una pasada, una historia profunda y cautivadora.
    [*]No necesitas tener el cerebro 100% conectado, con un par de neuronas te será suficiente para pasártelo.
    [*]Cuenta con una rejugabilidad artificial en forma de coleccionables y logros; de hecho, es imposible conseguir el 100% en una sola partida :)
[/list]
[b]¿Recomiendo el juego? ABSOLUTAMENTE.[/b]

Heyyy, gracias por leer toda la reseña. Si te ha parecido interesante, te animo a que le des a útil/gracioso para que más gente pueda leerla y decidirse por este juego tan chulo :3 ¡Gracias otra vez!

48949935.review:
RiME - A tale to remember

TL/DR: I think this game is excellent [i] IF [/i] you are a story motivated player.

At first glance, RiME seems to be a fairly simple and cute puzzle game. But throughout the first region, the game starts to feed you small pieces of information, just enough to hint at something more. 
And boy was there more, and it was  a feel train.

Its hard to truly convey what made the story good without spoiling it. So just trust me, its good.

RiME is an artistic masterpiece. Each individual level has distinct moods. (That later have more important meaning)
These moods are represented through fantastic choices in colour, lighting, weather and the soundtrack. When you finish the game, and understand the story, the levels feel so much better designed now that you know what they are meant to be. 

The puzzles may have been simple, but I felt like the increase of complexity was smooth. It introduced the new concepts fast enough to keep the simple game play from stagnating. 
It is NOT like other puzzle games like "Portal" where you might spend ages in a single room. I feel it was purposely made the way it was so it did not subtract from the flow of the story.

[b] If you are after a difficult puzzle platformer, this game isn't for you. [/b]

[b] If you are after an unique approach to story telling, I honestly couldn't recommend this more. [/b]

I suggest sitting down and dedicating an entire session to knock this out in one sitting. Its on the short side so it shouldn't be to hard.

With that all said, I wouldn't spend $40USD on it. Wait for a sale to slam this artwork down.

48881011.review:
While I really liked the story that unfolded before me, the mechanical downsides leave much to be desired.

RiME is a puzzle/platformer where you travel a mysterious island, learning more about your character as you progress.  Unfortunately, the game is extremely short and I completed it in about 5 hours.  Sure there are collectibles to gather, but considering your character's movement speed, it does not seem like a fun thing to do, even if the lore interests me.  I feel that if my character was able to move even a little faster I would have shaved off a lot of my playtime, but of course, that would break some of the puzzles.  Granted, there are positives about the gameplay, I never had to worry about falling off of ledges or about my jumps being too small, the game will appropriately snap you in place to where you need to jump everytime.

As for the graphics, I really like the art style, however, I feel like there were some optimization issues as I would get consistent framerate drops and some of the shadows would glitch in and out.  There's only one area in the game where I hit a solid, consistent 60fps and it was in one of the prettiest areas near the end of the game, but unfortunately it did not last long.  

This game is more like an interactive story, so if that's your thing, go ahead and get it, but I strongly stress that this is not worth the $30 price tag for only 5 hours of core gameplay.

48755292.review:
I tried very hard to like this game, but it felt as if it fought back against me every step of the way. On its surface, this game is extremely charming, the environments are stunning, and the soundtrack is truly exquisite. But the game itself -- the interaction between player and system is fundamentally unsatisfying -- from the way the character controls down to the puzzles or challenges the game presents to you. 

Your character's movement and animations feel so slow and labored that getting from one point to another in the game genuinely just got bothersome. Even the camera moves at an painfully sluggish pace -- when you're in control, that is. Because Rime loves to fix the camera to a certain point, and then it becomes a guessing game of which direction your character will move in in response to your inputs. While I started out wanting to explore the fantastic-looking world of Rime, by my second or third hour I just wanted to mainline it. By my fourth hour I just wanted to quit. 

There is barely anything to the puzzles you're asked to solve. Zero thinking required. You see something, it clicks immediately, because you've either done this in another game already or it's just that dead obvious, and then you just execute. Next. Where is the payoff, I wonder?

I think that that's the biggest problem with Rime. It fails to stimulate the player at any possible level -- not emotionally, not intellectually, and not kinesthetically (through controlling the character). Even the world loses its shine when you dread simply getting around.

48654091.review:
I bought Rime thinking it was a puzzle-platformer, which is superficially true, but boy was I in for a (pleasant) surprise. Yes, Rime does all the stuff that puzzle-platformers do: you explore various worlds, scale walls, navigate mazes, all the while solving puzzles to unlock areas. The puzzles were mostly fun to solve, although most of them were not difficult, actually some were even very straightforward. However, the main purpose of Rime is to tell you a story, the puzzle solving business is totally secondary. And that story is very intriguing. I completed the game in just two long nightly sessions, so curious was I to see the story unfold. The backstory is unclear when you start to play the game. The game consists of 5 chapters with very different moods and atmospheres. As the names of the 5 chapters indicate, the game is about dealing with loss. But only in the final chapter the backstory of the boy is finally revealed.

Apart from the story, there is much to like about Rime. To me one of the main attractions of the game is the art and visual style of the game. Each world is very beautiful and well designed, with the exception of the various extensive underwater scenes (with the air bubbles) which appear to be a tribute to Super Mario Galaxy. The character controls pretty well and runs reasonable fast, which is very important in this game as you do not want the platforming to get in the way of the story telling. In some parts of the game you are climbing massive walls and structures, which was actually fun to do because the character handles so well.

48651384.review:
Masterpiece. I'm not easly impressed nor generous with compliments, but I'm convinced that this game deserve all the love and admiration it receives. It's incredible how a videogame like RiME can tell a story, make you experience a great variety of feelings and emotions and even bring you to tears without using a single word.

If you are going to give this game a try, I recommend to not go for an achievement or treasures hunt. All that matter, at least for the first time, is the story.

9.5/10

It only starts to make sense near the end (which is a shame, because it is actually good) / WAAY TOO EXPENSIVE for only 4-6 hours of gameplay (and for the quality of the game as well tbh). Only buy it during a sale!

Conclusion: RiME is building on the existing, good ol' formula, adding little-to-none new stuff. Decent game, and decent story but honestly nothing new. The big pro here is how peaceful the gameplay feels. 6.5/10

48282549.review:
RiME is a story about a boy who can make statues light up by shouting at them and has an imaginary pet fox (that’s the spoiler-free version). It’s undeniably pretty but has so many flaws. Although it looks similar to fantastic experiences such as AER and ABZU, the similarities stop at the graphics. I don’t think I had to use my brain for the entire thing. The puzzles didn’t pose any challenge at all, and you’re literally led from one to the next, so it’s very linear. It’s short, so I finished it - but man was I bored for the entire game. It’s a good example of why you can’t just get artists and musicians to make a game without putting any thought in to the actual game design.

[b]Additional[/b]
Without spoilers, it’s a very pretentious game that takes you through 5 different stages, representing the after effects of an event that is slowly revealed at the end of each level. In that way, you might call it an example of games as an art form. I’d agree if it wasn’t so dull to play - I felt like the whole game was there to show off the artwork. It looks fantastic, but it just lacks and kind of depth or emotional engagement. I think that’s partly because it reveals so little of the story, but even after the first level I’d guessed what the game was about.

Luckily I got it in a Humble Bundle; I’d be really pissed off if I’d paid 36 euros for 4 hours of gameplay.

[b]Completed in 4.5 hours[/b]

48276939.review:
In my opinion this game is perfect.

the story is nice, the gameplay feels smooth and polished, the mechanics are easy to understand but don't get boring, the stages are visually pleasing. This is the perfect way of presenting a exploration driven adventure game!

The difficlulty curve for the collecteables is also great. At first I stumbled upon them by just playing the game, so that I knew what I was looking for. But in the later stages I wasn't even able top find a single thing, you really have to be thorough to find them all. There are also some more hidden ones in the first level, so a second playthrough is also encouraged!

It feels like a toy when you play the game, everything just works (except a weird camera transition bug when you're on 21:9, that happens when switching from third person to third person for a cutscene). 
I got very immersed in the game, an experience I hardly ever get. I mean I even watched the credits all the way to the end, which is mostly due to Silvia's amazing voice though, but still, I just didn't want it to end!

It's a very steep price for such a short game, but the experience is definetly worth it. So when it's on sale, don't even think twice, just buy it and enjoy!

48265839.review:
The easiest way for me to tell you what Rime is, and what to expect from it, is to tell you wat Rime is NOT:

- It's not a fun, cute Zelda-like adventure filled with intelligent puzzles. 
- It's not a game with easy story telling, dialogue, or text. The story is very symbolic, doesn't really drive the gameplay, and is confusing even after ending the game.


So what do we have left? 

■■■ Gameplay ■■■
A very easy, third-person exploration game. Calling it a walking simulator would be too harsh, but the puzzles are really light, and there is not a whole lot to do other than that.
The controls are good enough. This game is more about the experience and story than pure gameplay fun. There is some stuff to collect and complete,
but i must be very honest about that it is not a lot of fun to do so. The game is level based, so you will have to replay a complete level again to collect missed stuff, which can take up to an hour. The total game is very short, around 5 hours, maybe 10 to 100% complete it.

■■■ Visual style & Graphics ■■■
This game has some VERY nice graphics and artwork, very bright and colorful. This was what initially got me interested in the game, it's just so vibrant and well-made. The world design also is awesome, the buildings and area's all are designed very well visually, this game just really has its own little style, and i really like it.

■■■ Music ■■■
This game has a beautifully orchestrated soundtrack, which adds a lot of atmosphere, but above all emotion to the game. Sometimes the music is very subtle to focus more on environmental sounds.

■■■ Story ■■■
Very hard to write about without spoiling. You will wake up, washed ashore on a mysterious island with a huge white tower. You will have to find things out yourself, and learn about the situation. The story is completely told through cutscenes, and some wall paintings, there is no dialogue or text to read. 

■■■ Technical & Bugs ■■■
No problems. Game ran fine on my GTX1060 3GB and i7. Enough graphics options.

Don't buy it for full price, it's not worth it for only 5 hours of gameplay. Though this game is a bit more than a walking simulator with a story, i do recommend it to peeps who like experiences like that.

48246108.review:
RiME is a complicated review for me. I reccomend it, but not without reservations.

The Good:
It's an absolutely beautiful game. The art style is fantastic, and is executed perfectly across all aspects of RiME. Even more than the look of it, the music is incredible. It ranges from melodic and hopeful, to haunting and melancholy. The final two chapers are the ultimate showcase of this, as a combination of environmental choices along with music that makes you feel the anguish of the boy, are pulled off to perfection. The game shines with it's style, music, and subtle storytelling, and it's entirely why I recommend you play it.

The Not So Good:
The puzzles are fine, but they're not really anything special. That said, I knew I was coming in to this for the look and sound of it, and less so for the actual video game parts, so it's really not that big of a knock against it.

The only other thing that actually truly bothered me while playing, was some of the camera work. I don't usually feel motion sick playing games- I've got a Rift, and I can stay in that thing for hours- but for some reason, I found myself feeling kind of ill after certain sections of RiME. It's by no means a dealbreaker on an otherwise enjoyable experience, but it was an annoying problem that I've rarely experienced in any other game

7.5/10
