48122194.review:
This is a game that could've told a beautiful story in a stunning medium. 
And the story is great, don't get me wrong.
But you know what ruins the experience for me?
The atrocious gameplay following Act 2. 

FOLLOWING THIS POINT, THE REST OF THE REVIEW IS SPOILERS. YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED.

So Act 1 starts off at a slow pace, easing you into the basic elements of gameplay. You don't feel any sort of rush to complete the main objective right away so you're more likely to explore (which is good as you will ABSOLUTELY need to do that in later levels just to finish the main objective). One element never gets used again (feeding the boars fruit) which is seriously dissapointing to me.

Act 2 was INTENSE and I LOVED IT. I had all these good vibes going in and then the tone shift comes when a real enemy was introduced being the Bird(?) and the Phantoms. Now the thing with the bird is that I was expecting it to be the main antagonist for the whole game - not just one act. What I was expecting was finding out that this boy's tribe was responsible for destroying its home and the bird, in a continuous fit of anger, would attack their village. In order to appease it, they would offer a sacrifice - the boy - but something goes wrong. The boy survives and the bird is FURIOUS. He's now actively seeking out his meal and you must help this boy kill the bird and get to safety.
This is what I THOUGHT. But what I GOT was... well, like I said, it would've been good had the gameplay not ruined it.
The only other comment I have for Act 2 is the realization that the Phantoms were afraid of me. I thought that was an amazing discovery. This entire time, I had been going out of my way to avoid them, scared of them myself, and these things are just as afraid of me? That was AWESOME. You're meant to be playing from the perspective of a boy adrift in a strange land, you have no idea what's going on and you're just trying your best to survive. Then these bizarre creatures show up on what you can only presume is their territory and THEY are afraid of YOU? 

Act 3: 
Well, I wish the last point would've standed because even after you managed to kill the largest creature in the immediate area, those phantoms make a complete 180 and COME for you. Personally, I think this should've been switched. They should've started off aggressive and THEN gone to fear. Part of my frustration with this act is having to take a guess at whether or not this phantom is only acting as a barrier or if they're actually aggressive. The other part is not having a god damn clue what I was doing. Apparently I'm not the only one because one of the most watched Walkthroughs spends a good 5-10 min on puzzle just walking around, trying to figure out what the hell is going on. Half of my time was spent going " WELL HOW WAS I SUPPOSED TO KNOW THAT " and grinding my teeth in anger. This is BAD for many reasons but the largest one is that it takes you out of the running story that's going on. Like when you see these giant Cores which look like the Steam Punk version of cores found in Portal just lying there dead, I get the impression I'm SUPPOSED to care. I'm SUPPOSED to care when the 1st one you revive suddenly collapses. I'm SUPPOSED to care when the 2nd one sees its fallen brother and wails. 
But did I?
No. 
Because by the time I got to the end of the level, I was too pissed off to care. This same problem dominates through the rest of the game which is awful when you're trying to tell an emotional story like this. There was also this one part where there was this wall that looked like it had a golden ladder.
Couldn't climb it.
Massively infuriating.
You can climb vines, pillars with golden rungs, and rock walls with a small jut but you can't climb something that looks like a ladder?

Act 4:
Idk if this is meant to split up into 2 acts after the boy turns into a ghost but I'm counting it as one so you're gonna have to deal with it.
I was still pretty raw from anger coming into this and thought that this might be the Act I settle down but I was INSTANTLY enraged when I saw the robots were carrying the kid.
Why?
BECAUSE THAT WOULD HAVE BEEN SO USEFUL IN THE LAST DAMN CHAPTER, THAT'S WHY.
You gotta think before you do shit like this because I spent the majority of Act 3 glaring at this robot thinking " Why can't I just hold onto your leg or something and pilot you? "
Anyhow, the rest of the level was fine until midway through. One of the totems I needed to activate had the most infuriating platform sequences since the cliff I needed to grab was at a weird angle. The character is easy enough to control with just about any situation EXCEPT diagonal jumping. I had to make 5 attempts before making what should have been a relatively easy jump.
The final thing that ticked me right off was when the kid becomes a ghost.
DO. NOT. MAKE. YOUR. CHARACTER. THE. SAME. COLOR. AS. THE. PLATFORMS. OH. MY. GOD.
That was an AWFUL design choice. It's not pleasing to look at and it makes controller the character harder. 

4/10. This game could be so much better if it didn't try too much at once and cleaned things up a bit. I would rate this lower but it's still really beautiful and the music is composed+implemented very well.

47946895.review:
If you play this game without worrying about secrets or collectibles, it's probably fine. But god did they completely screw up secret/achievement hunting here. You can only select the start of each chapter, and there's points of no return all throughout chapters, meaning that secrets are easy to miss and then take a looong time to get back to if you do miss them. Which is bad. And they all do... nothing, really. Emblems mean nothing. Lullabies mean nothing. Toys and Keyholes have tiiiiny rewards but nooot really. Outfits are the only tangible reward and they're only aesthetic at best. And the way some stuff is hidden is... questionable. Go through a specific set of doors? Uhh. Climb a tower you already climbed but with no indication you need to climb it again? Why. 

The problem you face whether or not you go for completion is that this game is self-indulgent to the point of arrogance and thus looooves wasting your time. Be prepared for: 1. Slooow cutscenes. 2. Slow movement. 3. Lots of samey, uninteresting parkour platforming. 4. A general super slow feel. It's just... paced really badly and on replay (which is almost a necessity if you want to go for completion considering how easy it is to miss stuff) it reeeally shows how much this game revels in its own "atmosphere" and "beauty". Yeah, the game does look good. But not -that- good. Not so good you need to constantly shove it in my face. The music's also a tad generic but constantly seems to believe it's meaningful and deep. Bleh.

I will say, the story is solid, and it's revealed at a decent enough pace, though really they could've told the same story more succinctly and cut out a lot of the tedious puzzling. But ehh. In the end... yeah, especially for $30, with how little content is actually here, absolutely no recommendation, you can do much better in this style of atmospheric puzzly/explory game than this.

47909558.review:
[H1]I am writing a review for RIME.[/H1]

[H1]When I first saw this game the thought was, "I will Probably get this when they iron the bugs out."
The bugs are ironed out.
This game surprised me for several reasons, and I'll break it down for you.[/H1]

[H1]Gameplay:[/H1]
[H1]As simple as this game appeared when I first finally got my hands on it, It Quickly let me know this is a game of Skill and thought. You are in character like Tomb Raider. You jump from ledges and hurdle across casms and climb VERY high. I say this because I have a fear of heights. My games that terrifed me; were like Dying Lights First encounter with the Crane off the roof. I nearly hurled. After you get used to it its alright, and this game delivers that sense of height and risk.

The controls are very tight.
 
I am a WASD player, casual gamer. The controls having sensitivity is crucial because the game will kill you for jumping. Falling works in the game, and there IS gravity.

I found the situations and scenery made the game play all the more fun. As you go, youre able to collect things, There are shells, pieces of images, pictures keyholes, and some other things I cant remember. This game was LUSHLY populated with Lovely, and harsh landscapes.[/H1]

[H1]Look and feel:[/H1]
[H1]I loved the simple beauty of the character, there was a childlike innnocence you saw. The enviroments were Lush. I loved how things interact with you. In a sandbox Open-world, I can go anywhere,  this game was fairly forgiving and allowed me to get out of jams, unlike some games do. The walls and rocks arent Traps like Other games, in other words.

I played this game for 3 days on a off. I tried to play to a stopping place and save. The game saves but its Usually where you started from, the last time you played. That Isnt a big deal because I saw how I needed to go sometimes when I was lost. Starting again helped me get my bearings.

The Puzzles are Great and varied. There are so many I couldnt count, but you were always involved. It was my Favorite part of this game.

Parker moves and jumping happens also.[/H1]

[H1]Likes:[/H1] 

[H1]The look wasnt so polished you were awestruck at every scene, but the graphics were (in Ultra) Beautiful. Physics are real and consisistent, as are response from controls.
The cut-scenes are a treat, and happen so infrequently its a great break in the action. It slows the play down too. Thats a deal because I found myself wanting to run through the game. I sort of Did, but in a thoughtful manner, trying to find stuff and get achievments.[/H1]

[H1]Dislikes:[/H1]

[H1]This game is Stingy with achievments if youre a collector of stuff. The artifacts to find, go from difficullt, to stupidly simple.
Not the strongest part of the game IMHO to complete. This requires a guide to find everthing.

At times I found my self having issues with what was being asked of me or where I was going (because I have a tendancy to wander in open world games like this, and I was lost a few times. Luckily the Devs had a Clue, and made it so if you save; it will allow you to return to the start of your mission. 

You have a traveling companion, a Fox. It willl lead you where you need to go. I had to pay attention to that, because its Really handy Not to get lost.
Im not a completionist.[/H1]

[H1]Final thoughts:[/H1]

[H1]I like to start at a place where everyone can agree, 'would you play this game again?'
I have to say, 'Yes'.
Im a sucker for games that allow me to run around everywhere and do mostly anything.
I liked the Puzzles in this game!! I like puzzles, but this game had great Logical puzzles, and it made sense when you finished them. Plus: You feel smarter.[/H1]

[H1]8/10 Beauty, because the graphics werent SO polished, but still lovely.
      9/10 Game play: It Was fun!
      10/10 Immersion, because at the end[spoiler]I cried[/spoiler][/H1]

[H1]The price is Right to get this, during a sale, so Please do. I enjoyed this game Immensely. [/H1]

47826328.review:
Good Idea Bad Devs

The first hour of this game is like dating a hot psycho sure shes great to you in the begining but slowly but surely her insanity starts to show. Rimes concept of an exploration game with epic puzzles is a great idea and you will feel like thats what your getting in the begining which sadly is as far as most people get with there games as seen with low achivement rates.

But sadly this game is full of frustrating flaws and outright incompetance at the hands of the designer and even the artists which is very poor by todays standards. This game is overall a simple design for the unreal engine which was speically built to make these kind of single player games great unlike PUBG etc but boy does it have problems. 

Firstly this game has one of the worst camera clipping issues I have seen that causes the camera to jarringly go through walls often stunning the player with black or worse whatever randomness is behind the games walls. Its like being blinded everytime as if a deer just dove out in front of your car, truly awful programing. Plently of unreal engine games dont have any issue with the camera like this its something you dont even think about in Tomb Raider for example. 

Tomb raider is a good thing to compare alot of things in this game as despite its faults its fundemntals are solid when compared to Rimes poor effort. Alot of the climbing in this game is based on bird shit on ledges signalling you can climb it but due to the artistic lighting you often can not see it. Now i don't wear glasses but if you do dont even finish the review just dont bother with the game youre going to rage often trying to figure out what youre missing when you can see the slight change in color that was vital to you progressing forward. The lighting in general makes the game such an awful experince espically the areas that are dark and due to the high washed out light in the day you cant fix it with brightness changes unless you plan to turn it up and down everytime you in an area which somethings if your moving like underwater for example its too risky to do so.

The parkour in general in this game is often terrible when compared to Tomb raider or Assasins creed and thers a distinct lack of smoothness to the animations and controls which make navigating the world a chore. The little boys animations are so janky and stilted as if he has brittle bones, it feels like every button press has animation delay which makes timing what you want to do bad. I died a few times jumping off a cliff when I wasnt intending to do what the game produced. The game is also very inconsistent with what is possible, yes I know you could make that jump back then but you can't here ... or can you its never clear whats possible or if your doing it wrong. I really wish they had implemtned the fox guide more to aliveate this.

The boy chacters design starts to anoy after you spend enough time with him as hes just so odd looking imagine a white kid with black face thats strangely what he looks like. The dumb thing to me is why there wasnt a character creation tool in this game as the story is so loose that being a girl or a boy of whatever race would have not effected the plot. Being able to create you as a child would have added a lot of depth to the game and made it more meaningful because after a while youll be flinging him off cliffs just to see whats possible without a care in the world, meaning you dont care for his saftey and therefore his journey. 

The puzzles arent really that speical, there often beautiful in there architetureal design and art which is one of the games big draws but there's nothing hear thats better than the Breath of the Wild mini puzzles. Im not the biggest fan of Tomb raider or Uncharted but I can promise you they both have far better puzzles. One that particular pissed me off was one of the gold door ones that asks the player to know how to do something thats impossible within the games logic until you learn of it. Soon as you know its possible the puzzle is easy if you don't you'll feel like you dont even have a clue as to not only what to do but if your even in the right place, its that fucking awful. 1 of the worse puzzles I've seen made, thats similar to telling the player I know you have 2 hands but you should have used the invisble 3rd hand we gave you but didnt tell you.

Another thing mentioned by reviewer Jim Sterling really hit home the more i played the game and thats the problem of having collectables which are an issue for several reasons in this specific game. Firstly they are mostly apart from the story ones worthless and unrewarding items that make you feel like that was pointless for my time investment. Theyre kind of a nod towards those that explore a little more than others whilst doing the main ones but it just makes you feel like checking every nook for the sake of it not because you want to. Thats bad because exploration is what makes this game feel unique and special yet often youre exploration is not rewarded because instead of something like a beautiful hidden waterfall with unique life, you find a worthless charm thats more like an emoticon than anything else. The game really needed more animal life and a way for the boy to interact with it in an enjoyable way like petting it for example. 

The music is nice but kind of forgettable you want really be hearing it in your head later on but its not anoying unlike many of the sound effects from the shouting boy to the segul to the hellish bird boss scream. I turned the sound down more and more that I pushed through the game, shame.

The game runs very poorly on my powerful computer for a game this simple and it feels very poorly optomised. This is really bad given you kinda need the graphics on high to see things clearly due to the previously mentioned problems with the game. Even though the game looks simple enough if you have a low end system really do not bother with this game its going to be troublesome for you. I also hate the lack of being able to save when you want its really jarring when you have to come back to the game as your not where youd like to pause your journey. The options menu is very poor by Total Biscuits standards and pc buffs are not going to be impressed by whats here.

Overall this game is not worth the high price for a short indie game and even at sale due to its painfully frustrating elements I can not recomend you spend your time with this game. The sad part about this game is that if they had a team of testers or went early access that would have spotted all these obvious issues with the game and lead to them being fixed. A lot of what this game does has been done before but better and its a real shame the game designers didnt study hard enough to learn about the importance of customer feedback in design. Their lack of expertise has turned what could have been a great title into a bad one and how sad it is that all the hard work they put into this game is wasted.  

The main lesson here is Hire Quality Assurance Testers no matter what your games budget is, pls Devs.

47781455.review:
Yo no sé las películas que se han montado con el juego este y sus significados ocultos, si no hay misterio. Claramente narra la vida de un niño gaditano que se despierta en la playa después de 16 horas de siesta al sol y se pega un fin de semana de paseo por los pueblos del interior de la costa andaluza. ¿Qué de donde me saco esto? Pues pongo algunos ejemplos:

En un inicio llegamos a Mojacar, donde encontramos todas esas calles y casas blancas revestidas de cal (ya sabéis, para estar fresquitos en verano), visitamos también la playa de Punta Paloma, con sus aguas cristalinas y su maravillosa orilla en la que buscar fardos y, más tarde, nos adentramos en terrenos montañosos, concretamente en Málaga, donde casi al final del juego puedes encontrar el caminito del rey.

Es cierto eso de que es muy importante la voz del protagonista. Y es que en tu viaje deberás aprender a cantar soleás, tímidamente empezarás con suaves “mmmh” que avanzarán directamente a gritos porque no terminas bien de pillar el compás, y claro, eso te descarta automáticamente como cantante pero te vale para el jaleo.

Otra referencia clara es cuando, en un momento del juego en el que todo está oscuro, se te aparece la virgen de la macarena para darte fuerza cristiana, pero al verte se raya y desaparece porque sabe que no estás bautizao.

El zorro ese que no hace más que ronearte es en realidad el chivato del dealer del barrio. Uno que va con un poncho rojo y que está en todos los rincones del juego porque cambia continuamente de lugar no vaya a ser que los verdes le desmonten el tinglao.

Y bueno aún me queda juego por delante así que si veo más referencias iré actualizando esto. Gracias Tequila Works por llevar el folclore mediterráneo allende de nuestras fronteras. Moláis.

47605091.review:
I'm really confused.
The game is beautifull, and I mean it. One of the best looking, atmospheric, games out there. It's just astonishing. The story is also great, and well told. Music score kicks ass and so on. 10/10 if it comes to the tech / goodies.

Now, the game itself... It's not a puzzle game. There are like 5 puzzles where you have to think (a bit), and the rest is just tedious moving things around. No thinking involved at all. 

It's more WALKING SIMULATOR, rather than puzzle game. 
Quite wonderful walking simulator, but still - not a puzzle game. 
You walk, you jump, you walk and jump. No gameplay at all. Just tedious moving around the levels.

But then, once you turn the blind eye on the fact it's gameplay kind of sucks, and just realise it's a walking simulator, you'll spend couple of great hours discovering all the beauty  and heart, developers put into this title.

Not sure if I'd recommend this game to everyone, but if you're willing to forgive a lot of tedious walking, to get something quite special on different fronts (design, graphics, story) - it's a treat!

47595842.review:
Rating: 7.5/10
Genre: 3D platforming 

The Good:
+ An incredibly well-crafted game, exploring the environments with some light platforming and puzzle solving in the mix.  Exploring the environment carefully usually rewards you with some sort of collectable.

+ Variety of environments between the 5 chapters

+ There is a ‘silent’ story, no dialogue, and things start to make more sense as you play the game. Again, it fits nicely with the narrative of the game and doesn’t get in the way, allowing you to explore and enjoy the game. 

+ Fantastic soundtrack 
 
The Average:
+/- The puzzle fit nicely with the overall theme of the game but felt a bit too easy especially in the later half of the game since the puzzles don’t evolve very much. 

+/- The game will take around 5-10 hours depending on how thorough you explore each area.

The Bad:
- Framerates were not stable at all, fluctuating between 30-60fps. 

Conclusion:
The closest thing we will get to ICO on steam. Although I wouldn’t call this game a masterpiece, it does do a good job of filling that void though and those looking for a more relaxing, casual experience will definitely appreciate what this game has to offer.

47522972.review:
Simply can't recommend a game where graphics takes center stage while gameplay - in this case puzzles - takes a backseat. Puzzles are just .. bad.. They don't have any real cleverness to any of them, at least for the player. It's all trial and error. The game just wants to show off its artistry at every point, which I admit is top notch and the game is absolutely beautiful. But with some clunky controls and poor puzzles, this is definitely a thumb down for me. Also has optimization issues. Stutters sometimes in some areas even on a Vega 64.

The game clearly takes inspiration from third person action adventure games like the classic Prince of Persia / Tomb Raider /God of War / Darksiders. Except, they have meaning to exploration, have great puzzles, much better level design, and good combat as well. Granted this is a chill-out and relax game,  but it fails even in that department because some of the puzzles are just annoying -they don't really require much use of your brain, but just trial and error.. If the puzzles were actually clever, like what you see in Talos Principle or Portal, I would've absolutely recommended this game. But, they're just mind numbingly boring to solve.. If you've played Hellblade Senua's Sacrifice, you'd know what I'm talking about. In Rime, puzzles are basically align an object with another,  rotate a ball till you hit the right spot, adjust an object so the shadows fall in the right places, so on and so forth. Sure, these puzzles show off a great lighting system and the developer's artistry skills, but as puzzles, they are barebones, yet frustrating at times, and it simply ruins it from being a good walking simulator as well.

This game has you pushing the Left analog stick on your controller forward (or pressing and holding W) for 80% of the game. It is a small open world, but your hand is still held by your pet which guides you to your objective. 

There is immense beauty on first look, but without any real content or meaning to it, it's nothing but a pretty empty shell that fails to keep me hooked.. There is no real story until the epilogue of the game, but by that time, I was already frustrated with the game that I truly didn't care.. If you think graphics/ visual art triumphs all, then boy oh boy are you in for a treat. Especially if you have an ultrawide monitor.

47443117.review:
RiME is a beautiful platforming, puzzle and somewhat explorational game. The game is emersive and tells an interesting story without the need for narration. Although RiME has some issues, it is certianly a game that I enjoyed and would recommend to people who love going on a story-telling journey.

[h1] Puzzles [/h1] 
This game is more of an art piece. The puzzles aren't meant to be challenging, but are meant to take you through the environment you're in. There are different puzzle mechanics that get introduced throughout the game that keeps the game interesting without making the introduction of he new mechanics abrupt.

[h1] Exploration [/h1]
Although RiME may seem linear, the player still has the option to explore their surroundings, often finding secrets or collectables; which can provide some lore (but it's totally optional and you don't need to collect them). The game isn't fully open world as you cannot explore places that are in different chapters from the one the player is in.

[h1] Music and Visuals [/h1]
The music in this game was breathtaking and the visuals were superb. The music for each setting really added to the atmosphere of the game; making you feel wonder at some times and fear at others. The art style is fitting for the story the game is telling and the visuals look really good in game. Giant structures would be imposing and the creatures within the game looked rather cute.

[h1] Story [/h1]
You uncover the story about the boy and the island as you progress through the game. Telling the story through the environment and symbolism rather than narration is, although not a new concept, very effective in RiME. The story is left up to interpretation by the player which makes it all the more interesting. As I was playing, I felt as though the story was pulling me in; I wanted to know more about where it was going which lead me to progressing throughout the entire game.
*In my opinion, the first 30 minutes of the game was to get the player used to the types of puzzles and mechanics that would be seen throughout the game. The story in this part of the game is not very apparent. However, RiME becomes much more interesting past this part and has good pace throughout the rest of the game*

[h1] Controls and Mechanics [/h1]
The controls are reletively simple, and the game would often prompt you as to what button you need to press to do something (e.g interact, throw, s c r e a m).  The player mechanics are just your average jump, drop, climb and scream. These mechanics can be a little janky though, at times I would be jumping to a climbable plank above me and I would fall instead of grabbing on. Climbable wouldn't be climbable past a certian point, which required me to get off and get back on again. The animation when jumping up a small ledge was a little awkward too, the boy would just look like he was sliding towards the ledge. You would also have to wait for a previous animation to end before screaming at something as well. Overall, platforming wasn't too difficult, it's just sometimes these awkward mishaps can be a litle annoying. 

[h1] Performance [/h1]
I would often drop frames in some areas for no particular reason and the game crashed twice in the 4.5 hours of playing even with the recommended specs.

[h1] Pricing [/h1]
I do understand that this is an indie game however $40 is pretty expensive for what you get out of the 5 hour game. I recommend buying RiME while on it's on sale (I got it for $20)

[h1] Conclusion and Recommendation [/h1]
In conclusion, RiME does have a couple of issues but overall it is an amazing experience and remains emersive throughout. The visuals and music help create the environment and atmosphere the player is in and it tells an interesting story. I don't think RiME is for everyone though, I recommend it to people who appreciate games that are there to take you on a journey and allow you to experience a story (or people who have free time and money to spend).

47420695.review:
Nothing makes me happier as both a player and aspiring developer than seeing this genre of Journey-esque games grow with every beautiful contribution. I mention Journey because it was the first game like this that I got to experience first-hand. It is still one of my favorites, but I gotta say Rime grabbed my heart and squeezed more than Journey ever managed to do. 

I expected a quiet, beautiful puzzle game, which it ultimately was. But the emotional journey I went on was neither quiet nor beautiful considering I sat through the last minutes of the game as well as the end credits bawling my eyes out and slobbering all over my keyboard. I cry all the time, but you know something messed you up real bad when your nose clogs up and the tears mix with your snot (TMI I know). 

The level design was fantastic, both in the way the world was built and the puzzles. The game used subtle visual, auricular and narrative queues to guide you and every feature immersed you in the experience. It used a lot of classic concepts that, as a gamer, you are very familiar with, but in a way that made them feel unique and interesting. I loved all the shaders and VFX. The feature that allowed you to sing and hum and cower and cry depending on your surroundings was absolutely fantastic. When I got to the dark room where you lit a path by singing, the subtle melody of the boy's voice instantly brought tears to my eyes and it continued to do so throughout the game. The music and soundeffects took the game to a completely different level.

I was constantly amazed by the beauty of each area, my favorite being the [spoiler] beginning of Bargaining, the swampy area. I especially enjoyed the part where you walk through one door and without walking up any stairs arrive at another floor, and when you take the same route again end up somewhere completely different. And the part where you walk and walk but never get anywhere (although it was a little buggy). It felt like the game was playing with you. 

The whole five stages of grief thing was fantastic and you could see signs of each stage in everything about each level. The mood, the progression, the way you interacted with the world, the way the boy acted etc etc. The symbolism was brilliant in both the holistic experience and in the little details. And in the end when you finally realized the truth it hit you like a bag of bricks. /[/spoiler]

I bought this game during Black friday which means it was heavily discounted, but for everyone that missed that I would 100% buy this game for the full price. I didn't go out of my way to get any of the collectibles but it still took me 12+ hours to get to the end. This game will touch you in a way that feels personal and intimate, and that is a very rare and precious thing. I highly recommend it.

47413755.review:
[i]RiME[/i] is the emotional journey of a fragile boy in some mysterious world. He has to fight himself through puzzles and hostile encounters, sometimes with the help of friends he makes along the way, othertimes alone.
One of the first things I asked myself while playing was how this game hadn't even been nominated for best score during the 2017 game awards. The orchestral accompaniment carried the mood of the scene throughout the game, and, together with the character design of the wondrous protagonist, created a Ghibliesque experience.
There are many positive things to touch on, from the adaptive use of the action button ([spoiler]either shouting to activate something, or expressing the protagonist's mood when no objects are in range[/spoiler]), to the complex relationships with NPCs ([spoiler]e.g. the shades fearing the boy, then attacking, and later accepting him[/spoiler]), but the dev's biggest accomplishment is the story.
I'd recommend a playthrough to anyone who has a heart. 8/10

The Puzzles in the game doesn't take extreme thinking but leaves you at a medium level of difficulty.The only flaw that I found was the frame stuttering even with high end gear.(You can easily fix it just by tweaking the graphic settings lower, don't worry because the scenery of the game won't be hugely affected and you won't even notice a difference).

RiME is a masterpiece of a story driven game that will rock you at your core upon uncovering the secrets.This game has left me with an emotional state but learned lessons as well from it.


I recommend fully you try this game.Do prepare for what RiME has instore for you 😉

8.5/10

47286308.review:
A lovely game full of calm, almost dreamy exploration, as well as delightful and sad surprises. I strongly recommend it for [I]people like me[/I], realizing fully that others might find it boring and confusing.

The gameplay is generally linear but gives you as much time as you'd like to explore each level. There are environmental puzzles: not too challenging and yet still satisfyingly composed. And yet the puzzles are more like focal points for your attention, small moments along a grand path. The true core of the gameplay is exploration.

Exploration is rewarding. The levels are beautifully designed, and there are nooks and crannies from which you can peek at familiar vistas from new angles. Many people who dislike the gameplay still admit that it's visually breathtaking. And there are small secrets (collectibles) to be found for meaningful achievements. (You can return and collect all of them after you've finished the game, so don't fret.)

The unspoken narrative is more of a loose poem than tight prose, even though it does coalesce in the end. You can assemble meanings and feelings yourself or read that interview with Raúl Rubio Munárriz in which he explains the basic intent. But he was just one person on the dev team, and there are many layers. Good art can evoke many perspectives.

Some have reviewed this game as being boring and tritely sentimental. I can't argue against taste, but it seems that I value the things they find unimportant. Some say  a pale imitation of [I]Ico[/I], a game that likely inspired it. Well, I recently played [I]Ico[/I] on the PlayStation 2, and RiME is a vast improvement. It has more imaginative and diverse levels, more satisfying puzzles, and a more creative story. It's funny how nostalgia makes old games seem better than they are.

Finally, some criticism. What I can say is that [I]Ico[/I] achieved a lot with very little, and sometimes [I]RiME[/I] can seem too lush and crammed with ideas. It's a nice long game, but perhaps it would have been more poignant if it were more compact, the themes drawn together a bit more starkly.

And as many have pointed out, the game has technical difficulties. Frame rates are not great even on high-end hardware. You can overcome stuttering by reducing the graphics quality and even the resolution. The game will still be beautiful, trust me. I was specifically annoyed that I couldn't get my Xbox controller to work with it, even though it works fine in other Steam games.

Rime is an odd title but can it be a good game? I will be reviewing the game in a pro/ con style and end with my conclusion.

Pro:
     The graphics are beautiful. The game has a simplistic style that looks similar to journey, a cartoon like fantasy design for both worlds and characters. It kinda looks like zelda in a way.

I think the story in RiME could have been pushed a little more, as I basically didn't pick up on any of it until I talked the game over with a friend, and he didn't even get it until he looked stuff up online. 47221729.review:
Beware before playing this game: RiME is less a game than it is a story.  Those who, like me, play games for the story will find much to like about RiME.  Those who play games as games might be less enthusiastic in their comments.  In particular, I've read several reviews which complain that the puzzles in RiME are too straightforward, and they are.  This did not bother me so much because I was more interested in the story unfolding as I progressed through the game.  The puzzles are there, not to make you think, but to suggest things about the plot unfolding before you.  The visuals and the settings are superb in conveying a particular mood, and the mood changes as you progress.  Like a good book, you find you want to keep going further into the narrative; and it isn't until you come up for air at the end that you realize just how invested you became.

My recommendation? Play RiME as an experience, not as a game.  Play as it a story rather than something to beat.

47219090.review:
RiME is an adventure-platformer videogame developed by Spanish indie developing team Tequila Works. The whole premise is really simple: your playable character is a kid who find himself cast away on a seemingly deserted island filled with the ruins of a civilization long gone. He must proceed to navigate the (at times) dangerous new environment with the help of a magical fox companion in order to find a way to escape.

It's pretty clear that the developers took a lot of gameplay and atmosphere clues from the Team ICO games. Putting aside the premise itself and the design of pretty much everyone and everything, the gameplay is all about leading your young protagonist throught the various, breath-taking areas and solve some puzzles or otherwise manipulate the environment in order to escape danger or to advance.

While RiME doesn't reach the unforgettable status of its inspiration, the result is still a really enjoyable experience. The gameplay is simple yet enjoyable and the controls, especially during the purest platforming sequences, are comfortable, at the very least most of the time. The puzzles you are presented along the journey aren't especially hard, but they are varied and entertaining enough in their own right. The atmosphere, the characters and the minimalist, cartoony art style are most definitely endearing and make go throught the game a very enjoyable and relaxing experience. It also helps that the areas after the first one, the Island proper, are varied enough and each feature its own theme and elements. The soundtrack also enhances the mood perfectly.

RiME's major drawback is most definitely its kinda short lenght: an average player will be able to complete it in under five hours or so. That said, the game's world is filled with hidden collectables and hard-to-reach secrets that may increase the overall longevity a great deal, should you have the will and patience to find them all

47173142.review:
I so wish I could leave a neutral rating. I thought about dropping a bad review, but that would not be fair. I finished RiME in round about 8 hours. And I loved it for seven of those. 

It all starts with a young boy waking up at the beach of a mysterious, foreign land. There are no other people, but old, ancient ruins. So we have our lad run about Tomb Raider style, jumping, climbing, swimming, diving, solving puzzles and riddles, trying to find out where we are.

This journey is a most beautiful one. The graphic style is simple, but colorful and very well made. It reminds of The Witness and Firewatch. Not one word is spoken throughout the game, the whole story is being told through pictures. Lovely nature sounds and an orchestral sound track wonderfully add to the atmosphere.

What seriously spoiled the game for me was the ending. I can not go too deep into detail, but I believe it's safe to say that at the end, nothing of the bright happiness is left. Watch the trailers on Steam. They show how the game begins. The ending will be the total opposite. The trailers make RiME appear as the perfect puzzle game for the entire family, your kids included, and YES for the very most part it actually is! The puzzles are not really challenging, the world, the young boy, the little fox, everything is super cute and there will be a lot of bright smiles while you play. Just if you let your kids play RiME, pray that they never make it to the end.  Or have paper tissues ready. 

This is not what I expected from reading the game description or watching the trailers and I feel a bit betrayed. I believe finishing a game should leave you satisfied. Yes, some games have sad endings, some games have a dark theme too so that you are prepared for what there is to come. And even sad endings can be positive in a way.  But RiME just left me sad and empty. I hoped that after the credits there would be something, a hint, a picture, anything that would make me feel better, but there was nothing. Yes. yes. I do understand the message behind the story. But I believe RiME was not the right game for such messages.

So I still recommend playing RiME for all the beauty that is has...but if you hate sad endings, skip this one.

46991591.review:
Rime is a beautiful game.  There is a lot to said about its amazing scenery and mysterious atmosphere.  However, the game falls short in player mechanics; particularly in its platforming.  

In many 3D games, the camera view is located behind the player, so controller movements align with character movements.  This alignment is important when navigating difficult environments such as a narrow bridge.  Sometimes a game will shift the camera view to better show off the scenery.  This view change can make platforming excruciatingly difficult when making jumps or walking across narrow paths.  Many games solve this problem by either locking movement controls to the character or making it impossible to fall off and fail.  

Rime has many narrow platforms and bridges where the camera shifts to an angled position rather than behind the character.  The camera sift causes most players to propel themselves off the bridge and to their deaths.  Furthermore, the save point is located behind the bridge, allowing the player to fail over and over.  Rime consistently changes the camera to an angled position, making it very difficult to platform.  

The second issue is running jumps.  Thirty minutes into the game, my character got stuck; unable to go forward or back.  I was in an area where I had to align three giant blue spheres.  To progress I had to make a running jump and hold onto a small ledge.  I failed the jump and fell onto the previous section.  However, the handholds leading up had been destroyed and my character became stuck.

46986414.review:
Al escribir una reseña de este juego me veo en la obligación de separar dos elementos:
[list]
    [*][b]Referencias:[/b] 
El juego bebe muchísimo de dos juegos, que son los del Team ICO y Journey. Ahora bien, con esto no me refiero a que una lo mejor de los dos, si no que simplemente se dedica a [i]tomar prestados[/i] ciertos elementos para un uso mayoritariamente estético. De journey toma cosas como el hecho de haber varios personajes con capa en el que es la propia capa el elemento distinguible y el hecho de mostrarte repetidas veces el lugar que debes alcanzar (la torre en este caso, lo que sería la montaña de Journey). Esto podrían ser un par de detalles tontos, pero con los del team ICO es directamente un despiporre: el protagonista lleva una especie de capa, el juego transcurre en unas ruinas en islas rodeadas de agua, las playas, hay varios puentes laaaaaargos y estrechos, los molinos (no había suficiente con uno y por eso han metido tres), los enemigos son sombras, [spoiler] en la canción hablan de un chico de luz, que al final muere y se torna todo oscuro, como una sombra (¿Yorda, estás ahí?)[/spoiler], el prota es un ser indefenso, en ocasiones vas acompañado de otro personaje controlado por la IA que va abriendo puertas y con el que intentan que te encariñes... de verdad creo que se han pasado, especialmente cuando, como digo, la mayorá son cuestiones estéticas, ni el juego va de lo mismo y ni mucho menos consigue lo mismo.

    [*][b]El juego en sí:[/b] 
Ahora sí que sí, vamos a lo más importante. El resumen es que el juego está bien. Empieza bien, luego afloja un poco y el final está bastante cuidado, así que deja buen sabor de boca. Jugablemente es una mezcla de walking simulator con algún objetivo (estilo Journey), mezclado con aventura ligera como ICO (con puzzles que están bien, te puedes atascar en alguno incluso) y cierto plataformeo guionizado como podría ser el de Uncharted o los nuevos Tomb Raider (sí, con color distintivo en las cornisas agarrables, exactamente igual). En cuanto al aspecto gráfico de los escenarios, el juego cumple de sobra: es bonito, resultón y creíble. Además, el hecho de ofrecer un ambiente mediterráneo, relativamente infrecuente en este medio audiovisual, me parece un punto muy a remarcar. Como detalles mejorables, los personajes me parecen feos con ganas (en cuanto a estilo), demasiado sencillos (en referencia a lo puramente técnico) y algunas de las animaciones dignas de un estudio indie de garaje (no todas, ojo, pero se podría pulir bastante este tema). Y para acabar pero no menos importante, la banda sonora me ha gustado bastante. Menos en un par de ocasiones, es de tipo ambiental, no pretende que recuerdes las melodías ni que las vayas tatareando en el metro durante la semana siguiente, pero refuerzan contundentemente lo que se ve en pantalla. Y punto positivo a que el tema principal esté cantado en castellano, ¡hay que reivindicar el producto patrio, que no vamos sobrados!
[/list]

[b]Conclusión: si tenéís posibilidad, jugad a Ios juegos del Team ICO, luego a Journey, y luego si queréis ver un juego preciosista que remememora los dos anteriores de forma descafeinada, jugad a este, que no está mal. [/b]

45923136.review:
An artistic beauty throughout that is stylistically impressive and aesthethetically pleasing throughout with a gorgeous soundtrack to accompany it. Rime is a game that waits until its last moments to bring you into a larger picture and it is then that everything you had done prior becomes that much more emblamatic and poignant. It is a charming, symbolic, and unforgettable take on its central thematic elements, though it is hard to delve into specifics without giving too much away. 

It is worth noting that this game is a bit demanding on the hardware side at max settings.

45915763.review:
Rime is the complete tonal opposite of Tequila Works' previous game, Deadlight. Where Deadlight focused on shadows, darkness and despair, Rime is a constant play of warmth, light and affirmation. This can easily been seen in the games' lovely, bright visual style but also in the overall feel of the game. Rime made me think of huge personal favorites like Journey, ICO, A tale of Two Brothers and more recently the delightful Abzu. 

Like those games Rime tells a (mostly silent) story that ends up being so much more than just a series of environments to explore, obstacles to overcome or puzzles to solve. Without going into detail and spoiling the wonderful story, Rime made my heart ache and my soul soar. This is mostly attributed to the sublime soundtrack that accompanies the games most important scenes. 

Does all that make Rime a perfect game? Unfortunatly not. The games two greatest flaws are the obtuse puzzles - which rarely go beyond pushing a button and carrying around a globe of light - and the jarring graphics. Even on my fairly powerful system I was constantly trying to ignore massive stuttering and jarring gameplay, which took away a fair bit of the enjoyment for me. 

It's a huge shame, because with some more thoughtful puzzle design and variety, and a more stable engine, Rime could have been one of those perfect games for me. As it stands, it is still a great game but it could have been so much more. 7.5/10

I have not gotten all the way through this game yet, but I've seen enough to know that this is a real winner.  The design is beautiful and there's a fair mix of problem-solving and hand-eye coördination skills needed (heavier on the problem solving, happily).

It's also the sort of game where you can just sort of sit there for a few minutes and take in the sights.  You're not on the clock, so you're free to wander the strange little island you're stranded on.

As for how absorbing this game can be, when I first launched it, I figured I'd poke at it a little before turning in.  Two hours later, I finally went to bed (an hour later than I should have), resentful for once of the physical need for sleep because I just plain wanted to explore more.

[b]Recommended[/b] for style and substance both.  One dares hope for a sequel.

45813013.review:
[h1] About Rime [/h1]
It really touched me. This game told an amazing story, while applying in a puzzle-platformer game. However, the game itself doesn’t really shine in gameplay. The puzzle feels weak, compare to other puzzle-platformer games such as Q.U.B.E. series and Portal series, where those games open up your imaginations in solving those puzzles. The platforming sometimes seems off too. There are cetain times where my protagonist just doesn’t jump to where I want to. Precision is very important in platformer games, which is why Mario is always getting the praise. However, the graphics are suited for this game, and it unfolds a very strong story, make this game worth it. 

It is better to wait for sale tho, if you are not sure of it.

[h1] The story (Heavy spoiler ahead)	[/h1]

The story starts off with a little boy wondering around, trying to seek for something. The true story slowly unfolds when the little boy progress. For people who had not yet finished or buy the game, please do not continue, this is all you need to know.

For people who had finished the game but unable to connect to the story, [spoiler] this is a story that talks about five stages of grief, in a very superb way. The little boy tries to seek for something, which I interpret as denial. The father is not accepting the death of his son during the sail. As such, everything is seems beautiful, nice and peaceful. Then, as the masking effect of denial starts to wear off, anger comes in. The “eagle” is the sign of anger. The metal ball is the sign of something important, and that the eagle, which representing the father, do not want to loss such important stuff/memories. As you progress in retrieving the metal ball, the “father” is actually slowly wearing the anger stage, and going into bargaining. However, the bargaining stage didn’t really show much from my point of view. The only significant sign is that there are times where you will see a red hood guy walks past in sight, but it slips quickly. The red hood guy is the “father”. “What if, I was there? What if, I was able to catch him?	[/spoiler]

[spoiler] As you reach to a statue where you have to activate 4 small statues, a “dark aura” strikes in the little boy, and started to walk very slow. This is the stage of “depression”. His father, at this point, realise that his son is no longer here, despite he wished to. He starts to prepare a quiet preparation (the one-eyed robots), to accept this. As the robots starts unlocking the door, so does the “door” of his heart. In the end phrase, we see the real protagonist, the father, goes into his son room. The fox figurine is right there to remind that his son is gone, and is not coming back. He later on, let go of the red hood, which in fact was belong to his son.	[/spoiler]

45738260.review:
Sin palabras. Parece mentira que obras de arte de este calibre tengan origen español. Por que, esto no es un videojuego, es arte en movimiento que evoca sensaciones.

Después de más de 35 años jugando videojuegos, he visto de todo, así que sólo puedo felicitar a todos los implicados en este juego, por vuestro fantástico trabajo.

No sé cuál es vuestro techo, pero seguramente, y espero equivocarme, habéis creado la obra suprema de vuestra vida.

Este juego hace pocos años podría clasificarse de triple A, y poco tiene que envidiarle al ICO o tantos otros.

La banda sonora magistral, las animaciones, la interrelación de los personajes, la idea que subyace de cómo contar una historia sin palabras, basándose en evocar sentimientos y emociones, lo que la hace intergeneracional, interracial y multicultural.

Pese a todo, y siempre hay un pero, es cierto lo que comentan algunos, el rendimiento no es su fuerte. Lo juego en ultra con un I5 3570K y una 1080TI, y en algunas transiciones se nota la rascada de FPS. Si no fuese por esto último sería perfecto.

Por otro lado los puzles son sencillitos, pero ... ¿ por qué tienen que ser complejos ? Este es un juego que debe disfrutarlo desde un niño de 6 años hasta un viejoven como yo.

Es un MUST HAVE, necesario en la biblioteca de cualquiera que se considere jugador.

Mi nota un 9.9 de 10.

The art is simple and beautiful, and along with the amazing music it can be breathtaking if you let yourself into the game and along for the journey.

It's not a game that aims to be challenging, not even difficult. It's a casual meaningful game of exploration and puzzles (not hardcore puzzles or anything). But if you do like those games and you allow yourself to immerse in the experience, this is one of those titles you need to get.

Just let yourself go and enjoy this fully

pero capaz de moverme algunas burradas gráficas de forma decente a 1080. 
   En el aspecto puramente artístico, es un portento. Gráficos vistosos en un mundo lleno de detalles. Música envolvente y que acompaña sin desentonar, y enfatiza cuando toca.
   A nivel de puzzles, son relativametne sencillos, variados, y van moviendo el desarrollo de la historia de forma coherente.

Le falta tiempo, ves algunos actos que parecen impostados, no te parece coherente lo que expresa el protagonista en relación a lo que ha vivido ante tus ojos.

   Pero estos dos fallitos que he comentado sería lo que le faltaría al juego para ser redondo. Ya es un 9, una experiencia que has de probar sí o sí. De un estudio español que ha sabido capear un desarrollo complicado y sacar un muy buen juego que ha sobrevivido al hype.

45696781.review:
I really, really wanted to like this game. I came back to it a handful of times after having determined it wasn't for me just in case I'd find something amazing that would lead a total change of heart, but it didn't happen. Unfortunately, this is a game I'll have to write off as "competent, but boring". 

I'm sure the developers did a good job executing what they were going for, with a nice atmosphere, an adorable greek-ish graphical style, an understated melancholic and mysterious tone, and beautiful sprawling sceneries. I really wanted to like it because the main character really looks, sounds and acts in a likable manner, and the worlds are absolutely gorgeous. Unfortunately, the game did not "click" with me. The sad music coupled with the slow pace and long sections of nothing but uneventful corridors and rooms made for a boring experience most of the time.

Admittedly, the first thing that disappointed me about this game is the gap between what I assumed the game was gonna be like and how it actually was. When I saw that the main character was a shipwrecked kid on an unknown island, I expected it to be more of an open world platformer, and was quickly proven wrong. Very little of the world is open to exploration at any given time, and optional branching paths tend to be short and lead only to optional collectibles, so the bulk of the game is mostly linear.  Say, the game's worlds are less like a large tree and its branches and more like a centipede and its feet, if that makes sense. I can't give the game crap for this, however, it's just a disconnect between my expectations and reality.

Still, it doesn't help that the game pretty much punishes exploration in certain parts by making you backtrack through long obvious platforming sections if you drop down one too many tall ledges in search of secrets. I swear to god this happened to me like five times while exploring the desert world. I'd drop down a seemingly interesting path only to learn it took me back to the beginning of whatever structure I had to climb, forcing me to go a long way back up, at which point I'd just give up and walk towards my fox buddy to move on. Add to that the fact that pretty much every platforming section is an obvious zero-choice game of "find the right thing to jump towards" requiring no timing or skill, and you have a tedious platforming experience. Sure, one may claim that platforming is not the game's main focus, but it is still wide spread throughout the whole experience, serving as little more than a zero-stakes, zero-choice and often overlong bridge between the actually interesting bits.

To make matters worse, if you shut off the game and return to it later, you might have a hard time remembering where to go depending on where you left off, especially when the paths ahead are winding and confusing to navigate. I understand that the game does not have minimaps or pointers to avoid breaking immersion, but it'd still help to have something other than our yappy fox friend to guide us around, especially when the first thing we have to do after reloading the game is locate the bloody thing.

Dialog-free storytelling is all well and good, but after having watched a handful of cinematics and looked at some wall paintings and keyholes, all I gather is that we're a shipwrecked kid whose parents were some important folks, and the recurring pervert in the Little Red Riding Hood suit is apparently important too, as he's in our boat when it gets caught in a storm. In general, the game did not engage me enough for me to want to piece the story together. This game might contain a beautiful, deep, heart wrenching plot, but I'll never know because the game itself bored me. Maybe I'll watch a Let's Play one of these days, as having someone talking while playing feels like a sure fire way to keep it from making me fall asleep.

Anyway, let's move on to the good bits, because I do think this game has many positive traits. In spite of the linearity, and the platforming being basic and uninteresting, the game has a ton of interesting puzzles and mechanics that make for short moments of genuine enjoyment amidst the overall dragging feeling that populates most of it. While the puzzles in the first island are rather simplistic, the ones in the second island are fun and interesting, giving me that "eureka" feeling when I figured them out. One mechanic that stood out to me was the damn bird thing that jumpscares you if you stay too long under the sun, like the world's most adamant skin cancer awareness activist, because it ramps up the stakes, making us carefully and meticulously plan our route forward to expose ourselves for as little time as possible as we walk from sheltered area to sheltered area. Probably the second most fun part of the game.

All that is brought down, however, by the fact that the paths connecting every good part of the game are mostly uneventful and occasionally outrageously long, being basically a "press forward simulator", except with you occasionally having to press buttons other than forward when navigating the aforementioned boring and simplistic platforming sections.

All in all, I was disengaged. I stopped playing after a while and didn't feel like coming back to it. The game has sudden spikes in engagement when we need to overcome an actual puzzle or challenge, but those are sparsely spread out amidst mostly linear and predictable walking, jumping and swimming sections with that droning sad music. The lullaby-ish soundtrack and lack of dialog makes those sections tedious as all hell.

I really like what this game was setting out to do, but I think it took way too many liberties with the slow pace, large empty spaces, and scripted platforming sections. Maybe if there was a narrator with a deep voice or something, that might have gotten me engaged enough to plow through it, but I digress. Who knows, though, you might enjoy it more than I did, if you have a higher than average tolerance for the almost uninterrupted melancholic atmosphere, and a better brain than me to piece the story together. 

All that being said, I do think this game is a valuable little piece of art. I may come back to it one day, probably to see if I can finally try piecing the story together. Who knows, I might start liking the game after that. So yeah, my opinion of this game is more "mixed" than "negative".

45696242.review:
A marvelous game, with fantastic visuals, sound design, and music. What sets RiME apart is its unique visual landscapes that vary in tone throughout the game. Cryptic images and symbols can be found all over the maps, which add to the mystery and style of the game. I was particularly impressed with how much work went into the hidden areas, which are visual gems that make the world feel even more expansive.

Some of the "puzzles" were quite inventive, especially the physics bending ones, but I wouldn't call this game a puzzle game; it was an experiential game. You explore, you travel, you see. The "puzzles" were mostly a way of getting from one place to another and weren't very challenging. That said, I like experiential games, but you should know what you're getting with RiME.

Lastly, the score. The music was what drew me initially to the game (even though the trailer was poorly made IMO), and I was not dissappointed. I savoured the lush moments of the music, and liked how it held back during most of the game to give greater impact to those special moments. I wish the music took a more unique route, especially as the game progressed, since its influences (Joe Hisaishi, Michael Nyman, etc.) were front-and-centre throughout the entire game.

Though it has its flaws, overall, I highly recommend RiME.

NB: The game requires a pretty decent graphics card to get the most out of the experience.

45678427.review:
I have tried to edit out the spoilers for those who are yet to play the game however some may remain.

Gameplay: run, jump, climb, shout, interact, that is how you play. The shouting is a form of interact that triggers the lamps and most things that have a slight glow at range, interact is used for moving blocks and picking up items. You will unlock a fox guide near the beginning of the game, and can help out with the story. The game is a railroaded story with no branches although there is plenty of space to explore for the hidden collectables. The achievements are mostly centered around exploration of the island and collecting of the optional collectables.

Difficulty: Easy, there are two types of ‘enemy’ in the game and are both easy to avoid and one acts as more of an environmental hazard. The puzzles are straightforward and never leaves the player feeling stuck, some collectable are protected by slightly tougher puzzles but remain in the easy category. Hints larger scale puzzles are given on a will that the camera will lock onto in a mini cutscene upon entering the area or given as a vision when the way to the puzzle area is opened.

Story: The games story of what is happening won't be revealed to the player until the end of the fourth chapter, until then it will raise more questions than answers. It is delivered without any dialogue making this game multilingual by default (except for the menu, credits and some hints) to offer any description of what the story is about would be an extreme spoiler. If you are the sort to allow yourself to get involved in the story/atmosphere of a game then have a box of tissues handy as the game has some sad moments around <Spoiler>.

Graphics and sound: The sound will help draw you in and one set of collectables is the parts of a lullaby. Wildlife makes the appropriate sounds when required such that it blends into the location seamlessly. Visually the game is stunning with the settings maxed out with the various areas conveying the feel of the area and showing even small details like lizards on the walls, schools of fish in the sea

Longevity: Rime a short game game that can be completed in about 8 hours for main story line and probably another 12 to get all the collectables. The game is replayable however if you want to recollect the collectable you will need to disable cloud save and delete the save file. Due to the nature of the story, expansions and direct sequels are highly improbable without sacrificing story quality.

Final verdict: An enjoyable game that will hit the feels right at the end. Recommended but not at £30 due to short length.

45676664.review:
Without giving any spoilers, RIME is a masterpiece. The amazing world design, the beauty of the music, and the deeply emotional meaning that slowly becomes clear lends to an unforgetable experience. 
The puzzles and obstacles aren't especially hard, and the game is pretty forgiving if you do manage to beef it. 
It's definitely important to take your time with this game, as there's always a secret collectable hidden just out of view. While the collectables themselves don't affect the gameplay in any way, they do help flesh out the story, and they add poignancy to the ending. This isn't a case of "find all 200 gems to unlock the true ending," it's the same either way, but it makes what happens way more meaningful. [I can't really say more without spoiling it.]
This is the kind of game I'd pay +$60 for. The care and commitment Tequila Works put into making a beautiful experience is apparent in just about every little detail, and I'm still not over the ending.

TL;DR: RIME is an amazing game and a beautiful story. Its casual puzzles are forgiving but entertaining, and the big reveal at the end will stick with you for a while.

Not a masterpiece, but clearly positive.

45663126.review:
I'm a little surprised more people aren't talking about this game. The opening hour is brilliant. While the rest of the game never quite reaches the same heights that the first impression leaves, it is still a really enjoyable and noteworthy game. Especially for the PC, which I always feel is lacking these types of well polished 3rd person adventure/puzzler games. I mean they exist, they're just not usually as clean as RIME is.

It's simple, but simple works. Some segments are tense, some are peaceful. While there might be some storytelling through the environments, I never felt like I was being beaten over the head with any 'look how important all this is' nonsense. You mostly just move from place to place, puzzle to puzzle, with a sense of wonder. It's linear, but there are alternate routes to explore which contain secrets. The music especially stands out and really carries a lot of the emotional weight, moving you along through each scenic moment.

I finished the game in just under 5 hours, but I didn't even come close to finding all the little collectibles. RIME doesn't do anything to reinvent the 3rd person adventure genre, but it is a standout release for the PC.

45614070.review:
If you liked Ico, you should buy this.  While it's not quite as good as Ico itself is, it shares many characteristics of it (a puzzle platformer with no spoken dialogue in a beautiful setting laden with the feels).

Puzzles are well designed, with a few core mechanics used consistently but with slightly different twists each time, so they are familiar enough to solve without getting boring.

Platforming is straightforward and forgiving; there's a few times you can get lost or miss the cues about where to go next, but the controls handle well and if you do miss a jump you're usually landed right back ready for another go without losing any progress.  (The jumps themselves tend to err on the forgiving side; on occasion your character will visibly not quite make the jump but the game will let you latch on and continue anyway rather than dropping you into the void.  I consider this a good thing.)  There are a few spots where it probably would have been better to use a controller (due to camera angles and needing to do the two-key running shuffle), but I played through using keyboard and mouse just fine.

The environments are beautiful (especially at the beginning, although later chapters are still beautiful in a different way).  The only downer here is that on my system (which is not the best, but is reasonably decent) there are quite a few spots where it's unable to maintain a stable 60 FPS, so wide angle camera motion in particular can sometimes suffer a bit.  As this only really happened during cinematic transitions it never particularly affected gameplay.

There is a definite story in the game, although it's one that's best experienced for yourself, and since it is of the "silent but evocative" type, in some cases each person might come away with a slightly different idea of what story it was actually telling, somewhat informed by their own experiences.  But this is fine, and as long as you see it through to the end (and avoid spoiling yourself beforehand) you should get something good out of it.  Several articles have been written based on interviews with the game's creators as well as other people's experiences of the story, but you really should try to avoid reading these until you've played it through at least once on your own.

For the explorers and completionists, it comes with a healthy number of hidden secrets, collectibles, and achievements, which you can either spend time hunting down on your first playthrough or use the Chapter Select feature to jump back later on to collect things you missed.  (There are only one or two things that are actually impossible to find on your first playthrough, although unless you're very thorough you're likely to miss quite a bit more than that.)

Overall, again: if you like this sort of thing, you should play this.

45609169.review:
Ever since Ico became popular I've seen a lot of games attempt doing something similar - a puzzle and platforming 3D game with no spoken narration, simple but beautiful artstyle, moving music and some central concept/idea to it all. And as more and more indie developers became enabled to use powerful engines that allow creating something mechanically simple, but beautiful and, hopefully, evocative, the amount of games of this type went up dramatically. RiME is just another example of this type of game. Made with lots of care, genuinely good looking, with a good story concept behind it and yet all too familiar, not particularly fun and ultimately forgettable.

The big issue RiME has lies in the fact that the game never really gets anything to truly hook you with. You run, jump, climb and scream at things to solve problems as you start the game, and that's all you do until the end, with all of these basic mechanics being rather bland. There's never any clever challenge or strategy involved with the platforming bits as they just use the modern approach to 3D platforming where you go along the only (and usually obvious) path, clearly outlined and never need to think where you are in space. Puzzles suffer from a bizarre decision to make action button work only after a short pause after a full stop and scream not working at times if another animation is playing, meaning you always come to a full stop, wait a bit and then hope that you can perform the action necessary, which isn't helping already mundane puzzle design.

And the game never properly knows if it wants to be about exploration or not, as it would give you a bunch of things to collect throughout the game world, and give you an open space, but then can just push you into a linear path when you least expect it with no way to backtrack and see if you've missed anything. In addition right from the start it gives you one of the most obnoxious "guide" I've encountered in games - a magic fox that barks (more like yaps) to "help" you find the way. With the issue being that it always does it either when there's only one way you can take, or when it's somewhere offscreen and you can't possibly know how to get to it, making it useless and annoying in both cases. And not helping if you're trying to explore.

There's no good story or even mood hook either. There's an attempt at one, but when the revelation of what this game is all about comes, it feels unexpected because the game never actually delivers on that mood at any point prior to that. Like if I'd start showing you my ninth grade pictures while punk rock plays and then at the end tell that this experience was meant to help you understand how to make better pasta. It's not completely unrelated because I like pasta, but... It still doesn't feel like that's what the experience was supposed to be about.

Not that the game doesn't try to be interesting and evocative. It does look good, it does sound good (sans that annoying fox), there are a few puzzles that aren't boring and there are moments that are genuinely interesting. And there is a certain desire to make the game feel as varied as it could. It's just that this isn't enough and it's one of those instances where after finishing the game in 5 hours you feel drained as if you spent the entire day and all your energy on it without really getting anything in return.

RiME seems to have its heart in the right place and it does feel like it tried to be an interesting moving and beautiful journey. But it's not what it turned out to be. It's not a game you should be specifically avoiding and maybe you would have some good times with it, just wondering around and enjoying the look and the mood of the areas. But I can't recommend specifically purchasing the game unless you get it as part of some bundle as your time and money would be better spent elsewhere.

45570307.review:
RiME is a game with strong artistic design that lacks two of the most important elements in video games: a compelling story or fun gameplay. While its graphics are intriguing, the sound is mediocre with its focus on ambience rather than melody. There is practically no story for at least the first hour of gameplay, leaving you with little desire to aid this character on his quest. 

But its worst flaw is the fact that the gameplay lacks any dimension: between the simplistic "puzzles", generic platforming, and lack of any danger, RiME sacrifices fun for a sort of postmodern, minimalist, atmospheric art experiment. I HATE when games do this; this is not art, its laziness by the developers. Ultimately, RiME is a poor game not worth your time or money. Perhaps it would have been interesting as a short film, but here it just fails.

Visuals and overall atmosphere are heavily influenced by Shadow of the Colossus, Studio Ghibli films, and a little Jim Henson's Dark Crystal.  It's an amazing, amazing A/V experience.  However, the gameplay is good, too!   The controls are tight and responsive, there's a shockingly wide range of things to do, and you can tell that the devs polished the hell out of the experience to make it as natural and flowing as possible.  For example, the game regularly introduces new goals and gameplay types without ever providing explicit instructions or using words at all, yet you are given enough clues to quickly figure out what to do.  It's very elegantly designed.

Highly recommended.

RiME is one of the most beautiful games I think I have ever played. Both the visuals and audio are done with such perfection you are moved in ways most large budget titles cannot achieve, and while there is action in a common sense this doesn't hold back the title whatsoever. Not many games have actually brought me to tears but the ending of RiME did just that. However this game is purely an atmospheric title; almost an interactive story. 45437733.review:
La mayor virtud de esta producción del equipo español Tequila Works, es sobre todo la belleza, tanto visual como sonora, pese a que realmente se nota que el estilo artístico es una muy buena copia de Ghibli, en ambos aspectos.
Por un lado la banda sonora parece compuesta por el mismismo Joe Hisaishi, con temas que parecen sacados de La princesa Mononoke, y por otro lado el aspecto gráfico que parece que estemos viendo un hijo de toda la filmografía del estudio :D.
Respecto a la banda sonora, mención especial al tema creado por la violinista "youtuber" Lindey Stirling, y un tema vocal en español.
También se puede comparar bastante con Abzu, Journey e Ico. Es más, el juego ha pasado apenas sin hacer ruido, cuando no tiene absolutamente nada que envidiar a Journey por ejemplo.

No obstante donde para mi falla es en su exploración, el juego tiene unos escenarios increíbles, que daban para hacer mucho mas juego y una sensación de exploración mas profunda. Tenían que haber creado una suerte de mundo abierto y poder recorrerlo de principio a fin y volver cuando queramos o necesitemos, sin embargo han optado por un sistema por capítulos "inconexos" entre ellos que en mi opinión no le hace bien.
Los puzzles tampoco es que sean muy complejos, aunque hay alguna mecánica jugable algo original. 

La historia a diferencia de Abzu, o Journey, es bastante clara de entender, y no es la típica fumada mental de tantos juegos indie que salen hoy en día.

Para terminar decir que su rendimiento es bastante malo, pese a tener unos reflejos cojonudos que hacen chupar fps cosa mala.

Recomiendo el juego siempre y cuando nos gusten los juegos relajantes y te llame la estética tan cuidada que tiene.

45423111.review: This is not a game, this is a story about hard feelings. A story about a loss, a story about a love, a story about... Please take it away from me. It's to painful. But full of beauty. And the beauty i everything there. Everything what lasts...
