45380390.review:
A truly exceptional masterpiece in atmospheric exploration, storytelling and platforming with light puzzle elements.

The graphics, sound design and animation along with visual effects, level design and lighting all play hand in hand to establish atmosphere exceptionally well. Environment and puzzle variance is good, with good pacing. The story revelations are interesting and surprising. The established world is consistent and enjoyable. The level of detail to establish it is quite good. I really enjoyed these four hours.

If you can enjoy atmospheric third person platforming exploration with light puzzle elements, definitely play this masterpiece.

+ Exceptional atmosphere
+ Exceptional sound design
++ Great music
++ Great dynamic elements and adjustments
+ Exceptional animation
+ Exceptional visual effects
+ Exceptional presentation, exceptional direction (everything coming together great)
+ Great environment and world, great level of detail, great variance
+ Great platforming mechanics
+ Good, enjoyable puzzles, quite some variance
+ Interesting story/setting (explored through action, exploration and visuals)
+ Great guidance
* 4 hours for a playthrough
- No skippable cutscenes, even after playthrough

45377935.review:
Fantastic game with great atmosphere, nice graphics and puzzles that are not too hard for the casual player of puzzle games... (so, myst-type players might find ths too easy as there is no hours of backtracking and so forth)

The game also has a fantastic story which unfolds between each level and in which you actively take part after level 5.

I don't want to spoil too much, but the end will have some people having wet eyes.

This game is one i really can recommend.  I really wanted to start playing it when i came back on my pc, but i tried to play a level at a sitting so i had to refrain myself when i had only like half an hour.  I probably used more time than the average player, but that's because i also went on looking for items and i have a fair amount of them (all toys, all emblems, 4/6 lullabies, etc etc). 
If you just want a game where you puzzle a bit and have really nice aestethics, then i can also recommend this game, it's got a really nice atmosphere.  For those that also go itemhunting; it gets reflected at the end of the game but i can't tell too much about it as it would spoil the story. Look at it as a little incentive you get ...

I got this game in a bundle (i believe it came with humble monthly, not sure anymore) and the quality of the game really makes the full price worth it, although if you don't search for items the playtime gets shorter and then i'd pay about 50% of it's regular price (which is €17.50 instead of 35€) I believe 20€ wouldve been a better price for the game, but the level of detail they've put into the game and thus work, makes the original price not really overpriced if you appreciate the gametype and play it to it's full extend (thus searching for the extra's).

If you can ever get this game in a bundle or very cheap promo (like 5€/5$) then buy it, you won't be disappointed!

Went in expecting a simple puzzle/platformer (and the first couple of areas are like that). Wasn't ready for the feels that followed  (˚ ˃̣̣̥᷄⌓˂̣̣̥᷅ )


Graphical fidelity is good (runs on Unreal Engine 4) but the aesthetics are more important to lend to the perspective of the character. The theme is purposely inconsistent between the areas which is hard to elaborate on without ruining parts of the story. Puzzles are simple enough though they do better with creativity than difficulty, some puzzles use perspective, light/shadows and day/night cycle, you will never find yourself stuck though as they stay fairly simple push, pull, carry, climb type puzzles akin to Zelda (though a lot less demanding than Zelda's), pushing yourself past the first area or two is important as they feel over simplified. The controls are good and responsive (even on mouse and keyboard) but like the puzzles, the platforming stays simple to the point some mechanics (like rolling) feel unnecessary and under utilized. The more important point of the game is the aspect that is hard to talk about in a review, the story (that is told with no words) but it doesn't take long before you know something is wrong here...


Recommended but not at full price due to how short the game is.

45225076.review:
It took me quite some time to understand what this game was about. The first few hours, running about, collecting, solving, were just lighthearted. But as you move on, see things, watch things change, the realisation occurs, and you comprehend the nature of the story. I'm trying to write this without spoilers, so the language might be a little vague in places. 

Further in the feeling of the game changes radically and there is strife and difficulty, over and above the simple game mechanics. You begin to get a darker sensation of narrative and the solutions to puzzles don't satisfy in the same way, there's a sense of achievement but also one of sadness. 

As a gaming experience this is not the hardest thing you will ever do. As an emotional journey, if you are open to such things, it may well be very difficult indeed.

If exploration of feeling is of any interest to you then I whole-heartedly recommend this game.

45145270.review:
RiME is a third-person non-violent adventure game, sometimes exploration, sometimes platformer, sometimes puzzle game.

The gameplay is not particularly original. It felt like I had already seen these kinds of puzzles, these kinds of adventure in many games before this one. If you already played Tomb Raider, or Zelda, for example, you'll get it. It's not much difficult either, except if you want to get all the achievements. It's also (mostly) linear: even if some places may be huge, there is always only one path. There are not many characters. You'll mostly follow a magic friendly fox, and a mysterious guy with a red cape who remains out of reach. There are some minor defaults, like a camera which sometimes takes dubious initatives, or some zones so dark that I had to switch off the light in my room. It also requires a decent computer.

But it's a utterly fantastic game, and for me one of the best games of 2017. Why? Because of the ambience.
If the vivid screenshots and the trailers didn't give you the compulsive desire to click "Buy" right now, wait, there is more:
[list]
 [*] First, like I said it's not difficult; but it's a good point, because you never feel stuck up very long, it's enjoyable.
 [*] Second, the environment is fantastic. It felt like I was visiting an abandoned crumbling civilisation and I wondered during most of the game what happened and what it was all about.
 [*] Third, the melancholic music, barely audible during the game and yet omnipresent, helps me put in this state of wonder.
 [*] Fourth, the story is great, even if it is sad, and is rarely present in the game. The game - all of it - fits the story, and not the contrary.
[/list]

In the end, the downside is that the game is not that long (9 hours for me without speeding up, including getting a good part of the achievements)... And when the end occurs, I wished I could continue exploring new green grasslands and beautiful ruins, and yet it's the end. But that, too, serves the story.

44835542.review:
I bought RIME on its description as a puzzle game with exploration. What I got instead felt like a walking simulator without sufficient payoff, narrative or otherwise.

The single factor that killed this game for me is the size of the environments, combined with the glacially slow pace. Movement speed in particular would have had to be twice or thrice as high for me not to constantly get bored to tears. It's rage-inducingly slow.

And once a game screws up like that way, you know it won't work in other ways, either. For instance, despite the description of "exploration", the game is almost entirely linear except for various hidden collectables. But trying to collect those is deeply unsatisfying. Partly due to the glacial movement speed, which discourages walking around. But also because stage select is chapter-based, so trying to collect missing doodads after the fact sounds like soul-crushing pain.

There's no way to save manually, and the autosave mechanic is pretty bad; I played through the game in a few sessions and typically had to replay a small section each time.

The game is rather pretty, I do admit. But it's also full of dark areas and zones, and those didn't work for me at all.

When it comes to the puzzles themselves, there aren't that many, and most of them are mediocre or trivially easy.

A concrete plot underlies the game, but it's told in a very vague, nonverbal way. The end seems neat-ish, but also disconnected from what came before. I had to read a story explanation to make any sense of it. Not my kind of storytelling.

I hated this game. It felt like it was designed entirely to waste the player's time. Like some business guy realized the game only had 2-3 hours of content, and promptly cut movement speed by 1/2 or 2/3 to pad the playtime numbers. Instead of this mediocre game that does neither puzzles nor exploration well, I recommend purer games instead: e.g. The Witness or Stephen's Sausage Roll for puzzles; and A Hat in Time, a Mario game, or Hollow Knight for platforming and exploration.

PS: My displayed Steam playtime is wrong; the actual playtime was more on the order of 6-7h.

44474903.review: Incredible effort. One of the best stories, which effcted me on completion. Few bottom lip whibbles. Gameplay itself is perfect, setting is beautiful, music is outstanding, zero UI which is excellent, all in all a gteat title more than deserving of praise and more recognition.

44338495.review:
I've played too many artsy, allegorical games with mysterious protagonists. Once you've played Journey, ABZU, AER, Unfinished Swan or any of another dozen games of The Type, RiME just does not feel that remarkable, even though it predates or is contemperaneous with these works. I played it too late and struggled to feel engaged. Yet, I recommend it.

I recommend it, because RiME is a high-quality experience. It harkens back to the best moments from games by Team Ico and Nintendo's Zelda team. It doesn't do a whole lot new, but it does it with style and attention to detail. There's a fair bit of Disneyesque cheese here too, but it is probably necessary in a game about emotions that has no voice acting.

I didn't really feel the allegorical Deeper Themes it was trying to convey, because they were - and I rarely say this - too subtle and oblique. But that's a taste thing. You might feel differently.

Al igual que me ocurrio con "Ico", "Shadow of the Colossus" y "The Last Guardian", hay una palabra que define a la perfeccion el juego: PRECIOSO.

Y si, hay muchas referencias a esos juegos mencionados (quiza el que menos "Shadow of the Colossus" ya que no hay combate). Controles muy basicos y nada complejos, al contrario que su historia, que hasta que consigues llegar al final no comprenderas todo, pero es fascinante como al acabar el juego vas atando cabos de todo lo que has visto, esa sensacion me encanto, y este juego lo consigue.

La mecanica es bastante simple, y la simplicidad lo hace tan bello, resolver puzzles e ir avanzando, muy chulos todos, no muy dificiles, bien adaptados para que no llegues a momentos frustrantes y no puedas avanzar (al menos desde mi perspectiva). Por supuesto, la exploracion es bastante importante, sobre todo si quereis conseguir los coleccionables, que explican aun mas de que va la historia, mi consejo es que vuestro primer recorrido vayais a vuestra bola, y el segundo si que consigais todo para que ya la historia sea reveladora al instante. Y ademas desbloquea un final alternativo.

En resumen, precioso, vale la pena, que gran viaje.

43928471.review:
Have you ever been on a flight where they show these short, "artsy", pretentious and shallow student-made films to entertain the passengers? 

RiME is like that, but in a video game form. Very pretty art style and animation, but pretty much everything else is uninspired or derivative. RiME tries to imitate ICO and Journey, but the similarities are skin-deep. Those games manage to build suspense over the game and merge gameplay with story to great effect, but RiME does none of that. Instead, RiME copies the superficial qualities of those games, like the minimalism. "If there are no words used in our game, that MUST mean that the game is deep!", thinks RiME.

This game is a massive wasted opportunity, and that irritates me. I wish its developers the best of luck in their next game, I'm sure they can do better.

43906055.review:
OBRA DE ARTE.
A ver por donde empiezo...
Es un juego que, en su mecánico es bastante básico, y donde se podría haber profundizado un poco más en cuanto a tipos de movimientos del personaje, fluidez y realismo en algunas físicas... Pero después de habérmelo pasado dos veces, creo que su encanto reside en esa sencillez. No es complicado de superar, por lo que es un título apto para todo tipo de público, pese que la profundidad de la historia no lo sea. Es una historia arrolladora y aplastante como la vida misma... Lo que empieza como una aventura de un niño que despierta en una isla desierta, sin saber por qué "que por cierto la isla es preciosa, con ese toque de isla griega", se convierte en un viaje cada vez mas oscuro, misterioso y lúgubre, para darte cuenta, y no hago spoilers, de que al final, todo era algo muy distinto a lo que el juego te estaba mostrando y darte un buen gancho de izquierdas al corazón... Vamos, que si eres un poco sensiblero como yo, acabas llorando a moco tendido con el final xDDD Y aquí reside la importancia de una buena historia señores, el hecho de que al tenerla, al juego se le perdonen otros fallos, como los que anteriormente he mencionado. Ya no me importa la sencillez de la mecánica, ni el irrealismo de algunos movimientos o físicas... este juego me ha llegado al alma y me ha hecho LLORAR señores... que hoy en día es muy difícil... Porque aunque no lo parezca, este juego trata de algo muy común de la vida cotidiana de las personas... Algo por lo que todo el mundo pasa.

Lo recomiendo encarecidamente en versión PC, ahora que no tiene DNUVO, luce genial a 60FPS.
La banda sonora es preciosa, y me encanta que el estudio de TEQUILA haya decidido poner una canción final para los créditos en español, si señor! Que quede la marca ESPAÑA en algo de tanta calidad...

Me hubiera encantado que el viaje durase mas, en unas 7-8 horas puedes pasártelo en una primera pasada, depende de la facilidad que tengas en resolver sus puzzles, pero habría estado genial que el mundo de RiME hubiera sido mas basto y grande, pero supongo que el presupuesto para este título era algo limitado... No hablamos de un Assassin's claro...
Ojalá les vaya bien a TEQUILA para poder hacer un RiME 2 u otro título diferente con la misma magia.

Felicidades chicos!!

43871661.review:
To be honest, this is one of such games that you should play yourself to understand, because it’s nearly impossible to describe it with words. I would actually describe Rime like that: developers took Journey mechanics, expanded it to big locations and flavored it with mystique and more or less reasonable ending. If you still do not sure whether you should buy it or not, here are the details:

Graphics – just perfect. Seriously, about 2 hours of my walkthrough I just walked and enjoyed sceneries. The picture is far from photo-realistic but it has its own soft, vivid, saturated style, which creates just wonderful beauties, the sky at night is just something indescribable.
After completion, I collected whole wallpaper pack for my desktop, where half of the pictures were my own screenshots. 

Atmosphere is also hard to characterize. I would just say that you dive into the game’s wonders and become astonished by the sceneries. 

Music is great. It perfectly fits the graphics and atmosphere, and the only drawback is inability to by soundtrack directly in Steam. 

Story. Well, I don’t wanna spoil it, so I’ll tell you shortly: itself it is not really unique, but with the local storytelling and narrative where you do not really understand what’s happening until the end of the game, it becomes just great and perfectly fits the game. 

Gameplay. Frankly, not much to say about it. It mostly resembles Journey, the only differences are bigger levels, more freedom and various goals or destinations throughout the game. The rest is quite similar: you walk through beautiful surroundings, solve easy puzzles and encounter only 1-2 aggressive creatures during the whole game. For some it may seem too meditative boring but it’s nice for such a game and complements it. 

So, all in all, RiME is great and in some part even original game, because, despite usual utilized elements, together they form something new and unique. I would recommend it for everyone, but if you are looking for some challenge or active gameplay, this game is not really for you.

tldr like shadow of the colossus without the colossi.

this is a pretty, somber, quiet experience that really nails the aesthetic and tone it was shooting for. it easily brings you through a gambit of emotions such as confusion, loneliness, joy and melancholy. its not so much that the story is complicated so much as it is very well told. there's no dialogue in this game so all the story telling has to be shown and not told. from a movie fans perspective i appreciate this.  its amazing how such a simple game can brig so much to the table with such a simple story. this is where the game shines. where the game could do a bit better is on the difficulty side. the puzzles and climbing sections make up the bulk of the experience and while they are clearly not phoned in they didn't really break the mold or challenge me. there's nothing inherently wrong with that of course but your not going to feel like your breaking new grounds. no completely unique mechanic that lights you up, nothing too hard. that's gonna turn some people off. there was maybe one or two puzzles that slowed me down for a sec but nothing too hard. there's a place for that in gaming in my opinion though. not everyone wants to be scratching there heads for hours on every single puzzle.for me this broke no deals.

still if your looking for a light single player puzzle and climbing game experience with a very moving tone this could tickle your fancy. would recommend.

43230272.review:
[b] [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31067175/] If you enjoy this review please consider following my Curator page here [/url]. [/b]

RiME is a puzzle adventure game in the mold of ICO and The Last Guardian, while also evocative of other indies like Journey, Abzu and The Unfinished Swan. If you enjoyed any of those titles, then I’d say it’s safe to say that you will really enjoy RiME.

Originally debuting with 2012’s Deadlight, developer Tequila Works delivers a real gem with RiME. While I enjoyed Deadlight, a good-not-great post-apocalyptic sidescroller, I would have never guessed they had it in them to make a game like RiME. I compared the game to Sony exclusives ICO and The Last Guardian, which is funny because at one time RiME too was a Sony exclusive. I’d say the split worked out pretty well for Tequila Works and gamers as a whole since more people get to play it now. I also firmly believe that RiME is a better game, and experience, than either ICO or The Last Guardian.

Being as spoiler free as possible, you play as a young boy who wakes up on a mysterious island. On this island you solve various environmental puzzles that I found to be both fun and intuitive. The game strikes a good balance of being accessible to most people while not making its solutions obvious on first glance. The game also boasts a striking visual aesthetic than is strong throughout and wholly cohesive.

Gameplay wise, it’s most similar to The Last Guardian, albeit with much, much better controls. I actually couldn’t finish TLG because I found the controls to so offensively bad. RiME is much better with it and I rarely found myself missing a jump and falling off something. Luckily, if you do make a wrong jump the checkpoint system is quite generous, so you’ll never lose too much progress. Perhaps the thing that most impressed me gameplay wise was the camera system. So often in third person games the camera can get hung up on the environment or just plain get in your way. This is not the case with RiME at all. It’s very cinematic and truthfully I rarely had to touch the camera controls. It always seems to be in the right place at the right time and more importantly does not impede you at all.

I’m keeping this review somewhat intentionally vague because I think it’s best to go in blind. If you liked the games I mentioned at the top, then know that this is a game for you. It often bests what those games do and will definitely deliver on the emotional beats as well. Tequila Works really outdid themselves with this one and delivered one of the best indie experiences of the past couple of years in my eyes. This should be a game in everyone’s collection.

I'm guessing it doesn't handle key-holding well because the game was designed for controllers. TIP2: Achievement Hunters! Don't even bother looking for the various collectibles if you want to avoid a walkthrough on your first playthrough. Use [url=http://www.escapistmagazine.com/articles/view/video-games/walkthroughs/17776-Rime-Achievement-Trophies-Guide-100-Completion]this one[/url] for 100% as the Steam guides for RiME are trash.[/i]

Recommending this game because I bought it on sale and got at least a dozen hours of playtime out of it. Under any other circumstances this would be a negative review due to poor performance, lack of manual saving, poor controls, tedious achievements, and an embarrassingly bad-looking protagonist. Aesthetics aside, the reason for making a game in this style is an easy performance win, but too much unoptimized-for-PC polish added to that makes the game run sluggishly. I'm sure it runs great on consoles, but the cool water effects just aren't worth the frame loss on PC when you have a main character whose face looks like Mr. Potatohead. To estimate 6 hours of playtime (single playthrough) seems reasonable, but $30 for a game with no replayability outside of achievements seems steep to me. For $15 though, there's enough good going on that I recommend it.

43080750.review:
Maybe it's because I'm in an emotional mood, but Rime hit me in ways I did not expect to get hit.  I started out going "Okay, this game is so saturated with Ico and Shadow of the Colossus that it's an irrefutable fact that it will be sad or uplifting (or sadlifting).  I'm prepared so I'll be fine."

And somewhere along the line this went to "Ok that's pretty sad" to "Ok that's utterly heartbreaking actually" to "WAIT NO NOT THIS, STOP, RIME PLEASE NO I HAVE A FAMILY."  So, fair warning, if you possess empathy, Rime will get tears out of you.

A lot of people complain that the story was vague, but it in fact seems extremely straightforward to me.  If you're confused about something then you're probably taking it too literally.  Also, just look at the names of the levels (either at the end or on a walkthrough like I did) and the nature of the game itself should be made extremely clear to you literally at first glance.  (So on that note, fair warning that looking at a walkthrough is a kind of spoiler, but this one probably enhanced more than hurt my playthrough tbh.)

On that note, yeah, I had to use a walkthrough once or twice.  There are some little finicky points in the game where things just aren't that clear (e.g.; I got stuck in an area where an enemy kept blasting me off a ledge, which no one else seemed to experience, until I figured out that I had to pass by from MUCH closer to the enemy than the game had taught me was wise, but to be fair it had also taught that moving around just under this enemy was okay, so--YMMV).  I also struggled when the game got dark, because Enu (the kid) will usually stop and hang from a ledge but sometimes he apparently just says "screw it" and jumps.  This was only a mechanic in one or two areas though.

Otherwise, the graphics are beautiful, and I didn't struggle too much with the controls.  The keyboard support is definitely nice for people like me who're short on controllers, but there are a lot of areas where it's super clear it would be more fun with an analog stick, and camera control through the mouse is very much an acquired taste on this kind of game, so I'd definitely recommend a controller where possible.

Also, yeah it runs short (and if you're an Ueda fan then you're probably used to that sad inevitability), but there's a lot of replay value.  Collectibles carry over at the end of the game, so you can play at your own pace and not worry so much about missing out.  And the multiple levels are sprawling, with a lot of different tones, so in most of them it's very easy to get distracted from your goal by exploration.  I'm definitely looking forward to poking around again without having to worry about advancing.

So yeah I recommend it.  I don't know how to end this.  I'm gonna go rest my feelings now.

43029869.review:
ok, i'm coming here directly after finishing the game, because i need to get my feelings about this game out somewhere. kind of long, scroll to the end for the tl;dr

GAMEPLAY: i was wary when starting out because a lot of these adventure walking-simulator puzzle games seem to have beautiful artwork and assets, while the actual controls are...not so enjoyable. but this game? the camera is amazing. the hitboxes make sense. there were maybe two or three instances where the camera was annoying and caused me to miss a jump and/or fall, but those barely affected my overall experience. 

the attention to detail in this game is ASTOUNDING. i think the very first thing that let me know this was a story made with a lot of love in the first *two minutes* of opening the game, was how the walking animation changed when MC was in knee-deep water. you know when you're at the beach and you're trying to walk through the water but it's hard because water is like, actually really heavy? the animators and devs actually kept that in mind, and changed MCs walk cycle and speed to reflect that. such a tiny detail, but one that delighted me a lot. and that's just the very first one i noticed!

now for the story...

i won't spoil it, because it's genuinely unexpected enough that to witness it for yourself is something worth doing, but despite my own doubts about it that persisted up until literally the Very End of my playthrough, there IS  a story, and it IS absolutely incredible. it changes the way you think about the entire game -- and when i say the entire game, i mean the entire game; the main parts of it, and the collectibles as well!

tl;dr: excellent controls, heartwrenching story, and while i bought this game for the summer sale, it's more than worth the standard selling price. 9/10

41624189.review:
[h1] Amazing. What an experience. Truly a masterpiece, this is one of the most gorgeous games I have ever played. No need for attacks, enemies, guns or vehicles. Just you, an incredible exploration Puzzle Adventure and a Story, without any Text or Story-telling. Only you in a Walking Simulator. [/h1]

[i] I'll be honest with you, when I first heard about this game, I wasn't sure what to make of it. It looked gorgeous, but I couldn't shake the feeling that it felt really reminiscent of a lot of other games (a lot of people throw around comparisons to "The Last Guardian," and I certainly see it). However, after hearing a lot more about the game and reading about it (and also seeing that it was a lower price), I decided to give it a go, and let me tell you, I had an incredible time.

I'll be the first to let you know, "RiME" is not for everyone. The game doesn't tell you anything: you interpret the story in your own way, you aren't told where to go or how to get there. Some people might get frustrated by that. Me? I was so moved by the game that I couldn't care less. The game is visually breathtaking, emotional, fun, exciting, heartbreaking, and all-around excellent (It reminded me a lot of The Legend of Zelda: Wind Waker. The sound design is also incredible, and I can say without hesitation that the music really added to the experience as a whole.

Like I said, the game isn't for everyone: the story can be frustrating to understand, the puzzles can be frustrating to solve, and some may find it too slow. That's totally okay, you are entitled to your opinion. However, I personally loved "RiME," and I can definitely say that if your curiosity is piqued, then give this game a go. It was an unforgettable experience and a beautiful game overall.

Just beat the game. I was not ready for that ending. By the time the credits rolled everything sort of blended together to give the full picture of what was happening. I loved this game. I don't have a single bad thing to say about it.

I bought this game a while ago placed it on the backlog. Had I played this the year it came out I'd be screaming GOTY CONTENDER.

40923985.review:
This game is a hidden gem in the gaming world. Gorgous graphics, amazing storyline, and great gameplay. The game is one of very few on steam that I absolutly love that has no violence in it whatsoever. While some darker areas on the map may scare small children, and certain mobs as well, overall it is a very great game I could recommend to anyone looking for something to sink their money into. However, without spoiling the game I will say this, the objects and objectives in the game are highly symbolic. I recommend AFTER completing the game to go look for a simpler explanation online as the game, espeacially the ending, is not very obvious in its meanings. This is also a very puzzle and story centric game, keep that in mind before purchasing if your looking for something faster paced, as this game is generally very slow, and mostly aims to invoke different emotions in the player.

As for the cons, there aren't very many. They are on the development side, but here they are in order from greatest complaints to least:

For one, Anti-Aliasing in this game is broken. I am running a Vega 56 card overclocked and I COULD NOT run SSAA even in 1080p medium settings. I was getting 20fps tops with horrible input lag. TXAA also has issues barley letting me hold on to 40-50 fps with some massive frame rate spikes dipping into the 20s. Honestly however, FXAA looks fine and seems to work great in this game. I was able to hold 60fps (as the max allowed in this game is 60fps for some reason) at 2k resolution max settings with FXAA on. I really wish the developers would fix this, but since this game is ported from console I can see why they would have issues like this.

Second, the parkour mechanics (at least on PC) can be frustrating at times. The main character you play has issues grabbing onto ledges you are supposed to climb or jump onto if you are already on another platform. Even if the distance is small and it is obvious that is where you need to go next. To make your life easier here is a TIP: While climbing be sure that your character is reaching out for the next platform BEFORE your make any jumps, this will tell you if he will make the jump or not without uneccesarily falling to his death.

Third, even without VSYNC, Freesync, Gsync, or whatever else you have, 60FPS is the max allowed in this game, I don't see why but that is just the way it is. Mabey it's for the physics engine or something but I doubt it. You really don't need more then 60fps in this game but I thought I would mention it.

Fourth: By far the most minor complaint, but it shows a small lack of polish with the port of this game to PC. MINOR SPOILER AHEAD!!!!!!!!!....... With that being said in certain spots in the game where you have to run from a mob (like in the above game pictures and preview section where you are running away from the bird) you character does not run straight across the bridge because of the camera angle. Because of this it is way to easy to fall off the bridge while running for your life. Its easy to fix this by just tapping the direction you need to go to compensate for the slight drag you have while trying to go straight but it needed to be mentioned so a dev can fix this small issue in an otherwise amazing game.

Overall: This game recieves 8/10 for what it is, and only loses the 2 points due to some issues with the port to PC. Keep in mind, I am a harsh critique. With that said, if you are on the fence, BUY THIS GAME!

40674019.review:
RiME was a mixed bag for me. I was very excited about this game because of how beautiful it looked. But in the end, I have mixed feelings:

+ beautiful graphics: water, rocks, metal and other textures are all breathtaking. The color palette is also perfect.
+ ‎nice soundtrack
+ ‎not super long
+ ‎can be fun to play: climbing, swimming, exploration and puzzle solving

- framerate drops in certain areas even with specs above the recommended
- ‎few characters and no dialogue AT ALL. I personally prefer games with different characters, dialogues and interactions
- ‎puzzles were mostly too simple and repetitive. A lot of the time, I wouldn't even call them "puzzles". It's more like acting a script in a movie because you just go and do the obvious. Only a couple of them were fun for me.
- ‎I found the ghost-like figures too creepy
- ‎a map would have been very welcome, I felt lost a lot of the time after stage 1.
- ‎no manual save points... Sometimes you just can't keep playing anymore and you wish you could just save and leave it there.
- ‎my biggest complain: the story, the "adventure". First, it's way too vague for me. I hate stories were you have very little concrete information and are left wondering and theorising, absolutely hate them. I didn't expect this game to be like this and it totally is. Also, the story itself... Spoilers ahead: I was totally disappointed to see that this island was somehow not actually real and the quest, the adventure I thought I was living, was totally not like what I had imagined. I thought this would be a great adventure were we would end up saving the island somehow, that we would have a victorius and happy ending. But it turned out to be a vaguely defined tragedy. I don't play video games to get depressed or confused while theorising. I play to go on a wonderful and exciting adventure that leaves me feeling satisfied and happy in the end. Think Zelda. The problem is that you advertise the game like it's this great magical adventure, like something super exciting, when it turns out to be a sad and tragical story, not very exciting at all. You should hint at this in your description so that people like me don't end up disappointed.

I really loved the visuals though. Props, thanks for that.

40625055.review:
RiME is a 3rd person exploration platformer, and graphically a feast for eyes - such vibrant colours, beautiful stylized environment, lots of stunning vistas, changing night/day cycle. Top notch aesthetics! There are few locations visually quite distinct from one another. And while I did prefer chapters 1 & 3 for their brighter palette, all of them painted a really nice atmosphere. 

The game features some puzzles too, but if you're following the main route, they are all quite easy and fairly obvious to figure out what needs to be done. The difficulty raises only if you decide to go for all the collectibles - many of them are tricky to obtain & hard to spot. Although there are way too many sets of objects to collect that don't serve any other purpose than collecting for the sake of collecting. Only few types were useful, like outfits, lullaby song parts (such a beautiful tune btw), or metaphorical story panels. But I can stand behind making the difficulty dynamic depending on how the player chooses to play :)

The story was vague and enigmatic most of the time, but when the reveal came at the end it turned out to be very emotional. I quite enjoyed the game overall. Personally, I do like exploring breathtaking & well crafted surroundings in a non-verbal setting, but I recognize that might not be enough for everyone.

[i]Written after completing the game with 9.5 hours played & 31 of 31 (100%) achievements earned.[/i]

39714889.review:
This game has stunning visual design, a subtle (and emotionally impactful) story and fun (but not particularly difficult) puzzles.

The design of the world is beautiful, but in terms of render quality it's not really close to the top new games. The camera behaviour is also a bit irritating at times (although certainly not the worst I've seen).

I found the puzzles engaging but not particularly hard (once I'd worked out the mechanics of a new puzzle piece). If you are primarily interested in challenging logic puzzles, there are other games that will do that better. This is a more relaxed style of puzzle.

The story is not handed to you on a plate, and it's not clear what's going on until the end (and even then, there's a reasonable amount left to the player's interpretation). The ending packed a real emotional punch, though, and a lot of that comes from the subtle build up.

To get the most out of it, I would recommend avoiding anything that might be spoilery, and taking the time to explore the world as you go.

39500281.review:
Giving this a very weak recommendation.

It's a very pretty game and you can tell the developers really put a lot into it.  It's another "mysterious boy wakes up and must run through the world solving puzzles in order to contine proceeding through the world" games.  Its okay...it's fun in some parts, over-long in others.  I didn't hate it, but I didn't love it either.  By the end, I was wondering when it was going to end since it started to drag on and on. 

So here's the biggest issue...It wants to be Ico, but the problem is, the character you play is so generic.  In Ico, the boy stumbles around in a way that gives him character.  He has a girl to interact with and you get to care about him because he has personality in his body language and the way he interacts with her.  In Rime, you're just some kid who shouts at things a lot.  There's no emotion, and even when there is a part where he is crying, it still doesn't come off very realistic...now we just have a generic character who is crying.  Even worse is the lovely score hits you over the head literally trying to violently pull some feelings out of you, but it feels so cloying, it just comes off as "meh."

The end, well, I get it...and it was probably the only part that gave me a few goosebumps, but it's a little too Deus Ex Machina for me.  It's lazy.  I'd rather have a game like The Witness not even pretend to have a story but be somewhat entertaining, then the ending here that felt a little too tacked on.  Like they got to the end and went, "Oh, we really do need to find some time to make up a reason why the player is doing all these things..."

Anyways, I recommend it because it is pretty, has a nice soundtrack and it's a pleasant way to spend a couple of evenings.  Just don't expect to remember it for long when you're done.

39479336.review:
[h1]Spoiler free review, with a short and longer version:[/h1]

I got this game as a Xmas' gift from a friend. Let's roll:

[b]TLDR version[/b]

buy this game if:

+ you love games that visually and emotionally are able to stimulate 
+ you like story driven games with a [u]side puzzle component[/u]
+ you fancy games that show different scenarios and setups quite often

don't buy this game if:

- you don't have a "decent" / above "mid-tier" pc
- you believe that spending 40$ on a 5 hour game might be too much
- you love games heavily based on puzzles

Verdict 8/10, well done, deep (expensive too) and meaningful gaming experience 
Time required to complete the main game : 5 hours
Time required to 100% the game: 8-10 hours 

[b]Detailed version[/b]

A quick summary of the most important subjects:

1- [b]The price tag[/b] can be discouraging and intimidating. The game hasn't any replayability value: replaying the story chapters will only grant you the chance to grab those collectibles you'll be needing for the real ending. Now... im not a business or budgeting manager, so i don't know why this price tag has been decided. I'm not saying that this title doesn't deserve its money, just keep in mind that for 40$ you can get many good indie titles at the same time rather then getting only this gorgeous, deep and terrific looking one that will last only for 5 hours.

2- [b] The pacing and story telling is extremely well structured [/b] as the game will start off with a sunny seaside landscapes, ruled by a peaceful environment and will keep changing throughout the whole game by switching themes, songs, enemies and situations, while being able to be and to seem fresh and never repetitive through the whole experience, which will be heavily puzzle based at the start and will get more and more platforming centered after.

3- [b] Frame drops aside, the game is really polished and meaningful [/b] as shown here:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1275327542

just to give you an example, when the young protagonist has to climb a slope, has to lean, sit down or just performing physical activity...he's actually realistic as his moves are properly represented. 
You will his see his legs moving accordingly and his whole body reacting naturally. Many puzzles and rooms are based on "dignity and magnificence" so you'll always have a chance to admire the landscapes, secrets and clearing out the game areas without any abrupt shifts or pauses (unlike Hob, just to give you an example).

TO SUM UP:

Play this game if you want to be enchanted by a gorgeous, expensive and short puzzle - story driven game. If you're looking for a long puzzle game only, you might have to look for something else.

Thanks for reading and for bearing up with me, leave a comment below if you have any questions or observations, have an amazing day/night, feel free to follow my other reviews at: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32344423/

39388718.review:
I was really looking forward to this game. It looked gorgeous and relaxing - just the type of game I love to play. Unfortunately, I was a bit disappointed.

Pros:
-Absolutely stunning.
-The soundtrack is fantastic.
-Puzzles aren't too difficult (definitely don't overthink them or you will get stuck).
-Super interesting visuals and ideas.

Meh
-The story is simple but you don't really understand much until the very end. Once the ending was revealed, a lot of the gameplay mechanics and symbolism really made sense, but I would have liked to have understood a bit more as I went through the game. Going OH repeatedly at the end of the game took away from the story. This is the type of game you need to replay to get the full value of the story/symbolism.
-Controller controls are a bit meh.
-Maneuvering the boy can get a little annoying - you have to hit some things just right or you have to start all over.
-The game is essentially a jumping/parkour simulator. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but it is not what I wanted out of a game, so I got super bored quickly. Especially when I kept missing jumps and had to start all over.

Cons
-The camera is horrible. It locks in certain areas, making it impossible to look around and see where you need to go. Other times it positions itself weirdly and the angles make it seem like you're closer to something than you really are, resulting in missed jumps.
-Sometimes it is really hard to figure out where you need to go/what you need to do. The level layout is a bit wonky. It allows for a lot of exploration if you're into that kind of thing, but it can become a maze-like convoluted mess to those who just want to run through the game.

I really, really, really wanted to adore this game. And in some respects I do. It is stunningly beautiful. The soundtrack really adds to the atmosphere. The story is emotional and interesting. Yet, at the same time, the game is boring. The first chapter consists of running around 'collecting' a few things. The second chapter consists of running from spot to spot while being chased. The third chapter is by far the absolute best - the puzzles are great, the gameplay mechanics are wonderful, and the story bits are fantastic. Then the fourth chapter is basically a repeat of the first chapter but with rain. I think, overall, I was just disappointed that the game wasn't what I expected. I wanted a super compelling story game with puzzle mechanics. Instead I got a jumping simulator with a story that doesn't really make sense until the very end. Nothing that continuously compelled me to continue playing.

A playthrough of just the story will take you about 5 hours. Collecting all the things and achievements might take you around 10 hours. You will likely be super bored. I still recommend the game but definitely get it on sale. $30 is too much.

39370012.review:
RiME had a very troubled development. The Spanish team Tequila Works, known for Deadlight (2012), began working on it in 2010 with the temporary title of Echoes of Siren; it should have been an action RPG with isometric view, crafting and survival mechanics, building of fortifications, strategic battles, exploration. Microsoft initially supported the project but later rejected it; the ball passed into the hands of Sony, which made it an exclusive for Playstation, until in 2016 Tequila Works repurchased the rights to distribute it on all platforms. Meanwhile, the concept of the game was completely transformed; the title became RiME, which I think it’s for Rest in MEmory and alludes to the meaning of the whole adventure that I leave you to unveil: this review is spoiler free.

It is a third-person 3D adventure characterized by a pleasant cartoon-style cell shading graphics; it is set on a mysterious and fascinating island that offers a great variety of breathtaking scenery. You impersonate a child with a red cape that is shipwrecked on the island and wakes up on the seashore; the starting scene is reminiscent of the final scene of ICO, one of RiME’s inspirational sources; other sources of inspiration are certainly The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker (2002), Journey (2012) and The Last Guardian (2016). From the beginning you are captured by the magical atmosphere of the island, and stimulated to thoroughly explore it for understanding its many mysteries. Sceneries offer majestic architectures that remind of the ones of ICO and The Last Guardian and therefore refer to the metaphysical paintings of Giorgio De Chirico and in part also to some visions of Salvator Dali. A certain spiritual, mystical, and ancestral aura is strengthened by the rapid cycling of day and night, with effects of light and color enchanting eyes and spirit. If you have a romantic and sensitive soul, I advise you to play immersed in the quiet of the night to get the maximum enjoyment.

Main components of gameplay are initially exploration and contemplation; later on, environmental puzzles prevail. Puzzles make use of the alienating architectural perspectives and of light and shadow effects; they are well-designed and help to keep high the enigmatic and mystical atmosphere of the experience. Their locations are full of symbols that recall the unconscious, the past and the memory; they are not too difficult, do not require particular skills. Some of them are cooperative and have to be solved with the help of your companions; yes, you are not alone on the island: a little fox will be your guide spirit, and a strange automata, a sort of Wheatley from Portal 2 but bigger and on iron stilts, will lead you towards the end of your journey.

Gameplay will be sometime interrupted by enigmatic cut scenes concerning child’s past; they help to keep attention high and feed the desire to go on and understand the meaning of the experience. Aura of mystery is strengthened by frequent and suggestive encounters with a black and faceless man wrapped in a red cloth. Pace is well calibrated thanks to some moments of action where you have to face a few threats; in particular a big prehistoric bird that will give you a long hard time, and some strange hooded beings, a sort of dark priests who fear the light. Challenge is really minimal, and it is right for a game that focuses on contemplation; in any case you do not run the risk of dying: if you happen to fall from a ravine or get caught by the prehistoric bird or the dark priests, by magic you would start the game from the previous checkpoint, just a bit confused and bruised, just like in The Last Guardian.

And now we come to the less successful aspect of the game: narration.....

( for a deeper analisys and rating, continue on VGArt Website: https://vgartsite.wordpress.com/2018/01/15/rime/ )

Steam group: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/VgArtInt

Curator Page: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/26168615-Video-Games-Art-International/

39234494.review:
RiME is a lovely game with little danger, simple puzzles, and beautiful places to explore. There's no verbal story - everything is conveyed through murals and flashbacks and visual metaphor, for the most part. It's got a lovely soundtrack, too, and the art style is really stunning in places. Some of the puzzles are really cool conceptually - I love some of the light amd shadow puzzles in particular - but they're almost never confusing or frustrating. Overall, this was a really artistically resonant experience. The ending isn't exactly surprising, but it was nicely done.

That said, there are a few moments where I thought the game lacked polish. Some of the climbing segments twist the camera at odd angles where the controls stop being predictable, and it becomes difficult to orient the character for a jump to another ledge. Some of the scenes are very visually dark, which can be difficult to look at, let alone complete things in (thankfully, the puzzles are all pretty simple). The art style is also so beautiful, especially as evidenced in the first and third levels, that it's a shame how often the game goes dark and dim.

Still - lovely game overall, simple and curious, well-orchestrated and great to look at. I'd absolutely recommend people give it a shot if they're looking for a journey more than a challenge.

La premisa argumental de Hellblade tratada de la manera más tierna e inocente posible, el mismo excelente compositor, un arte fantástico y una narración excelentemente estructurada y dosificada. La innovación está en la dulce y cuidada narración de un proceso mental tan complicado y oscuro, y en cómo enseña sus fases perfectamente reflejadas en el arte, la música y la atmósfera que se crea con estos. Son capaces de crear escenas misteriosas y épicas de aventura a la par que deprimentes y reflexivas. 

Aunque me parece que sus referencias están muy claras, han sabido llevar todo esto a un producto personal y con identidad. Hellblade y Rime son mis juegos del año.

38953163.review:
RiME is a wonderful adventure, a game I didnt think I would enjoy but after finishing the game, and finally piecing everything togheter it made the whole thing a really great experience.

Just as Hob and other games, RiME does not tell you the story by dialogue or text, but instead it tells you by visual queues or by soundtrack, ultimately revealing the whole story at the end. Its hard to describe without spoiling but I will say this, you wont expect the ending. I enjoy obscure story telling and RiME did a good job at it. 

Visually, RiME looks incredible. You will progress through lots of varied zones, from sunny beatiful islands, to dark caverns. Whats great about the levels is that every single one is tied to the story and once you finish it, you'll understand in what way. Theres also a time of day in the first map which was fantastic. 

Gameplay basically consists of platforming and puzzle solving. All are incredibly easy and straightforward. I would've enjoyed a bit of a challenge though. Still, it never gets dull and it always feels cool. 

Soundtrack, as with everything else in the game is tied to the story as well. The more you progress the soundtrack shifts its tone. The songs are well made and arguably touching. 

Overall, what I was expecting to be just an okay adventure game, turned out to be a really great experience. Highly recommended 8.5/10.

38888689.review:
Similar in sense to Limbo in that both games have strong starts and then, after a certain beat is resolved, they just meander.

RiME builds a beautiful world with stunning cel-shaded style artwork and a soaring soundtrack, and entices you with early ideas about where things might go. But then, after a memorable area of hide-and-seek (like Limbo's spider), the plot gets lost. Mechanics that are introduced get a little bit of iteration and then are never used again.

You're supposed to be climbing a tower, but then randomly you'll just be in some other area entirely. One part has a groundhog day-esque section, then in another you're really just following some magic robots. The forest area was a confused mess, with no clear goal. Neither does the rainy area have a sense of place - it's just an arena to run around and solve four simplistic platforming puzzles. Where is it? Is it on top of the tower? It looks too big to be there. If these were meant to be inside the tower, it sure didn't feel like it. If these were meant to be around the tower, the tower should have been there in the background as a reminder of where we were and what our main goal is.

The game tries to give a sense of emotional weight to its narrative, but it doesn't spend enough time developing it. The fox for example, you bring it into being at the start and then it just acts as a guide of where to go. You don't really interact with it further, and then it rushes through its beats at the end. The nameless spirits are sometimes scared, then they're dangerous, then they're indifferent. Sometimes the soundtrack perfectly picks up the pace and setting, other times it's curiously absent.

With a better sense of progression of the tower, more interaction with the few characters so that their stories carried more weight, it could be greatly improved. It's an enjoyable experience, maybe a 6.5/10. Worth playing, but certainly a game with many rough edges that loses its direction in the later acts.

38884289.review:
I like it. There, I liked a game on my own merit, it's not impossible. It's also not impossible for me to like a game despite being biased against it.

I bought the game after having only seen a few bright, colorful, and cheerful advertisements about this kid solving puzzles and chasing after a spirit fox. I did not sign up for a depressing story about a family death, finding graves and ghosts, and overall the plot/story being representative of the cycle of grief. Especially when one of the achievements hints that the fox might "die" too.

I find myself a simple person. I like amazing graphics, exploration, feeling successful, and solving puzzles or otherwise feeling witty and special. I, having had family deaths in my history, do not like stories where a person or animal you become attached to passes away. I do not like admitting that the cycle of grief exists or that I have problems accepting the past. I especially didn't like the symmetry between my mom passing away and the scene witnessed through the keyhole.

Still, I like this game. It throws trials at you that may require some poking at times, but are simple enough to enjoy the scenery. I love the way you move through the water, considering few games realize how difficult it can be to be partially in the water.There's also the way the grief cycle is represented; it hit the feels. The biggest puzzle is the metaphors presented, not the puzzles themselves. There's the story you read on Wikipedia and then the alternate stories within RiMe. I'd love to talk about it more, but I'm also trying to be vague and let you figure it out yourself.

I recommend looking into it; the puzzles aren't as tough to solve as those presented in The Legend of Zelda, but it's got a way more complex story than rescuing a princess from a tyrant. Besides, it's beautiful; story and graphics-wise. I would put this at ... probably a nine out of ten for recommendation.

38805778.review:
First, and most importantly imo, RiME features incredible storytelling. The symbolism and foreshadowing that are almost ubiquitous throughout the game have led to countless "oh FUCK that's what that meant" moments for me, which is always a great feeling. 

The soundtrack is probably one of the best I've heard in a very long time, such that I threw literally all of my money at that shit and it'll be the only I listen to while I starve because all my money went into buying hundreds of copies of the soundtrack. Worth it. 

In terms of gameplay and difficulty, RiME is very forgiving, which is great for those who prefer to focus on things like story and exploration instead of aggravating precision platforming. In that same vein, the puzzles are relatively easy -- I was never stumped for more than 10 minutes on any one puzzle -- but they were still fun and satisfying nonetheless.

It also goes without saying that the graphics and art style are stunning; it's very easy to sit at the top of a tower overlooking the ocean for ten minutes because that shit is gorgeous as FUCK.

Finally, if you're one of those people who, like me, enjoy getting your heart ripped out of your FUCKING chest, you need to drop whatever the fuck it is you're doing and play this game now.

10/ fucking 10 would get emotionally ravaged again.

Don't get me wrong, though. I loved every second of this game. The puzzles were interesting but not frustrating, the mechanics were really cool, not to mention the amazing visuals. Those colors! 

It had its glitchy moments, every game does, but it never took away from my experience. 

Loved it. Thanks for an amazing game, y'all.

A really beautiful game that was a bit mismarketed. Has far less to do with "a land of discovery" and puzzles as its a mostly linear narrative driven game. There's more Dear Esther than Myst in this game's bones. That said, I really enjoyed the story it told and it reminded me a lot of Nocturna in pacing, tone, and use of magic realism. Design wise, this is the best use of affordances I've ever seen. There's no UI or tutorial pop ups, but I never felt lost or confused even during the game's  moments of open exploration. Every action had a clear response from the game and the path forward was never impossible to find. 

My only gripe with the game is that the collectables are often tucked away in a way that detracts from the wonderful story they've developed. I would have rather done without them quite franky and begain to enjoy the game a bit more once I decided to ignore them entirely.

38553484.review:
I hate to be one of those users who complains about tech issues in a review before resolving it first, but there's a major issue that interfered with the enjoyment of the game: framerate.

I don't have a particularly good GPU, but even on lowest graphics settings I'm getting ~5-10 FPS in some areas with this game (15-20 in others, depending on "visible" detail) whereas with other games it's been ~20-30FPS.  Apparently this has been a long-standing issue even after the removal of Denuvo, yet nothing appears to have been done about it.

Update: I managed to power through it.  This game's atmosphere was the only thing stringing me along.
At the end, I was... mind blown, to say the least!  RiME is an amazing adventure, but in the end, [i]es tan triste![/i]  Like Life Is Strange, the writers had the courage to embrace sadness.

...and, well, I might as well bring out the pros & cons:

++10/10 Mediterranean atmosphere and gorgeous music that will surely draw you in if nothing else.  It's very much like The Witness, but with the dreaminess of TRI (actually dreamier than that).
+Captivating story à la Journey, told through adventure and panels
+Good puzzles (nothing hardcore though)
+Surreal (reminded me slightly of NaissanceE, or perhaps Antichamber)
+Quick death respawn

-Controls when platforming feel a bit weird and counterintuitive, as Jim Sterling has mentioned in his review.
-Camera movements in these same areas (and a few others) were likewise wonky.  Sometimes I just wanted to look around.

...and the biggest con of all:
---Graphics and framerate issues, as mentioned above.  In fact, I was [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/493200/discussions/0/1621724915787261571/]almost[/url] about to refund this game!  Because of this, I've decided to stay comitted to my downvote, but that doesn't mean I hate the game as a game (as opposed to a product)!  It's truly an indie-team darling.

38049851.review:
Rime deserves far more credit than it's been given during its rough development history. Quite glad this was re-acquired to become a multi-platform release. I'm disappointed that this sat in my library for such a long time before getting around to it, I think part of the problem was the story seemed ambiguous to me.

[b]It's by design.[/b] After completing this story your perspective on the entire adventure changes. So much thought was put into keeping you in the dark about the reality of what's happening and it's going to slap you in the face when you complete it. Potential spoiler - [spoiler]The only true hint may be the boat in the desert, I feel it represents limbo,[/spoiler] and even if you interpret that you still don't have the whole picture.

Rime is absolutely beautiful to play in both visual and audio design. There's no dialog though you can shout using basic words/sounds. Its world has a dynamic weather and day/night cycle which really brings it to life. Music presentation is outstanding, changing with your actions and the environment to set the tone for the story.

This is listed as a puzzle game, and to some extent it is, but don't jump into this expecting some Myst-style adventure where the puzzles are difficult. The puzzles feel interactive more than anything, they're put in place as obstacles and it's clear the writer doesn't want them to interfere with the story.

Rime absolutely gets my recommendation, hands down what a total surprise this one was. It'll leave you with an ICO meets Journey sort of feel.


Technical bits:
In game v-sync and AA has issues, possibly due to porting, and it causes stuttering. Disable both in game and instead force v-sync and AA through your video card control panel.

38039732.review: Absoletely beautiful game. I'm not just talking about the graphics or the music, but also the story and storytelling. It's quite slow-paced and easy, but perfect nonetheless. Highly recommended.

38026511.review: This is a beautiful, well-polished game that has a great cinematic feel.  The artwork has an original, relaxing aesthetic with no outlines.  Combined with a cinematic soundtrack gives it a very Miyazaki-inspired feel that I enjoyed.  The gameplay is somewhat similar to Tomb Raider--third person perspective climbing, jumping, diving, swimming around large environments and finding your route to objectives.  Puzzles are similar to Tomb Raider--moving objects around to logical positions.  Unlike Tomb Raider there's no shooting or combat, so it has a more relaxed, peaceful theme.   Dying is pretty painless with minimal backtracking, so I seldom felt frustrated.  If you are looking for an adrenaline rush, this probably isn't your game, but if you are looking for a game with a lot of sense of discovery and exploration with some moderate to low difficulty puzzles mixed in, this is a nice experience.  You can't help but feel some emotion at the end of the story.  Short by some standards (check hours played of reviews), but like a good movie, I found it about right.

37980095.review: Super cute, refreshingly different and looks gorgeous in 4K.

37955926.review:
I want to preface this short review to state that this is one of the best games I have played in the category of atmosphere, soundtrack, and story.

Story: The story is really good. I did not expect it to wrap up in the way it did. At first, it seemed to be all over the place but by the end of the game. You begin to fill the pieces, and the story becomes clear to you. I really enjoyed the story of this game. One of the better ones in recent memory.

Gameplay: Controlling the protagonist is fun. This game is a puzzle platformer, and it does its job decently. You won't be disappointed. I encountered less than a handful of bugs throughout my experience. Most of them did not repeat after the first time, and they did not hinder my experience throughout the game since they only occurred in circumstances.

Graphics: I really really loved the art style of this game. At first, I thought the developers would use the same style throughout the game, but they changed it up multiple times. The game has varied environments, and each one looks just as good as the other. There are plenty of moments where you will look at it, and say wow! That looks awesome! To put it simply, it's gorgeous in many cases.

Sound: I loved the soundtrack of this game even more than its graphics. I'd go as far to say that without the soundtrack, this game would not have impressed me as much as it did. I wish they released a digital download of it (I would buy it asap). It picks up when it needs to, and it slows down when it needs to. It's done so well. It won't disappoint you at all.

I recommend this game for those that are looking for a great puzzle platformer. If you're the type of person that does not enjoy solving puzzles. There is a good chance that you will not enjoy this game because it might get frustrating for you. The puzzles are not difficult, and they are laid out in a pretty logical way in most cases. There are not many games in which I wait for the credits to finish, but this is one of the games in which I did exactly that. It left a strong impression on me, and I wish there were more games like this one. If you are a numbers person, I would give this a 10/10 (It's not the perfect game, but it gets damn close to it for me).

37911103.review:
RiME is a game where you play as a little boy wandering around in this beautiful world. The story consists of 5 chapters, 5th being very short, making the playtime around 5-6 hours, unless you look for unlockables and want to be a completionist.

Positives:
-Let's start with the important one, story. The story is.... AMAZING. One of the best stories I've played through, even though it was short, I really enjoyed it. At first the story seems a bit weird but slowly it all starts to make sense. The story even got very touching towards the end.
-The camera angles are most of the time in the scenes well done, but this also makes the movement sometimes different, since you move your character with for example W, you move your character forward, no matter where you look. This only happens in "locked" camera angles and otherwise the camera moves with your characters movement.
-The details on the textures and animations are amazing. There are so many cool little details that make the game just a slighty better. One of my favorites is that if you run for a while and run into a wall, your character will fall and get up.
-The sounds and soundtracks fit perfectly into the game and in every scene are just perfect. It really made every part of the game better just by being really fitting to the part of the story.

Negatives:
-It isn't that well optimized. Even with a GTX 1080 with max graphics, I was able to get 50-80 fps in most parts, and on some very detailed areas and such, it dropped down to 40ish. The game was still enjoyable, and I could've set down anti aliasing and such small, but very performance eating settings.
-It's too short. The story is full and amazing, but I want more just because of the soundtracks and graphics.
-The price. I got it for free from a giveaway (thankfully, because I wouldn't pay 35€ for this even after I've played it). But if it goes on sale and you want an amazing game, buy it. it might be worth it depending how much you are ready to spend on a game with only max 10 hours of gameplay, unless you play it all over again.

37905879.review:
Rime is a beautiful little game where you can immerse yourself in a gorgeous captivating world 
and it generally left me in awe with its simplicity of graphics, it's haunting soundtrack and it's interesting characters you meet along the way. Rime takes you on a emotional roller coaster ride with scenes in the game that range from confusion, wonder, joy, anger, sorrow and grief.  
 That being said; this is a game which left me feeling like I wanted more and that it was somehow still missing something. As other reviews have stated they are correct that this game is short and could use more material within it, however I saw no problem with the controls of the game or the operation of it, making Rime an easy win in my book for performance. if you have ever played a little well known game called Ico, you will surly like this game. Replay value is not too high here, completing a collections and adding more achievements does not really add much, the outfits are cool, but Rime's ending really cuts it for me. So should you invest your time in this game? sure!  the first play through would be no problem and generally worth it, but besides selecting stages for a second play through I don't see myself going back and playing the whole game again and that's sad. Rime has a great recipe of all the good ingredients that generally makes a really good game, what it lacks is enough support and enough material to expanded. It is fixable, easily adding some DLC creating more stages and background stories would help round out this game and complete it. All in all (FAIR) 7.5 out of 10
Rime gets my "Cried my eyes out" Award

37333117.review: A combat-free exploration and puzzle game that sees you, as a shipwrecked young boy, wandering round an island and the caverns below it solving environmental puzzles and piecing together the story of what happened there. There are shades of Tomb Raider in the mild platforming and the environmental puzzles, plus massive globs of ICO/Shadow of the Colossus in terms of the atmosphere and subtle audio work. In fact, despite it's beautiful cel-shaded aesthetic even visually it's got a lot in common with ICO/SotC in terms of the landscapes and overall design. In terms of gameplay it starts off very strong and I was utterly entranced by it. That never faded entirely, but the later sections in subterranean tunnels lost some of the charm without the sunny topside setting to marvel at and certainly the game seemed to drag a bit as it went on. Still brilliant and still highly recommended but maybe a bit less than the sum of it's parts by the end.

37287501.review:
Rime, an aesthetically superb exploration/puzzle game. It features varying environments which are all beautifully crafted. The game doesn't feature any combat, so when you do meet an enemy, you defeat it by outmaneuvering it. The puzzles are entertaining. When I didn't pay attention, some puzzles were challanging, but most weren't. The approach to narrative is: show don't tell. In my opinion, it works, but not necessarily as well as other parts of the game. I fell in love with the vibrant colors and carefree atmosphere in the beginning of the game, but like with all good things, they don't necessarily last.

Overall, I had a good experience with this game. My biggest complaint is that I felt like some story telling came at the cost of gameplay. It doesn't happen until the very end, so I can easily overlook it, because  the overal experience was very satisfying.

37201118.review:
Visually stunning, and the music is awesome.
It's a very nice experience of exploration and discovery.

However, don't expect too much from the gameplay : even if the environment changes a lot and a few things are introduced, the gameplay will still revolve around jumping and climbing over specific areas. You're too much directed to where you can or cannot go, and I feel it hurts an exploration-based game. Basically, there is the main path, and secondary paths where you get collectibles. However, straying from the main path will often be rewarded, especially if you go for the 100%.
One other bad design choice is that camera orientation defines the direction where you'll be moving forward. So if you want to look around to enjoy the stunning environment, you'll have a hard time keeping moving straight at the same time. This flaw is especially bad in the few bridge cutscenes when you don't control the camera angle and have to walk straight on a bridge despite the camera being oriented sideways. The visual effect is good, but the gameplay requires you to sidestep in order to advance forward on the bridge (or fall and die)

All in all, it feels like playing a beautiful movie : follow the script, and enjoy the show. Damn worth it.
So, is it worth the price ? Well maybe not completely, it's pretty expensive, and these flaws prevent you from fully enjoying the experience. I think you better get it on sales.

36692667.review:
Like many others, I got this game for free from the nvidia giveaway. I've had it on my wishlist for awhile, and was pleasantly surprised to get the free game key.

I want to like this game, but ultimately it's not really the game advertised on this page. Contrary to what the description would have you believe, this is not an exploration game, but rather a highly linear adventure with a few small side areas with collectibles. Which is really a shame, since the strongest part of the game is the world. I've always enjoyed the ancient sci-fi theme, and I wish I could actually really explore a world based around it instead of being railroaded through it.

The graphic aesthetics are great. The world, especially the first few areas, are beautiful and beg to be explored. Music is just okay, it's very much mood music and gets repetitive pretty quickly. 

The puzzles are fairly simplistic, and the only reason they can be difficult at times is because the game can be very vague and even directionless at times and you won't see the ledge you're supposed to climb (or realize that you can interact with the critical object you need to move forwards) until you've run around for quite awhile. The game literally throws you into the world with no inkling of what you're supposed to do or what the controls are or how they work. I get that many AAA games handhold the player too much and the devs want to encourage exploration (as limited as it is), but mant times it felt like this was taken a little too far.

On top of that, the controls are quite clunky and unresponsive at times, and only being able to save at checkpoints is something that should stay in the past and not be dragged into the present. At times, the camera can be a nuisance as well with the forced perspective changes.

I've also run into a few bugs with puzzles that let you get into previous areas, but then can't get back to where you're supposed to be so you have to reload the checkpoint. Checkpoints are a little too far apart for being the only place to save, resulting in having to replay good sized chunks of the game if you have to quit in the middle or run into a bug.

I also had some issues with optimization, this game is very heavy on the CPU for no good reason that I can see given the simplistic gameplay. Might be a result of this being a console port with the PC version taking a back seat.

Then there's the story. I'll try not to spoil it, but the ending is depressing, and I think this would have been a better game is the devs had kept it as ancient sci-fi with a fantasy story instead of having the depressing link to reality it is now.

There's also the issue of length. I have no problem with short games, but I do have a problem when they're priced like much larger ones and don't have much in the way of replay value. As you can see from my playtime, it takes about 3 hours to finish the game. I didn't hunt for collectibles, if you wanted to go back and get those it would add a few more hours, but you're still not really getting a great value at the asking price. Especially since I didn't really find the story rewarding.

Overall, not bad at all for a free game, or even for a modest price, but I'm glad I didn't impulse buy it earlier when it was on sale. I'm giving it a thumbs down because overall, the only really good thing the game has is the aesthetics and the world, yet you're not really given a chance to explore it.

36583888.review:
RiME is an extraordinary little game full of charm. There is not a word of dialogue (that is comprehensible), yet it knows to tell a story and guide you along through a beautifully designed world. What struck me the most is that you could feel the passion of the developers, there is a lot of raw emotion injected into the game which reveals itself slowly but surely and leads to a satisfying conclusion. The game itself is not difficult, it has fairly straightforward puzzles but the pacing is great. It's relatively slow, but it suits the vibe of the game and it builds the intrigue more and more as you go on. 

The game starts out in a world that's seemingly open and ready for exploration, which it is to an extent, but it's mostly secrets and collectibles that hide in the corners of the world. The game itself is linear and that's okay. The world is interesting enough that the exploration feels satisfying just to make your way through the beautifully crafted design. I definitely felt drawn to investigate the nooks and crannies and interact with all the objects that allowed it.

The main character is part of what makes the game awesome. The entire game revolves around this boy that finds itself in this mysterious place, guided by a little fox while the full story gets revealed through flashbacks and symbolism throughout the course of the game. His design is absolutely adorable, with a bright red cape and an innocent appearance. There is a dedicated 'yell' button (which activates certain objects in the game) which is the best. I love yelling at stuff. I love how flames flair up as he screams and I basically couldn't stop screaming (or humming depending on the situation). His animations are also just lovely. He feels genuine and lovable in a world that caters to his mystery.

All in all a very recommended game. It takes obvious inspiration from Team Ico games, especially Ico. If you enjoy those types of games then this is right up your alley. At times there are some janky moments with the camera or controls, but honestly it's not to the point of frustration. I just frigging loved playing RiME.
